content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												167 Hours of coop gameplay.PROS:- Great story- COOP- The writing is superb! (except for a few misspellings like "the chest of the souce king" :P)- Believable NPC characters- Enjoyable sidequests (never did I feel like I did it for XP)- The enviroment is beautiful and plays a big role in combat- There are puzzles and secrets to discover- The sound and effect of skills and spells are satisfying and carries weight to it- Editor and MOD supportCONS:- Divinity: Original sins was designed for a specific camera rotation and angle. For those who wants 360 degree camera rotation; you would need to activate it in options. Doing so will let you see 2d foliage and other "graphical anomalies". (I had 360 on all the way, and did not mind too much)- Only three skillbars that totals 30 slots, when you can get 40+ skills with ease. Why stop at three?- Only the player that initiate dialogue with an NPC gets a propper chatwindow.CONCLUSION:I give it 9/10 and a game worth every penny!And I leave you with this:"CYYY-SEAAL CYYY-SEAAL, SHIVER ME TIMBERS AND SLITHER ME EELS!"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Review @ 100 hours and level 18.<tl;dr>Despite having a few flaws this game is one of the most engaging for a long time, and worth the full asking price - don't wait for a sale, get it now!</tl;dr>My wife and I play this in LAN co-op mode, we bought this pre-release as we are fans of the genre but did not start playing until a few weeks after release to avoid the inevitable patch-aggrevation.To gauge whether you have a similar taste to us, we loved:- Baldur's Gate- Neverwinter Nights- Ultima series- Sacred 1 & 2- Diablo 1 & 2- Titan Quest- Eye of the Beholder- old-school Sierra Online & Lucasarts gamesAfter 200 collective hours of playing, we have not had a single crash (platform is Windows 8.1 x64) - this is noteworthy for modern games I think.The things we like most about the game:- the humour (at times subtle and possibly for older players, however)- the camera style (not first-person or over-the-shoulder)- the quests are not spoon-fed- you are free to develop your characters as you want (no forced classes)- ALT-tabbing works flawlessly and quicklyThings which have frustrated us at times, but not enough to dissuade from recommending the game:- mis-clicking during combat due to animation of a mob- the inventory UI does not feel polished (e.g. after dragging an item out of a container, clicking anywhere will be interpreted as a location for the character to move to)For the NPC dialogues we can look at whichever screen we need to, but I can imagine the passive player in a co-op game might feel a little lost or left out if not in the same room as the active player.We have had 1 quest which required a manual hack of a savegame to complete due to it disappearing entirely after selecting "we'll talk about this later" - luckily a quick Google showed us what to hex-edit trivially to reset the quest/NPC status.We have had no issues with performance, but our systems are not low-spec and not overclocked or bogged down with background processes - certainly no loading screens measured in minutes.It is good to know that the game uses 1 core 100% all the time, so having at least a quad core CPU is advisable, as well as plenty of RAM, a 64-bit OS, good cooling and no overclocking.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Ok... This is a bold statement... and shouldn't be taken lightly. Divinity: Original Sin is the BEST RPG I've ever played. Nothing can touch it. It's also my GOTY, hands down. Rarely does a developer put so much of their love and affection into a game. Larian have, and by doing so, they've changed the game, maybe even the rulebook for every RPG that follows. This is the new benchmark, probably for any genre.Even if you don't like RPGs, D:OS will have something for you. Even if you're a casual gamer, it's so well paced, you could hop in for just half an hour at a time. But you wont. You'll be drawn into a beautiful, complex and vibrant world of adventure, mystery and more importantly FUN.D:OS won't hold your hand, or assume you're stupid. You can do ANYTHING from the get go. GO anywhere. This freedom isn't just limited to what you can do, it's how you do it. You're offered choices constantly, be it through clever dialogues with NPC's or gameplay itself. The game will know what you've done, who knows about it, and who it will effect and adjust itself accordingly.I'm not going to offer any spoilers here past the first hour. That would be morally bankrupt. The beauty of this game, is discovering it for yourself. D:OS doesn't stop you from doing what you want. You can treat people how you want, do quests any way you want and shape the story any way you want. This is role playing at it's finest. Actually *Playing a Role*. Want to be the bad guy with a penchant for stealing fine art from inns? Go ahead, or maybe you want to be the wordsmith that uses their charm and intellect to feed your cheese habit. Real freedom, and from it comes real fun.If it's there, you can interact with it. You can even do it in combat too...Combat... oh yeah! There's so much to do that isn't fighting, that I almost forgot! The combat in D:OS, is quite simply, the best turn-based combat system ever devised. I'm not even going to describe it. Words don't do it justice. The worst thing you can do, is ignore this game. It may 'look' like a generic RPG from screenshots, but once you're in, you're not getting out without loving it.One thing I wish could be implemented is controller support. Then, this game would be absolute perfection.10/10 Must buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												My relationship with this game brings me back to Dragon Age: Origins. I'm not an old school PC RPG player, so I don't have any stories about Baldur's Gate or Planescape. Regardless, this is probably the best RPG to be released since Origins and has captured more of my time than I can scarcely begin to understand. The gameplay lends itself to thought and thankfully doesn't hold your hand with quest markers, flickering trails to the next objective or obvious build decisions. If you're not a veteran of the genre the game is going to sock you in the face over and over again, but it feels so good when you do finally learn to dodge the punch. Encounters, especially with bosses, seem unfair at the outset when they pit your 2 to 4 man group up against 5, 6 or 7+ enemies. A little element mixing and ingenuity can see two turns tilt a battle in your favor or bad positioning have you reloading in a heartbeat. You can use mages to deal massive AOE damage by combining elements such as fire and poison for huge explosions or catering to a melee character with massive magic buffs to create a massive wrecking ball. There's a certain level of sarcasm and wit peppered into the dialogue along with pop culture references that can bring a smile to the face without really overwhelming. Good music, nice looking areas--it's definitely worthy of all of the great reviews it's been getting. In a few weeks I'll probably have a 100+ hours into this and I'll still be coming back for more. There's even frickin' multiplayer, with rock-paper-scissor arguements that can come up between players on how to handle quest decisions. If you don't have a friend you can set your AI partner's behavior and experience two main characters disagreeing. It's fantastic. Oh, you can rob entire towns blind, too.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
NeutralPretty slow moving at the start of the gameThe game requires a reasonable amount of patienceNot a lot of direction in where to go / what to doCharacter and gameplay progression feels very unconventional. You have to take initiative to make sure you character is getting new skills and increasing in powerPositivesFeels like a proper RPGHeaps of freedom of choiceInteresting and varied character creationLots of fun skills/itemsCombat is really free-forming which is awesome. Rewards inventive/smart ability and item usageRewards explorationArt direction is solid, lots of interesting environments and maintains a consistent level of quality even with its unconventionally saturated colour palette Writing is pretty good, relatively interesting universe/storylineWriting also tongue-in-cheek (though perhaps a little too often)NegativesThere are times when you will probably need a walkthrough to progress because it is not clear how to progress otherwiseCombat often devolves into elemental ♥♥♥♥♥torm for lack of a better termSome of the combat scenarios will become more of a routine of using the same skills in orderCharacter balance is a little awkward at times. Trying to go into multiple specialties does not seem very effective and my rogue character (especially the invisibility spell) seemed pretty overpowered in the early stages of the game  Minor GripesIdle animations can make properly selecting targets in combat a painNon-grid-based combat can be finicky at timesCrafting could have been fleshed out a lot moreAlthough it's mostly just the nature of the type of game it is, the RNG in the combat can definitely be frustratingOverall, Divinity is a fantastic game and one of the best I have played in its particular genre. Just make sure you know what you are signing yourself up for!

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												This is definitely the best RPG I've played in years. The game has very little hand-holding and it makes you have to figure out stuff on your own. Quests aren't simply little exclamation points over character's heads, you don't have to necessarily run back to town to "turn in" a quest, you're not given a little point on a map for you to follow. This game wants you to become invested in its world, and invested I have definitely become. In most RPG's I've played recently I know the names of like, maybe 2 NPCs, because if I need to go to them for some reason the game will say, in capital letters, "GO HERE AND TURN IN THIS SPECIFIC QUEST TO PROCEED." This game doesn't do that, it's not its style.The first main quest in the game is essentially a murder mystery, which might not sound too amazing on paper, but it's a fantastic starting point in the game because it forces you to become invested in the world by talking to all of the NPC's, learning their relationships, collecting clues, etc... Your journal in the game recounts what you've learned, but it doesn't make any of the deductions for your, it's up to you, the player, to deduce who you think is the murderer.This type of quest design pervades throughout the game. If you play this game you may become a little frustrated at first because of how used current gamers are to having their hands held, but if you persevere (and please don't use a wiki) then you will find one of the most immersive and enjoyable games you'll ever play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												The best RPG I've played in a very long time. The closest a video game can get to a pen and paper RPG, Chris and I spent our first 5 hours just wandering around town literally doing nothing but stealing paintings, talking to kittens, and occasionally massacring random villagers. There's a lot of humor, a million ways to play the game, great turn based combat that is definitely not overly easily or too hard. The co-op is the best I've seen in an RPG, you can each make independant decisions and actually have your characters argue ending in a game of rock paper scissors, the victor getting the final say. The game doesn't hold your hand at all, so expect to have to learn and be creative, just as you have to do in a pen and paper story. There's crafting thats entirely experimental that I can't find two online lists that have found all the same things because theres that much. It's classless so you can really make your own character who you want them to be. There's a huge long story to this game, but I've been completely satisfied with my purchase and excited for the rest of the game without even venturing very far from the first town. I highly recommend Divinity if you are a fan of RPGs.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												I've had a lot of fun playing Divinity as it reminds me of time spent many years ago playing old school Bioware Infinity Engine RPGs like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale.  The engine, graphics, sound and production values are all triple-A quality (for a top-down RPG) which suprised me for a game that came out of a kickstarter campaign. The learning/difficulty curve seems about right (for a non-powergamer playing on normal), with the game being quite challenging at first but after a while the gradual pacing and steady level progression kept me wanting to play. Not to mention the decent exposition and story line that is well above par for the genre. The "classless" system works really well, providing a fair amount of freedom in shaping your source hunters throughout and allowing you to adapt playing style as you discover the magic and combat systems.  The turn based combat is really good, and will appeal to lovers of games like X-Com and Final Fantasy. Can't wait to try out co-op and highly recommend this game to RPG lovers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Divinity: Original Sin is wonderful.  From the serious characters to the quirky characters to the crafting and the combat, this game delivers on all counts.  Improving it would be difficult, though not entirely impossible.Two things I love about it: 1. Every battle presents some degree of challenge with few exceptions as the adversaries are equally matched to the playable characters.  Even a difference of one level can be devastating (e.g. a level 7 adversary tends to annihilate a level 6 party member).  This does bar access to some regions of the world, but it does so organically.  You can attempt it and fail or you could mark it on your map and return later.2. All of the skills (special attacks) gained remain useful throughout the game.  In many RPGs, the early skills become useless partway through and/or get replaced by upgraded versions.  In D:OS, they remain pertinent and never get replaced or outclassed by an upgraded version.  This is due to the skills scaling in effect as the characters progress improving their attributes and equipping superior weapons as well as to the old school combat system.  For instance, Minor Heal remains useful later on because its cooldown decreases as Intelligence increases and so, my healer could cast it every single turn by level 13.  I use it while Strong Regenerate cools down and out of combat to quickly recover the party.One thing of which to be aware: The game begins slowly and the beginning is not overly engaging.  It is a game that gets better as you play it which has pros and cons.  The pro is that it is wonderful as I said; the con, that many people give up on it early on.  Honestly, I did not play it for a while because it did not engage me as I am accustomed to games doing.  Give it a few hours and once you can leave Cyseal without being murdered by undead, you can really start enjoying it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
SummaryA good game with some flaws and great cooperative play.GameplayGame features a simple yet powerful(tho still limited) and funny crafting system and you could completely ignore if you don't like crafting. Crafted items are comparable to found and sold by vendors ones.Combat is... well, almost perfect. AI is sometimes bugged, but devs constantly improve it. Main issue is lava - you could kill anything not invulnerable with it.Questing is fun, well written and diverse, however it seems last chapter was rushed till release as it contains a way less quests than 1&2 ones on bigger territory. Main story is bug-free, but some quests are uncompliteable at 2 & 3 chapters.Non-mage characters will probably face lack of different skills, while mages enjoy diverse and rich amount of spells, both harmful and helpful.ReplayabilityIn my opinion game features zero-to-none replayability cause there's no major game-changing choices you could make. Game is filled with plenty of minor ones but those only affect your end-game stats via so-called "traits" like compassionate or blunt.Co-opThe game is desinged for two players. Both of you could do everything, no limits, later on you'll be able to take control of additional henchmen. You could savely afk while your partner takes control of your character. Game poses options for you to play a rock-scissor-paper game when you can't agree on certain answer in dialogue.Last-battle You can't take evil side by killing Astarte. And tis battle is extremely easy even on hard, cause dragon is not immune to disables. Boring.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								An intstant classic and a game made several years too late (where were you my whole life!?) Well, now it's finally going to release and I must say it's a very well made Ultima/Baulder's Gate styled game that will leave you doing random stuff for hours. Literally hours. I think that's the only bad quality of the game. You can play for eight hours straight and seemingly get nowhere. That was the charm of Ultima too, but in this case, for my life and where it is, I don't have the patience.The graphics are very good for the isometric portrayal of the game world, and the interactions with the environment are a welcome sight to see. Although the world feels alive, the people feel dull. Many of the villagers will not help you much with quests as they all say the same thing and do little in hinting you where to go next. That just adds to the hours spent meandering around doing nothing. While I love it when a game does not hold your hand it must try better at making you understand the world you are playing in. Otherwise I'd love to see more map markers for quests.Combat is highly rewarding. Finally we have a game where your tactical decisions mean a lot. I was expecting this from games like Dragon Age but that game never had the envronment as a tactic as much as this game does. Your characters matter, and a team of warriors will be ill prepared against magic while a team of rogues will die fast against a strong opponent. By using your partners to full effectiveness, it feels everyone has a place in the world.The loot and trading is awesome and makes the game feel very free and open. You can do anything you want. Lastly, the music and menu design is very well done. All things considered this is a really well built game, with deep lore to explore, allows you to do anything you want, and keeps you progressing as you play. But I will warn you: be prepared to sink a few hundred hours on your first playthrough (unaided) since a few quests can be a bit overmuch to explore.I'll also add, the first quests make it very slow to have multiple playthroughs of the game. If I were you I'd skip most of them just to get your playthroughs underway. Most of the stuff in the first town is talking and meandering and highly forgettable.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Everything that's great about old school CRPGs is present in Divinity: OS. The simplest way to put it is this: if you pine for a modern RPG in the spirit of Baldur's Gate I and II, Icewind Dale, and the first two Fallout games, drop whatever crap game you're currently playing and pick this one up as soon as you can. The world is alive and every object serves a purpose. The level of interaction is on par with the Ultima series (VII and UO come to mind) -- perhaps even better. The combat is immersive, tactical, unpredictable, and plenty of fun. There's nothing quite like creating a poison cloud around your enemies and then loosing and fire arrow in the middle of the fray to watch them all explode and burn. And that's just one of the many element/environment combos you can pull off on a whim.It begins with a murder mystery (like Ultima VII). Buy it. It's that good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This is pretty much everything I could have wanted in a Baldur's Gate-style RPG. You can steal pretty much everything that isn't nailed down, but you can't do it when anyone is watching, lest they alert the guards. You can bash doors and chests open if you don't have a thief in your party. There are a number of classes in addition to the classic 4 (Fighter, Mage, Cleric, Thief), but you can customize them to however you'd like them if you don't like what Larian offers. Turn based combat where the environment affects your spells (Shocking a nearby enemy while it's raining may have the desired effect of stunning them, but it may also arc and stun yourself too!) Quests have multiple ways to solve them, which is sort of necessary, as you're limited to two party members. Oh, and when two different people play the two characters? You can argue about the actions you take and your dialog choices can affect how other NPCs react to you and how well you can persuade them to do things they may not want to, via Intimidation, Charm, and appealing to Reason.I think my only real critique is that in combat, it's super easy to accidentally target something you didn't mean to and thus waste a turn, possibly to lethal outcomes.Overall, it's a fantastically fun game that takes the best parts of Planescape: Torment and Fallout 2. The competitive co-op is just icing on the cake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Original Early Access review:This is shaping up to be a really enjoyable RPG. It has a fun story and the combat is engaging and mostly deterministic. I've played about 20 hours, and I think I've exhausted the currently available alpha content. I'd like to have an option for a free rotating camera; since everything seems to be fully 3d modeled, I don't see any technical reason not to. It would also be nice to have dialog choices somewhere in between "I hate you and want you to die" and "I love you, let me be your slave forever". Aside from a few small bugs and the above issues, I have no complaints about the game. Definitely worth buying, even if they release the other 80% of the game without fixing any of the issues.Release update:The game is still very worth buying. I haven't noticed any of the bugs that I experienced in early access now that it has been released. I'm playing multiplayer now and it is loads of fun. Co-operating with a friend adds a whole new dimension to combat. Text chat works well, athough text chat is inherently clunky for this kind of game. I'd reccommend being on skype or teamspeak to play with a friend or three. An option for a free rotating camera has been added (I love you for this Larian Studios) with the caveat that the main compaign wasn't intended to be view from the unlocked angles. I haven't noticed any artifacts yet, but I'm incredibly pleased to have the option even if I did see them.Minor griefs:The only bug (new; nothing that I saw in EA still exists) that has bothered me is that walking on environmental surfaces seems to tick the environmental damage way too many times. Zombies can walk across their own secreted poision to heal to full and one of my party members walking across a single meter of poision surface might take 5x 10-15 damage ticks and end up almost dead. The multiplayer chat window makes it a bit tough for both players to keep up with the story when only one player gets to see the dialogue play out in the large font, high contrast window (and view what can be said instead of only what is said). I initially had trouble getting my friend's companion to bind back to him when reloading; it turns out that companions are configured with the first button on the esc menu. The dialogue options are still very binary, the same as they were during early access. Overall:The game plays a lot like D&D (4th ed? no daily limits on spells for spellcasters in this) for the computer. If you like D&D then you will probably like Divinity: Original Sin.New campaigns and mods from the dev tools will only make D:OS better.The overall experience is phenomenal. Grab a friend and start playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Divinity: Original Sin (DoS) is an excellent rpg game. With stunning graphics, nearly endless choices, and lots of difficult, advanced battles, DoS is an epic rpg. NPC's show lots of personality, whether or not they repeat the same lines over and over. Dos allows you to interact with the environment. For example, if a wooden barricade is blocking your path, you can shoot fire at it, then make it rain to diffuse the fire to continue walking your original path. No game can be perfect, and DoS is no exception. Early progression can be difficult and long, and people that dislike turn based combat will likely dislike the combat sequences in the game. DoS is a top down, Open world Rpg Epic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												First of all, I loved Divine Divinity and I waited long for its spiritual sequel and if anybody who reads this felt the same -	 Divinity Original Sin  IS this sequel. With a playtime of almost 20 hours, i didn't even get to the second map, I mean this game is HUGE! The combat is turn-based, everything else is real-time with a transition between combat and exploring.In all points, it is a upgrade to its predecessor: + a extensive crafting system + beautiful landscapes (although the texture quality could be better) + humor (a underestimated quality in games) + completely unrestricted skillsystem (a rogue attacking with close-combat mageskills, totally possible!) + many objects are destructable, movable AND you can "borrow" them. :) + the elemental system! (cover enemies in oil and light them on fire, then make it rain and freeze them. Only one example.) + Well, I'm done here, play the game, find a few points for yourself, be surprised.There is only one downside, most of the dialogs are not voiced, so there's a lot to read. (In case you want to follow the story)Other negative points, as descripted in the "negative reviews" section, are also partially true, but in my opinion these are minor setbacks for an otherwise great game.10/10 would play again, oh wait, I'm not done yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Everything that's great about old school CRPGs is present in Divinity: OS. The simplest way to put it is this: if you pine for a modern RPG in the spirit of Baldur's Gate I and II, Icewind Dale, and the first two Fallout games, drop whatever crap game you're currently playing and pick this one up as soon as you can. The world is alive and every object serves a purpose. The level of interaction is on par with the Ultima series (VII and UO come to mind) -- perhaps even better. The combat is immersive, tactical, unpredictable, and plenty of fun. There's nothing quite like creating a poison cloud around your enemies and then loosing and fire arrow in the middle of the fray to watch them all explode and burn. And that's just one of the many element/environment combos you can pull off on a whim.It begins with a murder mystery (like Ultima VII). Buy it. It's that good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												A return to what made the cRPG genre great. If you are a fan of the older D&D titles, such as Pool of Radiance, the original Bard's Tale, and the Baulder's Gate/Icewind Dale series, then this game will scratch that itch. This title takes all the great things of the cRPG genre and updates to modern features where sensible, such as easy item transfer, character interaction, and character development, while keeping the older game play style and difficulty.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This is pretty much everything I could have wanted in a Baldur's Gate-style RPG. You can steal pretty much everything that isn't nailed down, but you can't do it when anyone is watching, lest they alert the guards. You can bash doors and chests open if you don't have a thief in your party. There are a number of classes in addition to the classic 4 (Fighter, Mage, Cleric, Thief), but you can customize them to however you'd like them if you don't like what Larian offers. Turn based combat where the environment affects your spells (Shocking a nearby enemy while it's raining may have the desired effect of stunning them, but it may also arc and stun yourself too!) Quests have multiple ways to solve them, which is sort of necessary, as you're limited to two party members. Oh, and when two different people play the two characters? You can argue about the actions you take and your dialog choices can affect how other NPCs react to you and how well you can persuade them to do things they may not want to, via Intimidation, Charm, and appealing to Reason.I think my only real critique is that in combat, it's super easy to accidentally target something you didn't mean to and thus waste a turn, possibly to lethal outcomes.Overall, it's a fantastically fun game that takes the best parts of Planescape: Torment and Fallout 2. The competitive co-op is just icing on the cake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Do you long for the days of yore? The bygone era of endless rpg's that would immerse you and make you lose all track of time?Games that would let you decide the way to play, the way to react and the actual outcome of the game's story? The days that games that would let you get through those long, cold and wet winters when no child (friend or foe) could be found roaming the neighborhood? No need to dream about the past any longer: Divinity: Original Sin is an ode to those glory days, when RPG's could immerse and entice you so deeply that you would look up after 3 months of playing and ask yourself; How long have I been away from society? Do my friends still know my name? Are my parents still alive? And the most important question of all; Why haven't I finished this game yet?If anything of the above sounds familiar, pleasant or ♥♥♥♥ING AWESOME; GO BUY THIS♥♥♥♥♥♥RIGHT NOW!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Original Early Access review:This is shaping up to be a really enjoyable RPG. It has a fun story and the combat is engaging and mostly deterministic. I've played about 20 hours, and I think I've exhausted the currently available alpha content. I'd like to have an option for a free rotating camera; since everything seems to be fully 3d modeled, I don't see any technical reason not to. It would also be nice to have dialog choices somewhere in between "I hate you and want you to die" and "I love you, let me be your slave forever". Aside from a few small bugs and the above issues, I have no complaints about the game. Definitely worth buying, even if they release the other 80% of the game without fixing any of the issues.Release update:The game is still very worth buying. I haven't noticed any of the bugs that I experienced in early access now that it has been released. I'm playing multiplayer now and it is loads of fun. Co-operating with a friend adds a whole new dimension to combat. Text chat works well, athough text chat is inherently clunky for this kind of game. I'd reccommend being on skype or teamspeak to play with a friend or three. An option for a free rotating camera has been added (I love you for this Larian Studios) with the caveat that the main compaign wasn't intended to be view from the unlocked angles. I haven't noticed any artifacts yet, but I'm incredibly pleased to have the option even if I did see them.Minor griefs:The only bug (new; nothing that I saw in EA still exists) that has bothered me is that walking on environmental surfaces seems to tick the environmental damage way too many times. Zombies can walk across their own secreted poision to heal to full and one of my party members walking across a single meter of poision surface might take 5x 10-15 damage ticks and end up almost dead. The multiplayer chat window makes it a bit tough for both players to keep up with the story when only one player gets to see the dialogue play out in the large font, high contrast window (and view what can be said instead of only what is said). I initially had trouble getting my friend's companion to bind back to him when reloading; it turns out that companions are configured with the first button on the esc menu. The dialogue options are still very binary, the same as they were during early access. Overall:The game plays a lot like D&D (4th ed? no daily limits on spells for spellcasters in this) for the computer. If you like D&D then you will probably like Divinity: Original Sin.New campaigns and mods from the dev tools will only make D:OS better.The overall experience is phenomenal. Grab a friend and start playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												A very solid game overall - a must-buy if you're a fan of old-school cRPGs. The turn-based combat system is extremely deep and (especially in co-op mode) seems to help in making the combat not feel like a chore. It does have issues: often times it'll be hard to see where the edges of ground effects (fire, poison, etc.) are, especially if they're covered by grass. This has resulted in my characters taking unnecessary damage more times than I can count. Often times your character's vision will also be blocked for no reason, which can be frustrating. However, these issues are only minor and I expect they will be patched out in the near future.The story is engaging and the quests are mostly interesting, but unfortunately (or fortunately if you're like me) there's barely any voice acting. That is forgivable, though, as the game has a gigantic amount of dialogue. If you like reading, just buy the game already!One additional point I must bring up is the fact that the game starts off in a slow-ish manner. My friend and I were not very impressed by the combat system at the very beginning of the game, but it gets SO MUCH better after a few hours once you start getting more and more abilities to play around with.To summarize: the game is very good, but not perfect. 100% recommended if you're into cRPGs, otherwise you might want to read around a bit more to make sure that the game is for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Amazing game, I was glued to my screen the first few days after I bought this game.Music: original, incredible, love the main theme.Graphics: A lot better than you would expect from an indie game, though it warmed up my GPU faster than I would have expected.Gameplay: Love the storyline, lots of sidequests, choices, free world, the only downside is everyonce in a while the entire progress of a quest hinges on you finding one button. Some quests had a very original way of solving them. I was stumped quite a few times, sometimes even hours on a puzzle, but when you solve them, it is extremely satisfactory. Using a walkthrough will reduce your enjoyment of this game a lot. As they hint themselves though: unless you are the most careful player in the world, save often. Bugs: Encountered 1 bug in my entire playthrough. It was annoying, but since the game has 10 autosaves standard(up to 25), it was pretty easy to just load one, which fixed the situation.Overall: Definitely in my top 10 list of Steam games I have ever played. If you are a D&D/pathfinder/.. player, you will love the open world, choices, consequences. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												To put it briefly:If you like Baldur's Gate or PlaneScape:Torment or the XCom series and games like them, then you'll probably like this game.If you're expecting Diablo, then don't get Divinity: Original Sin.This game does not have quest markers, doesn't have highlights of where to go and what to say, and it won't give you an obvious crafting system.You can play it like a mindless killing machine and pretend it's Diablo, but then you'll be missing what I think are the best parts.To craft, you find books which give you "recepies". They will go to an easily accessible list, but it will be in the form of "When trying to survive in the wild, I think a couple of branches are priceless. They can be made into a make-shift spear, staff or even a make-shift dagger."You can also try to use common sense and discover crafting formulas on your own, if your character has enough crafting skill of course.Basically, the game expects you to read the lore, and to think for yourself when trying to both survive combat and solve the various puzzles.Regarding the difficulty levels of the game:I've put in hundreds of hours in all the XCom games, all Civilization games, all Fallout games, Baldur's Gate, PlaneScape:Torment, and I love those kinds of slow tactical and strategic games.I don't know if I just got lucky with my skill choices, or it was because of the games I've played, but I started on normal, and thought it wasn't that bad.Sure, at first I got killed several times until I started to understand how I should play the game... and after that point, it wasn't that hard anymore.The encounters don't normally scale with your level, but there are a few cases where I've seen them scale, but that might have been because I attacked friendlies for extra XP (whoops!).After some 30 hours of play, I joined a multiplayer session which was set to Hard, and I didn't notice it was on the Hard difficulty level.My point: If you like tactical games, you'll learn how to play the game. You can still go too far, too soon and be in a very tough situation... which you can still win by outsmarting your opponents...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Overall I have been very pleased with this game.  I played the original BG and NW series, Icewind Dale my favorite.  This game brings a lot of those rpg and turned-based 4-person squad elements with a fresh take on the open world / roaming environment that feels similar to playing the Ultima series for me. I'm not very far at the time of this post, maybe 15+ hours, and I've enjoyed every moment of it.The graphics are easy on the eye at ultra settings on a modest machine.  It defaulted to those on a AMD FX 6300 / Radeon 6800. UI is pretty standard as the come.  The only thing is the, rather important, button on the right which is how you teleport.  Wish that one was more evident... sadly responsible for 30 mins of my play time.The way you can split you party is very cool imo.  At one point one of my two main characters was about to die in combat on the next round (surrounded).  If both of your two main characters die you lose and load. (lots of f5/f8)  I fled with my other main character and one side character back to town and was able to regroup in real time while my other main character stayed in combat awiting their return.  I ran the other two back into the fight and was able to prevent his death.  While some may see this as a cheap way out or breaking game mechanics there is also the possibility that those returning character run into another mob and I would have two seperate battles to wage, or manage to merge them back into one.  Your characters have conversations with the party that you control. Doesn't really have a place in the SP mode (although it does change stats in some cases) and you can turn it off in the options but in MP mode it comes into play as if you don't agree with the person your playing with you can argue and try to intimiate/charm/reason with them.  And finally a draw will bring rock-paper-scissors to decide it all.  Another new element that I am indifferent on but for the record have yet to play multi.Crafting is a nice addition.  You learn your recipes by book reading and from there it's a drag-and-drop process mostly.  However keeping all the ingredients can get messy in the inventory.      Soudtrack is quite enjoyable and the audio is well done.  VOs are ok, but honestly very few make it immersive.  The main story is not bad so far but I've been bouncing all over the place with side quests and have much more to do. It's one of those "what's over there?" games that makes you hate the next day at work from lack of sleep.  I would give it a 9 or 10.  I bought it at $40, I'd do it again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												I am giving this game a thumbs up with a few caveats.  It is almost the gold standard for RPG of this kind.  It is well worth the money, I got 87 hours out of it and I didn't even complete everything.  It is a lot of fun and is a dynamic world.  For example in most games where you see backdrops of crates you can't interact with, in this game you can.  You can move them or set them on fire.  A door locked and can't find the key?  Bash or burn it down if you like.Anyway,  I would strongly reccomend that you wait at least 3 months after this game is released to buy it for the following reasons.  By this time I sure hope there are good walk-though guides available.The quests in this game are very old-school.  They do not give you a lot of hints and there in no guidance in the least.  Some of them may require that you find hidden switches and hit them in the right order.  You will not know how many hidden switches there are.  You might find three of them and try all combos and nothing happens.  Well you need to find the 4th switch and try again... maybe find the 5th one?One quest requires you to find a hidden object, this is a main quest so you have to do it.  This object is "somewhere" in a large forest.  You need a perception of like 12 to "see" it.  Stats are very precious and you generally are not going to be able to pump perception as other stats are FAR more important.   The only way I solved it was by finding a screen shot of the locaiton, then moving my character there, putting on all +perception gear I could find, and THEN drank a super preception potion and FINALLY I could "see" this huge mound of dirt that had the item I needed.It is stuff like this that pisses me off and really takes away from this game.  I would really like to know if people find stuff like this naturally without guides.  Other than stuff like that, this is a great game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												I didn't hear of this game until shortly before its release, but when I saw it in the Steam Sale and watched some gameplay videos of it I was instantly interested in it. An old-school RPG with turn-based combat, a well thought-through spell system (poison + fire = explosion, water/blood + electricity = stun, hitting puddles with fireballs makes them steam clouds, steam clouds + electricity = stun clouds and much, much more) and a huge, very detailed world with many secrets to discover make this game the best game I have played this year so far. I've heard people criticize the lack of a 100% voice-over, but Fallout 2 didn't have complete voice-overs and is considered one of the best RPGs up to this day.The negative points I have are these:- more or less bland companions. You don't get to know a lot about them, and both are only relevant for one or two quests overall, but depending on how you chose your main character's classes they complement your party very well. If you want to play "alone" (ie. only with your 2 main characters, there is an extra perk for that as well)- the story could have had better pacing. For the first half of the game the story makes total sense, you are investigating an outbreak of undeads and some other things on the side, and then suddenly everything gets overthrown and for a while you are left wondering what is going on. Luckily this gets cleared up shortly after, but it was still a little confusing in the beginning- the fights in the beginning of the game start out extremely challenging, but lose the intensity later-on as more of your characters can learn healing spells and have high resistances gainst the spell schools etc.. - also, money inflation is a problem. In the beginning you never have enough money, but after ~15h played I had so much money I traded items with vendors for free just to get them out of my inventoryHowever, these negative points are far outweighed by the positive aspects of this game, and it has been a long time since I put 65h+ into game in such a short time (the last game was Skyrim, and only due to mods that I spent so much time with it).If you like RPGs and you are not put off by turn-based combat or lack of complete voice-over then this is a must buy!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												It's been a long time since I've played an old school RPG of this quality. I highly recommend it to RPG fans! Here is my breakdown:THINGS THIS GAME DOES RIGHTCustomization - Instead of setting the length and thickness of your character's nose, you get options that matter, like choosing skills, talents, and stats which add up to make your own custom class. Of course, you can pick from a default list and build it however you want if you prefer. This is customization done right.Difficulty - This game will kill you. It's not Dark Souls hard, but it's hard enough to give you a sense of satisfcation when overcomingits challenges.Non-linearity - Aspects of this game are non-linear. Ultimately it does have a linear narrative, but you can almost completely freely explore the world. You're limited mostly by your level, which is the main barrier limiting progression.Grinding - Most RPGs allow you (or force you) to gain excessive amounts of experience to out-level the game's content. That is the fundamental principle of the JRPG. This game only gives you enough experience to survive the next challenge which ensures that the difficulty of the game is more fine tuned and harder to trivialize.Puzzles - Not everything is explicitly a puzzle. Sometimes advancing the story is a puzzle in itself (like the old adventure games). Sometimes a combat has puzzle elements. Sometimes it's just a room full of traps. Either way, there's almost always a problem to figure out.THINGS YOU MAY OR MAY NOT LIKESpeed of Play - This is a slow methodical game best spent enjoyed at a leisurely pace. The turn based combat, sprawling maps, and slower paced movement speed means that it'll take hours to progress through what some may consider a small amount of content. For the perceptive and the patient, though, that content has a lot to offer.Tone - It's a fairly straight forward fantasy setting. It's fun, whimsical, and self aware at times. It doesn't get overly dark nor overly comical. It's not too geneteric or creative. It serves primarily as a backdrop for the gameplay.Co-op Dialogue - You can do rock-paper-scissors to overcome disagreements. What you choose impacts your stats in small ways. Min-maxers beware. Everyone else; have fun.Random Loot - This has pros and cons. On the one hand, each playthrough is different. On the otherhand, a lot of loot sucks. It's debatable whether or not random loot works in a game with a limited pool of enemies.Nietzsche - He can join your party. It's pretty neat if you're in to that sort of thing. The devs didn't actually name him Nietzsche, but you'll figure it out if you went through that phase in your teen years.THINGS YOU PROBABLY WONT LIKEOops - It can be easy to make it hard or impossible to progress in the game by killing an NPC, letting them get killed, or just♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥them off enough. Same goes for accidently clicking on an object or walking into a room that causes the entire town to aggro on you. Save often.Bugs - There's still quite a number of bugs, but they are very quickly being addressed. Still, be warned. Save often.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Short and sweet:I did not play the other Divinity titles, and I'm not one to play Dungeons and Dragons in real life, though I can understand the appeal. That being said Divinity: Original Sin (DOS) is hands down the best RPG I've played in recent years from a gameplay perspective. I'd recommend this game to anybody who enjoys the RPG genre, as it will not let you down. I've taken my first taste of a Divinity title and now all I want is more; with more multiplayer components and systems that support 4-player (or even 6-8 players) out of the box.The turn-based gameplay is absolutely perfect; the classes (that you can completely customize yourself) are diverse and fun to play, leaving a lot of replay value in the game although the campaign itself is massive enough alone. Graphically the game looks great and after a quick graphic-streaming fix in the game files it ran seamlessly at 144FPS 2560x1440 resolution.I'd heavily recommend a decent 4-player mod or 4-player edit as with 4 people the game is even more fun; though by itself it would still offer people a good experience. Even with the massive content rich evnironment myself and all those I know who love this game are left craving more; different campaigns from the communities and DLC from the developers bringing us new campaigns!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												9.5 out of 10. Fantastic Game. As an avid Divinity Fan since Divine Divinity, I was excited when I first found out that Larian was going to release another Divinity Game. I played all the Divinity Games from Divine Divinity to Dragon Commander. It is very deserving to be Game of the Year.  I enjoyed this game as much as I enjoyed Skyrim when it came out. Pros: Excellent Turn-Base Combat: Ability to use your enviroment against your enemy is very unheard of in most RPG and how each monster has a specific weakness to a specific type of damage whether it be magical or phyiscally. It's a blast to expierment on what does more damages to what specific group of monsters. And a battle could be in your enemies favor one time and next it's in your favor. Same applies to them. Longvity of a game: So many quests to do, I don't even think I completed all the quests in my 140 hours of playing this game. Excellent StoryHumorous: Especially when you meet Bellegar. Character Interaction, to actually be able to interact with every character and barter with each one actually made me feel like I was really in the world, but I expected nothing less as all the Divinity series aside from Dragon Commanderr had that. No Class Roles: You may have to pick a class to start out with but you don't need to follow the layout. I started out as a Wizard but decided to turn into a Battlemage. Replayablity: Replaying a different class after finishing the game adds so much more replay value. Co-Op: It's so fun to play with a friend, I played with my ex when we were still together and we had a blast playing. Exploration: So much to explore and I highly recommend you explore each and every place of this game you can find secrets, new quests and even legendary items. Music: One Word: Masterpiece Kirill Pokrovsky who is the composer of all the Divinity Music is a master at his art. The music is so blended perfectly with the game and it's atmosphere that it really adds a whole new layer of depth to the game. I could listen to this soundtrack so much and never get tired of it. Cons:The only con I can think of is I wish crafting was more in depth, and more recipes. Crafting seemed pretty non-existing to me while I played and I only used it to craft magic lock. Better armormaking and weaponsmithing would be nice. Still a fantastic game and has overtaken Divine Divinity and Dragon Knight as my favorite Divinity games.  Buy it and play it especially with a friend, the cooperation part really makes this game so much fun. Side Note: Those who complain about the difficulty of this game, sure it is difficult to begin with but it's really easy to get stronger and beat even the most diffiicult battles. With so many quests to do especially without leaving the main city you can easily get to the level you need to be to fight the mobs you see. I know it was hard for me but after some questing and gearing up, I was able to compete against the mobs and if that's not your cup of tea you can always turn the difficulty down. And make sure you grab two more companions in Cyseal before adventuring out, unless you're doing lone wolf build.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I backed the project through Kickstarter and I can say I am more than pleased.After a few hours of intense NON-combat questing in the town I solved a few quests in surprising ways, had disagreements with "myself" that lead to new friends or foes, skipped questlines by pickpocketing the right people, crafted my first gear and ventured out of town for my first big fights. There is enough content in the first town and surroundings to pass as a proper game these days and that is only scratching the surface. The implementation of co-op, the way that fights can play in turn-based mode while other party members venture the world in real time add another layer of depth and fun to the game. Together with  the classless system I am already contemplating which skill/ability combination I will try for my next playthrough !Highly recommended, a true RPG offering freedom, experimentation and challenge without holding your hand while never being obtuse or confusing.Highly recommended !

Posted: July 27, 2014
SummaryA good game with some flaws and great cooperative play.GameplayGame features a simple yet powerful(tho still limited) and funny crafting system and you could completely ignore if you don't like crafting. Crafted items are comparable to found and sold by vendors ones.Combat is... well, almost perfect. AI is sometimes bugged, but devs constantly improve it. Main issue is lava - you could kill anything not invulnerable with it.Questing is fun, well written and diverse, however it seems last chapter was rushed till release as it contains a way less quests than 1&2 ones on bigger territory. Main story is bug-free, but some quests are uncompliteable at 2 & 3 chapters.Non-mage characters will probably face lack of different skills, while mages enjoy diverse and rich amount of spells, both harmful and helpful.ReplayabilityIn my opinion game features zero-to-none replayability cause there's no major game-changing choices you could make. Game is filled with plenty of minor ones but those only affect your end-game stats via so-called "traits" like compassionate or blunt.Co-opThe game is desinged for two players. Both of you could do everything, no limits, later on you'll be able to take control of additional henchmen. You could savely afk while your partner takes control of your character. Game poses options for you to play a rock-scissor-paper game when you can't agree on certain answer in dialogue.Last-battle You can't take evil side by killing Astarte. And tis battle is extremely easy even on hard, cause dragon is not immune to disables. Boring.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Short and sweet:I did not play the other Divinity titles, and I'm not one to play Dungeons and Dragons in real life, though I can understand the appeal. That being said Divinity: Original Sin (DOS) is hands down the best RPG I've played in recent years from a gameplay perspective. I'd recommend this game to anybody who enjoys the RPG genre, as it will not let you down. I've taken my first taste of a Divinity title and now all I want is more; with more multiplayer components and systems that support 4-player (or even 6-8 players) out of the box.The turn-based gameplay is absolutely perfect; the classes (that you can completely customize yourself) are diverse and fun to play, leaving a lot of replay value in the game although the campaign itself is massive enough alone. Graphically the game looks great and after a quick graphic-streaming fix in the game files it ran seamlessly at 144FPS 2560x1440 resolution.I'd heavily recommend a decent 4-player mod or 4-player edit as with 4 people the game is even more fun; though by itself it would still offer people a good experience. Even with the massive content rich evnironment myself and all those I know who love this game are left craving more; different campaigns from the communities and DLC from the developers bringing us new campaigns!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												There are a lot of reviews, and perhaps one more isn't needed. But hopefully this will be a good one for those of you on the fence, since this game is not usually on sale. In summary, yes, this game is worth $39.99. No question! First, the positives. For a game funded through Kickstarter and seemingly made under financial duress, the polish is that of a larger publisher's work. There are some aspects of it that do scream "needed more budget," but overall, this is a fine piece of work. The gameplay itself is also fun, yet simple. Combat relies a lot on terrain, use of elements, distance, position... for such a seemingly simple setup, the combat can get really creative. You can sneak around and plant oil barrels in preparation for a fight with an invisible character, and then set off a giant explosion with fire. Of course, then fiery oil is everywhere and no one can see anything, and if you use a lot of barrels, you might get caught in the spreading flames. Combat in Divinity is often like this, with crazy sequences.The story is also not just a placeholder. It's funny, self-aware, sometimes terrifying. The game doesn't take itself too seriously but it can get very dark. The campy, dark humor is very refreshing, and conversations with NCPs more entertaining than it should be. The character creation is very flexible, and at a later point in the game you can even reset your character (!), at the cost of re-quiring all your skillbooks. I haven't got to play CO-OP, but I imagine the reset was for this kind of gameplay.There are some negatives, not insignificant. The graphics can be extremely frustrating to target in combat, as the area to click on for enemies actually moves around with the opponent's outline. The UI, especially how items and the stash works, is absolutely cluttered and terrible. The bags you get don't make it any simpler. The other problem is the game likes to use puzzles, and these puzzles are often absolutely opaque. There's no way to figure them out, or the solution is so narrow and specific, you probably would have never thought of it.The paper-rock-scissors event to solve disputes between characters is utterly irritating, especially in single play. I imagine in COOP it's probably hilarious. But I don't like that it occurs with NPCs, since it's really just a random chance to overcome your opponent.These cons aside, Divinity is a really magical game. It's pretty, it's fun, you can play with a friend (which I will do very soon!) and you won't regret purchasing it, even at full price. Highly recommended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												My second review, yay :D(P.S. Please ignore all of the grammar and spelling mistakes, I wrote this review when I was waay to tired)Anyways, I can defenatly recommend this game. At first I was skeptical, since I'm not one for Top-Down view games. Especially when there is turned based combat. But after the first few hours or so I just started loving this game, and I don't think I'm even a quarter through it.So like I said its a top-down view game, wher you can move your character either by holding the left mouse button and then draging it in the direction that you want to move in, or my simply clicking on anywhere in the area.The combat is turned baste, which at first was a "meh" thing for me since turned baste games are a "meh" kind of thing but after an hour or two it just became something that was there and I accepted it, so its defenatly not a negative aspect for me. I haven't really figured out what decides the order of when each character goes, but so far my characters were all ways the first ones (yay). Similar to other games with turne based combat, you have AP which decides what and how much you can do per turn. So if you need to move in order to dash at the enemy because a big rock is in the way, both of those things will cost AP. If you level as specific skill from your Characters, you will get more starting AP. And if you just simply do nothing and skip a characters turn, or you do something which doesnt require a lot of AP, the left over AP gets added to your next turn.Now at the beginning of the game you can go into a Tutorial Dungeon, where you will already get to learn quit a few of the games mechanics, LIKE LIGHTING TORCHES (I love little things like these). You can move boxes and barrels around to find a hidden key under neath that may unlock a chest or a door. You can use the environment to your advantage in combat. For example there are barrels that have poisen in them, you can move them into position so that when you enter combat all you need to do is shoot them with an arrow (or something equivallent) to make them explode. Now of course you could already explode the barrels even before you enter combat, to already deal damage to your enemies.You also have to look around real carefully for traps or hidden loot.But even outside of the Dungeons and inside the Towns you can do a lot of stuff. For example, you can brake into other people homes and steal their stuff, all though you have to be carefull because if you get cought there will be consequences.You can trade with pretty much anyone, and all most everyone will have something to sell to you, or you can sell anything to them. The trading in this game is pretty good to, you don't necessarily don't need to pay for the Items with Gold. If you have some spare equipment that you don't need, you can use that to pay for the Items. Making your useless crap into...something...more...usefull.....yea.Like someone ells have probably already said, you need to talk to different people in order to get your quests, so no exclamation marker above peoples heads to tell you where a quest is to be found. Which is actually pretty cool and something new. And for me it draws and immerses me more into the game.You are also able to use your abilities (like becoming invisible) in order to accomblish different things.When you create a new game you get to customise two characters, meaning you will have two main characters that you can switch between (and later you can also switch between other party memebers that you pick up). Again at first it was a "meh" thing for me but I have gotten used to it and I actually quit like it now since I can have a Mage and a Rouge. Though you can also teach both characters both things, so the starting class that you pick is just more of a specialisation rather then a locked in character class. When you are talking to a NPC and they give you a choice, you sometimes need to defend your choice from your parters choice by a simple game of rock-paper-scissors. And who ever wins, their choice will be take. So if you say "Kill them all" but your partner says "Spare them all" and you play the game of rock-paper-scissors and you win, that means that you and your partner will kill every person/enemy there. There are also stats that influence of how quickly and easaly you can win these little games.The writing/story of this game, for me, has ben pretty good so far. Though its best if you find that out yourself, or look at a few videos.I can't comment on the Co-Op part of this game yet, since I haven't played this game with a friend up until now, but I'm sure if you enjoy the single player like me then you will definitly love the co-op. Though I would recommend playing it with a friend that is also interested to hear the story, and not just goofing off killing every body (though in a second play through there is nothing standing in your way of doing that of course).So do I recomend this game, hell yes. At first I was skeptical about it, with the top down and turn based thing and all, but after a few hours I can definitly say that this game has become one of my favorit games. And the RPG element in this game is pretty awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is this year's most positive surprise, without doubt. It's very much an old school RPG, with a large world that doesn't scale to your level, and plenty of complex game mechanics and character customization, in the best RPG fashion. The main plot could've been something more interesting, but then again it's constructed in a way to leave lot of room for personal choice of style, trying its best to avoid black and white morals.One of the most interesting aspect of the game is the two main characters, and their possibility to interact and contradict each other. The games uses a rock-paper-scissor social game mechanic to resolve social disputes, which I think earns major extra points: It's a simple mechanic that works really well; much better than a simplistic skill check like in most RPGs.I personally find the game's crafting mechanics a little bit confusing, but I guess they're built in a way to promote experimentation and trial and error, you'll find crafting instructions within ingame books, but otherwise there's no information on it. Barely anything in manual.The best part of the game is the turn-based combat. Really. It fits this genre perfectly. Combat can be very challenging at times, and the game mechanics really take advantage of the turn-based with lots of complexity e.g. regarding the relation of the different magical elements, which affect each other in multitudes of ways creating emergent complexity that leaves a lot of room for creativity. Combat is very much a thinking man's game in Divinity: Original Sin. Large number of combatants can make the fights a bit frustrating at times, but then again, you can save any time, any where, even during combat rounds, so although the fights can be a challenge, you're welcome to save scum your way to victory.Overall, it's an excellent RPG with old school feel (lots of text to read!), pleasant overall graphics and very solid game mechanics. It's definitely worth the monies if you like old school RPGs and don't mind reading through a lot of text (the dialogue can be a bit bloated at times).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												First, to the developers, a heartfelt thank you. Probably my first computer gaming experience was Ultima VII. I never finished it. It was too long, I was too young, and it was too hard to get games to run in the first place back then (memory managers? who remembers that crap?). It has, in the rouchly 25 years of gaming since then, been my white whale. I think about it constantly and long to play it again and finally finish it. Divinity: Original Sin captures so much of what made that game great to me, and so much of what simply doesn't exist in gaming today. It shines creatively, both in a refreshing take on stats/classes/skills/etc, as well as the story. I personally found the graphics to be very good as well. Art is a purely subjective thing to discuss, and I won't say that this game is for everyone. But I will say, if you want a deep role playing experience, turn-based combat, and a pool of nostalgia deep enough to drown in, this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Keep in mind this is a beta, so optimization isn't perfect by any means, but I am having a lot of fun with this game. The level of freedom you get to exercise in building your characters, as well as the ways you can use those skills to solve puzzles, adds a huge level of independence that other games are relucant to allow. The turn based combat is also a nice change from the wave of ARPGs lately that haven't been doing much for me. I have a chunk of hours already invested, and my characters are barely level 4. If you want to enjoy a game with tons of quests, deep and thoughtful character creation, and even a quest creating tool that will be linked to the steam workshop, here is your game.Also, you can talk to chickens and dogs.

												A really fun game which reminds me of the days where i used to play baldur's gate. everything in the world is interactable, even in combat, giving a wider approach to fights strategy wise, for example teleporting an oil barrel amidst a group of enemies then casting a fireball on the oil to trigger an explosion, making the use of the fireball spell much more efficient. When playing multiplayer, you can even argue with your partner as to making decisions, making the multiplayer a hell lot of fun. my only complaint is that the characters in the game lack something that attracts you to them (maybe it's just me, but well..).8/10 would pay & play the DLC.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Keep in mind this is a beta, so optimization isn't perfect by any means, but I am having a lot of fun with this game. The level of freedom you get to exercise in building your characters, as well as the ways you can use those skills to solve puzzles, adds a huge level of independence that other games are relucant to allow. The turn based combat is also a nice change from the wave of ARPGs lately that haven't been doing much for me. I have a chunk of hours already invested, and my characters are barely level 4. If you want to enjoy a game with tons of quests, deep and thoughtful character creation, and even a quest creating tool that will be linked to the steam workshop, here is your game.Also, you can talk to chickens and dogs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												My second review, yay :D(P.S. Please ignore all of the grammar and spelling mistakes, I wrote this review when I was waay to tired)Anyways, I can defenatly recommend this game. At first I was skeptical, since I'm not one for Top-Down view games. Especially when there is turned based combat. But after the first few hours or so I just started loving this game, and I don't think I'm even a quarter through it.So like I said its a top-down view game, wher you can move your character either by holding the left mouse button and then draging it in the direction that you want to move in, or my simply clicking on anywhere in the area.The combat is turned baste, which at first was a "meh" thing for me since turned baste games are a "meh" kind of thing but after an hour or two it just became something that was there and I accepted it, so its defenatly not a negative aspect for me. I haven't really figured out what decides the order of when each character goes, but so far my characters were all ways the first ones (yay). Similar to other games with turne based combat, you have AP which decides what and how much you can do per turn. So if you need to move in order to dash at the enemy because a big rock is in the way, both of those things will cost AP. If you level as specific skill from your Characters, you will get more starting AP. And if you just simply do nothing and skip a characters turn, or you do something which doesnt require a lot of AP, the left over AP gets added to your next turn.Now at the beginning of the game you can go into a Tutorial Dungeon, where you will already get to learn quit a few of the games mechanics, LIKE LIGHTING TORCHES (I love little things like these). You can move boxes and barrels around to find a hidden key under neath that may unlock a chest or a door. You can use the environment to your advantage in combat. For example there are barrels that have poisen in them, you can move them into position so that when you enter combat all you need to do is shoot them with an arrow (or something equivallent) to make them explode. Now of course you could already explode the barrels even before you enter combat, to already deal damage to your enemies.You also have to look around real carefully for traps or hidden loot.But even outside of the Dungeons and inside the Towns you can do a lot of stuff. For example, you can brake into other people homes and steal their stuff, all though you have to be carefull because if you get cought there will be consequences.You can trade with pretty much anyone, and all most everyone will have something to sell to you, or you can sell anything to them. The trading in this game is pretty good to, you don't necessarily don't need to pay for the Items with Gold. If you have some spare equipment that you don't need, you can use that to pay for the Items. Making your useless crap into...something...more...usefull.....yea.Like someone ells have probably already said, you need to talk to different people in order to get your quests, so no exclamation marker above peoples heads to tell you where a quest is to be found. Which is actually pretty cool and something new. And for me it draws and immerses me more into the game.You are also able to use your abilities (like becoming invisible) in order to accomblish different things.When you create a new game you get to customise two characters, meaning you will have two main characters that you can switch between (and later you can also switch between other party memebers that you pick up). Again at first it was a "meh" thing for me but I have gotten used to it and I actually quit like it now since I can have a Mage and a Rouge. Though you can also teach both characters both things, so the starting class that you pick is just more of a specialisation rather then a locked in character class. When you are talking to a NPC and they give you a choice, you sometimes need to defend your choice from your parters choice by a simple game of rock-paper-scissors. And who ever wins, their choice will be take. So if you say "Kill them all" but your partner says "Spare them all" and you play the game of rock-paper-scissors and you win, that means that you and your partner will kill every person/enemy there. There are also stats that influence of how quickly and easaly you can win these little games.The writing/story of this game, for me, has ben pretty good so far. Though its best if you find that out yourself, or look at a few videos.I can't comment on the Co-Op part of this game yet, since I haven't played this game with a friend up until now, but I'm sure if you enjoy the single player like me then you will definitly love the co-op. Though I would recommend playing it with a friend that is also interested to hear the story, and not just goofing off killing every body (though in a second play through there is nothing standing in your way of doing that of course).So do I recomend this game, hell yes. At first I was skeptical about it, with the top down and turn based thing and all, but after a few hours I can definitly say that this game has become one of my favorit games. And the RPG element in this game is pretty awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												The best CRPG in years and will no doubt make the top lists of best CRPGs for years to come. This game is so detailed, rich, and deep that it feels like playing a pen-and-paper RPG at times. There's a learning curve and it's tempting to stall out early because you think you've run out of things to do, but that's because it doesn't hold your hand. I'm the type that often skips through dialogue to get to the combat, but this game's narrative is compelling and worth following. There aren't the ordinary NPC quest givers that tell you where to run and what to do. You have to follow the stories, tease out clues, and figure out on your own how to act next. The environments are highly interactive and can be used in many different ways - both tactically and strategically. The combat system is fun and challenging. Baldur's Gate meets XCOM?
