number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Kickstarter shows us once again that the publisher establishment couldn't find it's own♥♥♥♥♥with both hands and a map.This excellent title is an amazing foray into classic style, Baldur's Gate-esque gameplay, with meaningful character interaction, humor, the ability to talk to animals (and even do quests for a house cat, lol).  This title will be one of those few which always remain installed on my computer, along such excellent works such as Wasteland 1 & 2, Mass Effect, the Fallout series, and TES: IV Oblivion.Graphics are outstanding, and use a sort of fog of war which allows you to see what is going on in your tactical view unimpeded except by range (and even then all terrain is visible) while the actual black fog is cleared on your strategic map and minimap views.  Combat?  Out-Freakin-Standing.  Turn based, action point oriented combat will leave you feeling like you're playing a fresh take on a late 90's RPG like Fallout 2, and magic attacks no longer pull from a mana or MP pool, rather, they act like all other actions simply requiring an investment of action points, no different then a warrior swinging a sword.  This helps with your everpresent necessisty of maintaining a massive inventory of mana potions which you encounter in most games with a caster class.Overall, I've had more fun in only a few hours with this title than I have with nearly anything else that has been released in the last year and a half.9/10, would recommend this to you again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Pros:Beautiful, lively worldReactive elements in combatCreative and robustThe musicBuilder's tool (like NWN)Very few bugsLong campaignA lot to doCraftingPriceMultiplayer is the best in this genreCons:Enemy AI lackingIceA lot of trash/uselss itemsAbundance of money, but nothing to do with itSome puzzlesRequired tediousnessUneven difficulty curveStoryline lacks urgency/attachmentDo you remember the original Neverwinter Nights, Baulder's Gate, or Pool of Radiance: Ruins of Myth Drannor?  If so, this game will score some major points with you.  It is turn based, which at first delayed my purchasing of it.  After a couple of hours in and a few battles under my belt, I realized that it is actually a huge benefit.  I have had more fun with the combat in this game than I have with action games (like NWN).  Combat:The combat is turn based, but that is a good thing.  You can setup the battleground and you have a lot of time to think about how you are going to proceed.  The environment can react to what is done to it.  Mix poison with fire for explosions, cold with water to create freezing, air with water to create electrified surfaces/clouds...  etc.  You can throw things around while in combat.  Want to light up that boss?  Throw that oil or poison barrel next to him and have your mage/archer hit it will something fiery.  Archers getting the best of you from a range?  Create a smoke screen so they cannot see you.  Melee enemies chasing your glass cannons?  Put some ice on the ground or throw the enemy half way across the battle field - make him land on his allies for additional damage to them as well.  Crafting:There are guides online for recipes - and for good reason.  While the books and such you find around the area hint towards recipes, they do not provide all of them - or perhaps I did not find all of the books.  To craft, you just drag an item over another item.  It is much like "Alchemy" (the game) in that sense.  You could spend a while just trying to combine everything until you find all of the recipes or you could just go online and find them there.  Questing:There are a lot of quests in this game.  I did not find any of them to be disappointing in terms of entertainment.  I often found the side quests to be more entertaining than the main storyline.Exploration:There is a lot to do and plenty of subtle secrets to find.  This game rewards (or severely punishes) the curious.  Save often.Main storyline:While it was intriguing to a point, I did not gain a real attachment to it.  There was no cataclysmic climax that the characters (or me as a player) really felt attached to.  While it is a story that wraps around the characters, it doesn't really seem attached to them.  Your role in the game seems more like an extra character than the main character at times.  Don't get me wrong, it was a good storyline, but I would not buy this game for that purpose alone.

Baldurs gate fan? you want this!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												This is fantastic roleplaying game that has a lot of fun exploration, the world is full of details and hidden nooks and crannies and each zone is packed with things to do.The main story is fairly interesting, faily typical high fantasy stuff. The game is packed with lots of quirky sidequests though that often go in unexpected and off the wall directions, be sure to pick the Pet Pal ability as being able to talk to animals is a hoot.  The combat in the game is quite difficult so I reccomend saving often, the quicksave system works well so make good use of it when things go pear shaped. There are a lot of complex interactions in the combat sytem with elements playing a huge part. For example you can shoot a barrel of water then cast lightning bolt on it and create a temporary electrified pool of water that will stun enemies in it (And you too, so be careful). Pools of poison explode so creating them and shooting a flaming arrow to create a damaging fireball is another option. There is a lot of variety there so it pays to pay attention to the enviroment and experiment with the various effects. There is a crafting system thats fairly easy to use but has a lot of complex recipes for making anything from weapons and armor to potions, spellbooks and scrolls. All in all this game has a lot going for it and if you can handle the difficulty I strongly reccomend this for any RPG fan.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Short: similar to Baldurs Gate. This is a nice RPG with no hand holding quest markers, directions, etc.. You have to figure out everything for yourself (besides of the tutorial dungeon cave with basic gameplay explanation) Character builds are open, you get some blue print role models but you can adjust everything as you wish (want a 2-handed combat healer with no INT and STR but a fishing rod and bucket, you are welcome to try).Btw, you create two main characters. At Coop your mate would control the other created main char.Moral or arguing conflicts are resolve with a mini game of rock-paper-sciccors but no lizard and no spock ;-)I really like the gameplay and exploration thing about this game. Round base combat rocks, beside targeting, enemy animation sometime makes you miss clicking them and moving next to them instead of attacking. But you can save game anytime, even during combat. Which you probably do often since combats aren't easy and requires some tactics.D:OS has some downsides:loading times, even from SSDInventory is inconvenient to useCrafting is more inconvenient to use, getting recipes itself is easy but using them. You do not have a list with items to create. You have to drag'n'drop items onto each other without having in game information of combinations that will work..No pause at all, even opening menu wont pause the game - not such a problem besides time tracking or if you want to talk with an moving target..Character portrait does not match (manual chose)Camera shakes are annoying and can't be deactivatedOverall i do not regret backing it at kickstarters. If you liked Realms of Arkania or Baldurs Gate you probalby like this game.

Early Access Review
								Even while just in beta I spent a good 20-30 hours in the starting zone, finding my way around, doing quests and building up my class and that of my companions. The game is fun, smart, and doesn't hold your hand. It can be tough but as you define your class and learn how to play it battles become easier and enemies die faster.The perk system is great and alot like that of the Fallout games, some give you huge bonus with even worse negative effects, but if played properly can really help you.The game is classless mostly, even though you start off as a pre-defined style you will find yourself taking different paths, beginning as a warrior and ending as a battlemage, or a rogue to an archer to a wizard, all things are possible.Leveling is slow but rewarding, I barely hit level 10 before my game was completed, and due to some minor beta issues could not continue.I would highly recommend this, its been a long time (Skyrim) since I put so much time into a game and had so much fun.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
IntroductionDivinity: Original Sin (commonly referred to as D:OS) follows the same style of play as the original Divinity Series, and also to, Divinity Eco Draconis or the Dragon Knight Saga.  D:OS is a role playing game that follows the rules of Dungeons and Dragons probably better than other games of a similar genre - wherein this game features turn based combat.  Explore freely, get attacked, and rather than being completely unprepared for it, you have the time to formulate your strategyThe GoodThere are very many fun aspects of the game, but the biggest "success" is the fact that you're given the freedom to be who you want to be.  If you want to be the most unsympathetic swine in the world - you can.  Want to kill random strangers?  Go right ahead!  Of course, you'll be hunted down for doing so, but at least the game gives you the choice to do it.The term "LOL" will apply many times when playing this game - of course assuming you have a funny bone.  I'm sure my neighbours heard me the first time I used the sneak ability.  The main story line is "serious", but I'd say a great many of the side quests have some kind of funny anecdote here and there.  These occasional lapses into ludicrity make the game really enjoyable to play.  You may even find yourself drawn into the game emotionally, feeling really sorry for the plight of the people that you are helping.The BadHaving played this game from it's release date, I've found that I've fell into a lot of pitfalls of this game, and I've had to play it 3 times through before being able to complete it.  I'm an achievement fanatic, and unless you play this game in a very specific way, you won't get 100% achievements, because some options just wont' be available.  To me, this is not a good thing, because it reduces some of my freedom.Another bad aspect of the game is the lack of quest markers - in fact, quest markers are, to my memory, used only twice within the game.  This is just simply not enough, considering the amount of times I've had to fumble about with the map to try to figure out where I'm supposed to go.I've spent more time Googling in this game than in any game I've ever played - because a lot of the quest objectives, or maps aren't obvious enough.  The dungeon tutorial also doesn't provide enough tutorial for you to really get to know the game well enough - like for example not telling you that you have the ability to heal yourself or any party member by lying on a bed and resting.ConclusionThanks to the concerted efforts of the developers to provide bugfixes so quickly after the game was released, I can happily say now that this game will now bring you a lot of hours of enjoyment, with a few hours of frustration.  The good news is that you don't have to stay frustrated for long - just use Google and then you'll find the clues that were nowhere else to be seen.  This game will annoy you - but as long as you persevere, you wil find that the overall experience will be more rewarding.Prepare yourself for many hours of fun.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Fans of the Divinity franchise don't need a review or analysis to know what this game is about and how this game is played; but for those who are new to this game, you should know:1. This game does not hold hands. You have to investigate, analyze, think, and process the data that are spread around the world. 2. You will be greeted with lots of texts. Rather than pushing away, they pull you into the story. You don't hear much voice work but the words written are enough to draw you into the story....along with many hints and clues. You will need them all.3. Combat is turn based, but assuming you are not playing on easy difficulty, this game will challenge your skill. Strategize and plan. Succeed and rip rewards; fail and face consequences...4. Fantastic visuals. The world is littered with lots of items that you can interact with. Use them for your benefits, or to earn some extra gold, or perhaps, use to solve puzzle that you are not even aware of will appear later.5. Loot, loot, loot! 6. When the creation tool will be out, you know what the mod community will do with it. Anyone who has modded games or used mods in games such as Skyrim would know...the possibilities are endless. A must have.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Author’s note: Whilst a Kickstarter funder myself, I did not touch the game during its development process – therefore I cannot compare any pre- and post-release changes. This is an early, first impressions review. I shall amend this upon further venturing into the game.Divinity: Original Sin is Larian Studio’s latest addition to the Divinity series, going back to its roots as a turn-based RPG set in an open world with unlimited possibilities. You control two customizable characters, who arrive on an Island chasing down sorcerers, fighting off orcs, and investigating the reports of undead activity in the area. Quirky and engaging, Larian’s Kickstarter darling is a welcome addition to anyone’s game library.Original Sin starts you off by letting you customize your two playable characters. You can change their class, appearance, and even their initial stats, if you wish. There are numerous options to choose from, with the classes ranging from fighter to wayfarer, offering varied styles of play, but can probably be grouped into three major roles (coinciding with the three voice pack choices in game): rogue, warrior, and wizard. There are many roles that min-max certain skill sets, while others act as a blend between two major roles. Overall, there is enough variety here to cater to different play styles. Cosmetic customization is also rich, with options to change gender, hair, voice, skin tone, face, and portrait all available.The game features a very neat art style and visual aesthetic. The world of Original Sin is colourful, vivid, and full of life. The trees sway gently, torches burn brightly, and water flows smoothly – the world feels dynamic and active with every little detail added in. The quality of the game’s graphics is astoundingly good, while also being somewhat efficient – it runs on Ultra by default on my GTX 765M, and I’ve had no issues with it dropping below 30, usually floating at the 40s on FRAPS. The art style is akin to a more realistic Torchlight – colours pop out and everything is somehow cartoonish, but it definitely feels like a believably real representation of its world.Combat in Original Sin goes about in a turn-based, action point oriented style. It is reminiscent of other classic RPGs such as Fallout 1 and 2. Certain actions cost a certain amount of AP, movement AP cost is dependent on distance (in meters, unsure if you can change this to the empirical format) and certain units are given priority to move first. Various stats affect what weapons and armor you can equip, how certain skills work for your character, hit chance, dodge chance, and inventory space. So far, the combat flows nicely, and is quite enjoyable. One of the more noticeable breaks from the usual AP system is that any unused AP in a turn is carried over, adding more options for your later turns.A major part of Original Sin is interaction with its various characters, with special focus between the two player characters. Often times, when a decision is to be made, your characters exchange dialog, with each option affecting certain traits of the characters, such as their persuasion, obedience, and altruism.So far, with roughly two hours in, Original Sin is showing plenty of signs of a good game, and I will definitely invest more time in it to further develop my opinion. It seems like the game is made for coop, with two players controlling one character each. I can see that playing out fairly well, with hilarious results in the inter-character dialog! Overall, I would say that if you were already interested in the game, it wouldn’t be such a bad idea to get it, especially if you have a friend playing it as well.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Let me tell you few words about this game. It's amazing what developers did from a Kickstarter campaign. This could be a GOTY, or one of the best RPG so far. It's either you love it, or hate it. I love it. It's an old school game with turn based combat, great graphics, effects and animations, level design and soundtracks which fits perfectly with the setting.  I'm not far in the game, and i can't say about story, but as far as i can say, it's a deep game. You can use environment to kill enemies, you can craft different items from lots of materials, even pizza if you like. The quests can be solved in different ways, you can talk with animals to help you, discover secrets, treasures, and many stuffs. You have the freedom to do what you want and how do you want.  There are plenty of dialogs, similar to Planescape Torment, and you dont have a quest marker, you need to read the journal. You can play alone, or coop, every player gets the chance to answer questions, to agree or disagree completely.     If you want to enter in a beautiful fantasy world with awesome feeling which requires the patience to read any dialog and crafting recipes, then this game is for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I have played the game for +20 hours now. I participated in the Beta and been supporting the game since I heard of it during the Kickstarter campaign.So far Divinity: Original Sin ("DOS") has captured me with all its features and parts; the gameplay, story, world, graphics, difficulty, music, dialogue. It all comes together with good harmony.The game is still quite fresh and there are some minor issues on some areas, but the people at Larian Studios are really showing the effort on fixing all the issues with constant updates and hotfixes.What I like the most in this game is maybe the fact how DOS emphasises the RP element. These days if the game has a character who has and inventory and you can choose his/her name its an RPG. In a way yes, but I think that the definition of RPG has become quite vague, but DOS really gives player the harnesses of his/her characters. You can feel the immersion as you become one with the world and truly make the story feel like your own. The amount of choices and paths player can choose to approach the goals in the game is huge and it doesn't even feel like you have to choose between something, but rather that you do exactly what you want. I hope that other RPG developers will catch on the fact that players of the RPG genre want RP!The other important feature is the Co-op. I haven't yet dived too deep into this feature as I first want to discover thing by myself, but so far what I have seen and heard its good. One more thing for game developers in general, people want Story/Campaign Co-ops for their games!But about the more specific game features:Difficulty:The game is really challenging, even of normal difficulty. I was quite shocked when I had my first real combat, but it was a positive surprise. The game is challenging yes, but you always have a feeling that you can do it, but something just went wrong this time.Gameplay: Gameplay is in general really nice. The turn-based combat works and is really fun. Sometimes in non-combat movement linked characters move a bit stupidly and sometimes seem to arrange themselves wrong in short distance placement. Also I find the party linking system still a bit clunky at times, but I'm confident the developers will keep polishing features like this.World:The world is truly immersive and it feels alive. The Larian humor can be seen in various places and forms, but it fits and it doesn't distract you from the atmosphere at all. Sometimes the city NPCs yelling the same old line comes as a bit of a nuisance, but its a minor thing.Graphics:The graphical look stays loyal to the Divinity saga and is really good in all its simpicity. There are few problems with the way shadows are made for example, but it mostly affects the higher resolution users and I see it also as quite minor issue for now. This also points that the game doesn't have to have top notch graphics with separately animated hair or super realistic 4k textures.Music:The nostalgy of hearing the tracks from Divinity 2, nice! The whole soundtrack is amazing and all the areas have quite nice variability on their sounds, it really fits the world. Only sometimes I have these somewhat intense parts in the music when I'm in the middle of a random dialogue or something and I'm like "Okay.. I guess this dialogue is quite intense." *Stares at the fish vendor* but it doesn't happen that often.Story & Dialogue:I really like the games non-linear story, from the very beginning the game doesn't force you to do anything for the story. You can go wherever you want and do what you want and skip all of the story if you so wish. Although I really recommend that you don't skip it :D but like previously stated you can approach the story from your own perspective. There are quests in the game but they have been cleverly hid as Journal entries that update when you do or discover something related to them. There are no handhelding quest markers or quest logs that tell you exactly what to do. I think this is great! Too many of the modern game underestimate the player and have all this cinematic slow motion "Press X" scenes and markers on the map to show you where stuff is so you can mindlessly roam from point A to point B. Of course those can of helpers are better with games that only offer one way of completing things in the game.Dialogue is great, it fits the world, its fun with the little jokes every there and now and its believable. There could be more lines for the nameless NPCs because you can ask them quite a lot of stuff, so far they seem to have something like 3 lines per question, but once again quite minor stuff.So as a conclusion; Divinity: Original Sin is a great piece of art to all people who love the RPG genre and great place to start for those who have not yet really dived into it. The game shows promise for the future of modern games and acts as an example for other developers that if you truly believe in it and want to make something great, you can. I'm eagerly following how the game develops even after the release and what's yet coming. I believe this game will be one to speak about in the future.That's all for now, I will update this review if necessary and hoped you find it useful! :)

content:

Early Access Review
								Me and me mate have been twiddling our thumbs since we finished NWN2 and BG2 before that, wasting our money on wanna be rpgs, but behold whats this Divinity Original Sin?, could this be the game we have been waiting for? 30 hours or so into it and several toon experimentations, RELEASE IT NOW!! darn you, we want to play the full version :).Graphics are nice, AI is very good on mobs but the bosses could use a tweek i think, loving the fast leveling i think that is bang on and the personality bonuses you get from interacting with npc's is a great touch. The game doesent hold your hand with silly quest markers which i also think is great, you can just roam around bumping into monsters and eventually you will find the quest update. Also you can pick a rdy made character class and edit it to your play style which is another lovely touch.This game could be the next BG2 or NWN, will have to wait till full realease to experience all game content but so far im hooked. Only negative i would say is only up to 2 players for co-op.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												In short, this game is easily worth $40.Haven't played much of the game yet (just got to lvl 3), but what I have seen so far has been truly impressive.  Combat is a mix between Baldur's Gate II and Temple of Elemental Evil, which is a great thing, especially if you are a fan of those games as I am.  Spell system works a little differently than D&D, however; spells have cooldowns & require action pts to use, no memorizing & resting are required.  Voice acting, Sound-FX, music & graphics are nicely done.  Dialogue is well-written with plenty of wit and the storyline is shaping up nicely.  Haven't messed with the Divinity Engine Toolkit yet, but from what I've seen, if the community gets behind it, expect Skyrim-calibre moddability.  Multiplayer can be fun, but the game is a little slow-paced for two players (lot of reading in between combat) so maybe skip the co-op for your second play thru and try out a different class with your friends.Game crashed on me once so far, but the auto & quicksaves help there.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Short: similar to Baldurs Gate. This is a nice RPG with no hand holding quest markers, directions, etc.. You have to figure out everything for yourself (besides of the tutorial dungeon cave with basic gameplay explanation) Character builds are open, you get some blue print role models but you can adjust everything as you wish (want a 2-handed combat healer with no INT and STR but a fishing rod and bucket, you are welcome to try).Btw, you create two main characters. At Coop your mate would control the other created main char.Moral or arguing conflicts are resolve with a mini game of rock-paper-sciccors but no lizard and no spock ;-)I really like the gameplay and exploration thing about this game. Round base combat rocks, beside targeting, enemy animation sometime makes you miss clicking them and moving next to them instead of attacking. But you can save game anytime, even during combat. Which you probably do often since combats aren't easy and requires some tactics.D:OS has some downsides:loading times, even from SSDInventory is inconvenient to useCrafting is more inconvenient to use, getting recipes itself is easy but using them. You do not have a list with items to create. You have to drag'n'drop items onto each other without having in game information of combinations that will work..No pause at all, even opening menu wont pause the game - not such a problem besides time tracking or if you want to talk with an moving target..Character portrait does not match (manual chose)Camera shakes are annoying and can't be deactivatedOverall i do not regret backing it at kickstarters. If you liked Realms of Arkania or Baldurs Gate you probalby like this game.

So that leaves us with about 4-5 hours to watch Anime/Movies/Play games every night, except weekends. <3We don't play this all the time, since there are tons of games and shows we have to choose from. :Q AS kjasfjfANYWAY! Enough personal story time. It's free roam when you're out of combat, and speed turn-based while in combat! highest initiation/speed goes first, of course. I play a healer (derp), and my husband plays a mage. He makes me control our companion, so I made her into a beefy two-hander.I also use gear with telekenisis (+2-3 points into the skill), so I can steal EVERYTHING! I love stealing in games when it's available! So I'm a healer with pickpocketing and telekenisis, haha. My husband laughed at me a few times when he's talking to an NPC for a quest, then I tell him to keep them distracted as I pickpocket them.Oh gawd. So.. I don't know what else to say about this game! BESIDES I CAN TALK TO ANIMALS! They also sell you their fur, teeth, etc. Kind of weird, but I'm a pack rat and collect crafting material. Okay this review isn't much of a review, is it? I'll stop now!This game is super fun and addicting to play with another person!! I haven't played it by myself, so I don't know about that! Aaaaaaaaaaa

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Let me tell you few words about this game. It's amazing what developers did from a Kickstarter campaign. This could be a GOTY, or one of the best RPG so far. It's either you love it, or hate it. I love it. It's an old school game with turn based combat, great graphics, effects and animations, level design and soundtracks which fits perfectly with the setting.  I'm not far in the game, and i can't say about story, but as far as i can say, it's a deep game. You can use environment to kill enemies, you can craft different items from lots of materials, even pizza if you like. The quests can be solved in different ways, you can talk with animals to help you, discover secrets, treasures, and many stuffs. You have the freedom to do what you want and how do you want.  There are plenty of dialogs, similar to Planescape Torment, and you dont have a quest marker, you need to read the journal. You can play alone, or coop, every player gets the chance to answer questions, to agree or disagree completely.     If you want to enter in a beautiful fantasy world with awesome feeling which requires the patience to read any dialog and crafting recipes, then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I have played the game for +20 hours now. I participated in the Beta and been supporting the game since I heard of it during the Kickstarter campaign.So far Divinity: Original Sin ("DOS") has captured me with all its features and parts; the gameplay, story, world, graphics, difficulty, music, dialogue. It all comes together with good harmony.The game is still quite fresh and there are some minor issues on some areas, but the people at Larian Studios are really showing the effort on fixing all the issues with constant updates and hotfixes.What I like the most in this game is maybe the fact how DOS emphasises the RP element. These days if the game has a character who has and inventory and you can choose his/her name its an RPG. In a way yes, but I think that the definition of RPG has become quite vague, but DOS really gives player the harnesses of his/her characters. You can feel the immersion as you become one with the world and truly make the story feel like your own. The amount of choices and paths player can choose to approach the goals in the game is huge and it doesn't even feel like you have to choose between something, but rather that you do exactly what you want. I hope that other RPG developers will catch on the fact that players of the RPG genre want RP!The other important feature is the Co-op. I haven't yet dived too deep into this feature as I first want to discover thing by myself, but so far what I have seen and heard its good. One more thing for game developers in general, people want Story/Campaign Co-ops for their games!But about the more specific game features:Difficulty:The game is really challenging, even of normal difficulty. I was quite shocked when I had my first real combat, but it was a positive surprise. The game is challenging yes, but you always have a feeling that you can do it, but something just went wrong this time.Gameplay: Gameplay is in general really nice. The turn-based combat works and is really fun. Sometimes in non-combat movement linked characters move a bit stupidly and sometimes seem to arrange themselves wrong in short distance placement. Also I find the party linking system still a bit clunky at times, but I'm confident the developers will keep polishing features like this.World:The world is truly immersive and it feels alive. The Larian humor can be seen in various places and forms, but it fits and it doesn't distract you from the atmosphere at all. Sometimes the city NPCs yelling the same old line comes as a bit of a nuisance, but its a minor thing.Graphics:The graphical look stays loyal to the Divinity saga and is really good in all its simpicity. There are few problems with the way shadows are made for example, but it mostly affects the higher resolution users and I see it also as quite minor issue for now. This also points that the game doesn't have to have top notch graphics with separately animated hair or super realistic 4k textures.Music:The nostalgy of hearing the tracks from Divinity 2, nice! The whole soundtrack is amazing and all the areas have quite nice variability on their sounds, it really fits the world. Only sometimes I have these somewhat intense parts in the music when I'm in the middle of a random dialogue or something and I'm like "Okay.. I guess this dialogue is quite intense." *Stares at the fish vendor* but it doesn't happen that often.Story & Dialogue:I really like the games non-linear story, from the very beginning the game doesn't force you to do anything for the story. You can go wherever you want and do what you want and skip all of the story if you so wish. Although I really recommend that you don't skip it :D but like previously stated you can approach the story from your own perspective. There are quests in the game but they have been cleverly hid as Journal entries that update when you do or discover something related to them. There are no handhelding quest markers or quest logs that tell you exactly what to do. I think this is great! Too many of the modern game underestimate the player and have all this cinematic slow motion "Press X" scenes and markers on the map to show you where stuff is so you can mindlessly roam from point A to point B. Of course those can of helpers are better with games that only offer one way of completing things in the game.Dialogue is great, it fits the world, its fun with the little jokes every there and now and its believable. There could be more lines for the nameless NPCs because you can ask them quite a lot of stuff, so far they seem to have something like 3 lines per question, but once again quite minor stuff.So as a conclusion; Divinity: Original Sin is a great piece of art to all people who love the RPG genre and great place to start for those who have not yet really dived into it. The game shows promise for the future of modern games and acts as an example for other developers that if you truly believe in it and want to make something great, you can. I'm eagerly following how the game develops even after the release and what's yet coming. I believe this game will be one to speak about in the future.That's all for now, I will update this review if necessary and hoped you find it useful! :)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												10/10The Good: Fantastic CRPG game, reminiscent of bygone days. If you liked the classic Ultima or Fallout series you will love this game. You have utmost freedom in creating your characters and classes. The combat is turned based, ala Xcom. What makes the combat great is the interaction of elements. Make it rain, and opponents get wet. If you now hit them with a ice spell they get frozen. This opens up countless of possible combinations. The story is a bit fantasy cliche, but the world is lovingly crafted, quirky and very immersive. The best part is that it has coop, which is a blast. Your coop partner can literally disagree with you in-game when you speak to NPCs, and change the outcome of a quest.The Bad: The game does not hold your hands, aside from a small tutorial dungeon in the beginning. There are no quest markers, and little to no explanation about its stats system. Little dialog is spoken, so lots of dialog reading is required to know how to finish quests. If you are the impatient type and are looking for an action-rpg, look elsewhere.Verdict: Game of the year for me so far. This illustrates nicely what kind of games are possible when developers don't have ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ publishers breathing down their necks about dumbing down or streamlining their games.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This game feels like exactly the sort of slow-burning RPG I've been missing the last few years over. Plenty of stats and classes and items to tinker around with, lots of flexibility and customization, and a really interesting world to play in. I haven't spent this much time just learning about the world (and consequently, how to mess it up) since the days I used to waste exploring Baldur's Gate. Really fun dynamic with the two-player main character feature, and the ability to run it online, co-op or jumping in and out of other people's games makes for a really cool, constantly changing experience.Play this game. Do it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												So, now that I beat the game, time to review !TL;DR: + turn based tactical combat+ elemental synergy+ eye candy+ you actually have to think a bit and use common sense. No more blindly following the big arrow on the screen, you'll have to look for clues and read books+ 80-100h to beat+ number of skills+ secondary quests- difficulty drop at mid-game. Once you understand buff/debuff and have a basic sense of tactic, It gets easy. - the inventory - lack of companionsSo, I recommend this game. I backed it on kickstarter, and I do not regret it. The game, in its mechanics, is challenging, and far from the current videogame standards. You will have to consults your quests journal, use common sense to resolve puzzles (they are not that difficult really, except when you have to look for a *******ing button hidden in shadows or behinda leaf) , look for clues, read every piece of paper or book you find. No quest markers, If you don't know what to expect, you can feel a bit lost there. Combats are great. Really. a bit hard at the beginning. You really have to pay attention to things like initiative, speed, perception, how 2 spells will work together ... It is really a pleasure to begin some chain reaction when combining different elements. Unfortunately, once you understand how it works, how you can buff/debuff, use initiative order and combine elements, you are pretty unstoppable. There is a huge drop in difficulty at mid game. Even the end boss was more "long to kill" than "hard to kill" . It can make the game a bit borng, because the main storyline, is not really that interesting (I did not say it sucks , but it's average) Concerning the 2 main characters: I liked the rock/paper/scissors system used here, and how you can make your characters disagree on anything :d A word on crafting: depending on your mele/casting orientation it can be useful. There are a lot of recipe that can help at the beginning of the game, but mostly, at some point, you only use it to craft mage skillbooks and add resistance to your equipments. The mechanic is interesting and relies on logic (combining item to create stuff, like "I use my dagger to sharpen this branch, I get a stake) but it comes with a price: the inventory is not really practical, as everything can be an ingredient for crafting (but you get used to it) NB: I did not test co-op

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Modern looking CRPG with roots in the old school. Divinity Original Sin is a solid built RPG with plenty of things to do and see. I started the game as a Cleric and a Knight (vanilla pre made classes the game it self provided for me to choose), then spent the next 10 hours enjoying my self until i came to a place where i kept running my head into a wall.I tried to circumvent this by seeing if there where more quests that i could do, to make my character level grow a bit. But turns out there was nothing left for me to do at this point. So after 3 hours in the same fight i called it quits, and started over. This time i took what i knew from the 10 hours of gameplay and made more focused character by avoiding the vanilla templates that where provided for me to use.I made a custom Ranger and a custom Fighter. The Ranger is a flimsy character, but with a bow i could negate that a bit by staying back. So i focued here points in Dex. For here skills i went with 1 point in Scoundrel only for 2 abilities that i would use all the way to the end of the game. Invisibility and a skill that let me earn more action points for the next rounds. I also put a single point in Geomancer so that i could get the ability to summon a spider, which was also a skill that i used in 95% of all my combat scenarios. After those i never upgraded Scoundrel or Geomancer again and stuck with the Expert Marksman still to give me more abilities in the usage of Bows.The fighter was simple, i focused points in Constitution from the start giving me an edge in terms of HP. His ability points went into Shield specialist and Man at Arms. I wanted him to take all the damage, along with the spider summon.So again played for 9 hours saved some time because i remembered most of what i was supposed to do, got to the same spot, lost. Tried again with a different strategy and i was finally over that painful part. Now this was a fight that had a party of 4 VS. an enemy party of 7-8. The boss fight right after was easy and i almost lost no health what so ever. And this is one of my biggest issues with the game, sometimes you will encounter some very unbalanced fights that just seem there for the sake of making you miserable. Luckily i didn't find my self in that situation that many times, and if i lost the battle i usually had it the next try or the one after.But any how despite all that i loved the 83 hours i have spent on the game. The settings and graphics are so damn nice to look at, and exploring the world is very fun. The whole murder mystery that the game starts off with is without a doubt the best part of the games story. The story gets very dumb and convoluted after you leave the first major town. But that doesn't stop the gameplay from still being very enjoyable and fun.I recommend this game to any one who likes old school RPG games. But i urge every one to focus their stats into a few key areas, if you spread your points out too much you will gimp your character, and make it frustrating and a bad experience. Do not pick any of the pre made classes, customize them and focus on what you want to be doing with that character. Maybe even look up a guide on how to set up some points.ProsTactical combat really fun and robustElemental combat scenariosPlenty of places to spend skill pointsGraphics and art style are gorgeousGood ambient and combat soundsBig variety in skills and magicConsStupid enemy AIUneven fights that result in hair lossVery limited look to armors and weaponsRepetive NPC dialoguePossible to create broken charactersDistribution of loot quality and unusable gear can be a blessing and a curse. Most often the latterStory loses its appeal after the first major townCompanions are very shallow in terms of character developmentFinal boss fight is infuriating and cheapOver all great game. And one i won't forget.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Excellent RPG. Good turn-based combat allowing for all kinds of tactical possibilities and ways to overcome difficult fights. Plenty of customization in how to build your characters, and there's no real wrong way to do it, just about anything is viable. Most quests have multiple ways to solve them, giving you freedom to play the kind of character you want without having to completely skip or fail any quests. The only downside is that quests are relatively self-contained meaning there isn't much replay value unless you just want to see things resolve slightly differently, but hopefully with the robust editing tools this won't be an issue, as inevitably we'll have full-length new campaign mods eventually. If you like RPGs, especially older Western ones like Baldur's Gate and (obviously) Divine Divinity, give this game a go.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This CRPG is one of the best out there. The game is played in real-time but the battles are turn-based, with great elemental and landscape interactions. The world itself wonderfully drawn--a nice combination between pretty landscapes and cartoonish monsters. The music is awesome and I enjoy the voicing (I talk to the rats more often than necessary because it makes me giggle). The price is well worth the amount of content for the game ($40). (Edited to add--finished the game at ~91 hours. Awesome value for dollar). The story is engrossing and you make many choices along the way that affect your gameplay. In fact, beware; choices are permanent and have consequences. If you choose to shoot an NPC in the face with a fireball in broad daylight...well, I recommend you save often in case you need to roll back after some instant regret. The puzzles in this game can be hard, and the most difficult aspect is likely the fact that you have to pay attention to EVERYTHING--there's a lot of story and the game expects you to listen and learn. If you get confused or lost (which happened to us...erm, often....) you might get a little frustrated. Consider all of your actions, pay attention to story and quests, put care into where you put your skill points, and you'll be fine. My complaints are small: inventory can become unwieldy, and some of the puzzles are hard (or require patience levels that I don't possess). However, the sheer fun of this game more than makes up for the small bugs and there are a lot of surprises waiting inside this gameI give it a 10/10 for co-op.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												This is what games used to be like before they were forced to dumb themselves down for consoles and for people who could not stand having to read something in the game. This is what games used to be like before the control was taken from gamers, before direction markers started solving quests for you. This is what it was like before the games became linear and started holding your hand, telling you every step of the way what you should to and where you're supposed to go, even though there really wasn't any other choice. Larian, thank you for this game. Thank you for having the courage to go against the tide and make something really special. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who has ever wanted to play Baldur's Gate or Planescape Torment, but couldn't get over the dated graphics and interface. Play this game. Buy it. Don't even wait for the sale, buy it at full price to let the game developers know that we appreciate the effort and that there are still people out there who actually want to *play games*, not just participate in an interactive movie that gives you no choice whatsoever.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												One of the best RPGs I have played, this reminds me of a modern day game of Baldur's Gate or Fallout Tatics game.You have your usual real time action until combat starts then its turn based with action points, the combat is where it shines as you have elemental effects that combine and can change the flow of battle.  For example you can make it rain and use lightening to shock your foes or another way is to use a water arrow and shock arrow combo, there are more then just one way of doing things.Another shining point is the multi player aspect of the game where you make choices and decisions and if you can't agree then its a game of rock, paper and scissors.Over all this is a very good game with some amusing death scenes and great music that brings out the atmoshere of the adventure.This is a game worth its price.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												I decided to wait a while to write a review on this game as I needed to at least "beat the game" once (current play time is just over 60 hours).  Divinity: Original Sin is an extremely punishing game to those who think you can brute force down the enemies.  You need to follow the story line and appreciate the game in its entirety to be able to succeed.  While the previous statements may have been negative, the game is 100% worth every penny and I would recommend it to any of my friends.  I have had the most personal fun playing co-op mode with one of my best friends (Escape -> Assign Characters is too hidden!) and it makes the replayability so much more considering you can always try new heroes and/or mercs.With all the positives there are some things that don't make a lot of sense, Crafting and Blacksmithing come to mind.  Have no idea why Crafting is in the game after 60 hours or how to use it.  Blacksmithing is a free repair... which means it's just tedious to use and item durability doesn't serve a purpose then.  The first time you play thru the game make sure you save often and try and balance your team/abilities/read an initial play guide.  If not, you are going to have a very bad time and get to about level 7 or 8 and hit a brick wall that can honestly be impassable.My recommendation is grab a friend, spend some long nights/weekends together and play one of the best action based RPGs I've played in a very long time.  Enjoy your travels together!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I'd like to start by saying, as a person who turns a blind eye to turned based combat games, this game is just spectacular & the implementation of turn based combat along with the rest of it truly makes this game worth playing, and a whole lot of fun. D:OS, is one of today's hand down best RPG games, it has the exploration value and fun, as such games like Skyrim, exploring is truly fun, and as well as that, important for character progression. There's no grinding in this game, XP is rare, which makes looking for monsters that bit more fun! Questing is very in depth, there's no exclamation, the game does not think for you, you do the thinking and choose how each quest is completed, remember EVERY action has a consequence. The elemental collaboration in this game is truly amazing, reminds me of magicka, and how elements are very valuable of how you use them. Finally the party system, you can have up to 4 people in your party, best to allocate each member to a specific role, as you would see in much RPGs, such as a tank, healer, DPS and so forth. Coop is also another high point of this game, you can jump into a friend game, playing their second designed character which I may add INTERACTIONS and actually chosen dialogue is given to both you & your friend for a fun immense RPG experience. This game is so addictive and fun, looking forward to seeing future mods and updates. TL:DR♥♥♥♥♥♥♥buy it, it is amazing 10/10 <3

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This CRPG is one of the best out there. The game is played in real-time but the battles are turn-based, with great elemental and landscape interactions. The world itself wonderfully drawn--a nice combination between pretty landscapes and cartoonish monsters. The music is awesome and I enjoy the voicing (I talk to the rats more often than necessary because it makes me giggle). The price is well worth the amount of content for the game ($40). (Edited to add--finished the game at ~91 hours. Awesome value for dollar). The story is engrossing and you make many choices along the way that affect your gameplay. In fact, beware; choices are permanent and have consequences. If you choose to shoot an NPC in the face with a fireball in broad daylight...well, I recommend you save often in case you need to roll back after some instant regret. The puzzles in this game can be hard, and the most difficult aspect is likely the fact that you have to pay attention to EVERYTHING--there's a lot of story and the game expects you to listen and learn. If you get confused or lost (which happened to us...erm, often....) you might get a little frustrated. Consider all of your actions, pay attention to story and quests, put care into where you put your skill points, and you'll be fine. My complaints are small: inventory can become unwieldy, and some of the puzzles are hard (or require patience levels that I don't possess). However, the sheer fun of this game more than makes up for the small bugs and there are a lot of surprises waiting inside this gameI give it a 10/10 for co-op.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Divinity Original Sin is old-school-style RPG, with a rich atmosphere, lots of character-building, turn-based combat and excellent coop-support where you (or you and a friend) play as the two main-characters, called the "source-hunters".TLDR-version: I definitly recommend this game to all non-casual RPG fans, for it highly depends on much reading and using ones own wits to solve or even find quests.[4/5] Gameplay The gameplay as it is would be perfect. You have interesting combat (more on that later), trading and dialouge options with almost every character in the world, a gripping story and huge freedom in terms of character-building. Battle-mage that vanishes like a rouge during combat? No problem. The typical grumpy, know-it-all wizard with devasting spells? Of course. A weak charismatic healer with almost no combat skills? Here you go.There regullary are dialouges between the two heros, where you can define their attitude towards each other and their nature.So the observing reader may ask: Why only 4 out of 5 stars? Well the gameplay experience is hindered by some bugs from time to time (not that often). There is for example a bug, that lets the attributes and breastplate of your controlled hero disappear (only on your client). The host has to save the game and reload it to fix it. Or there is this bug that prevent you from hitting enemies that are to close to rocks or walls (only had this bug twice in my playtime).With these bugs fixed the gameplay would be perfect.[5/5] Combat The combat is round-based. Normally I prefer real-time combat over turn-based, but Divinity: Original Sin is an exception I guess. The combat is incredibly complex (yet easy, don't get me wrong!), so the turn-based system lets you use the terrain and fight very strategicaly. There are tons of different spells and lots of different weapon styles. You can (with the right talent) backstab enemies for extra damage or create a oil surface and inflame that, teleport an enemy into that burning surface, electrify water sufaces or steam-clouds, the possiblities are endless.[4.5/5] Controls Not much to say about the controlls. One could say good controlls don't come to your attention and that's the case here. The game is mainly controlled with the mouse, though there are shortcuts for the spells in your hotbar, the inventory...The only problem that occured to me is that when you try to get some item out of an poisoned/burning/electrified area and you can't reach it from out of that area, your hero steps into it and (especially in the begining of your journey) dies. So you have to be careful...[3.5/5] AIThe AI in this game controlls your character when you are walking by clicking on the ground instead of holding the left mouse button to guide him or her. It does a decent job at that, avoiding hazardous areas or traps, as long as it is able to (see "controlls").The AI of enemies on the other hand somtimes is quite dumb. For example: It attacked my main character until he had 20hp left. Now it could have killed him with another successful hit. Instead it started attacking my companions and ended up losing that fight.Sometimes I'm quite thankful for quirks like that, for the fights can be really hard from time to time, yet it feels "wrong", if you know what i mean.Often the AI beautifully combines spells and terrain effects, creating challenging fights without feeling unfair. Many times there was that "WTF?!" effect when an enemy shot an poison arrow at my group and in the next turn a mage set it on fire, nearly wiping the party.[5/5] Immersion What can I say about this one, except it is perfect? The dialouges are interesting and you can have them with literally every person on the map (except the mobs of course...). A certain talent allows you to speak with animals, which often have an intersting story to tell, a funny sentence (Imagine a rooster saying: "Soon the cleaver of decapitation will be turned upon you, the revolution is coming!!"), or even tips on how to solve puzzles.[5/5] MapAll of the levels are beautiful designed and contain many details. There are hidden secrets and treasure, quests off the beaten path. Could you ask for more?[4.5/5] GraphicsThe graphics are held in a isometric view and rotatable by some 90°, but you can zoom in really close and look your hero into the eyes (while having a cool blurred background). The game nicely plays with different ambient lighting and weather effects. The spell effects are solid, not always brilliant, but definitly nice. Some of the animations are kind of clunky, yet they do not destroy the atmosphere or immersion.[4/5] AudioThe game has a amazing soundtrack, that beautifully accompanies combat, travel or dialgoues. All the other audio is solid, but sometimes repetitive.Take for example the marketplace of the first city, where you will spend very much time. All of the merchants have a few lines they say, some funny, some serious. But they repeat that few lines over and over again.After hearing "No one has as many friends, as the man with the many cheeses!" for the 40th time you have an urge to slaughter that man, believe me. Only a few of the dialouges are spoken, but considering the vast amount of dialouges I guess it's ok. Yet, everything that is spoken is done very well.[NA/5] DevelopersI had no contact with the developers.Though it has some flaws this game is definitly worth buying. It is highly addictive, especially in coop. Divinity: Original Sin is one of my favourite games of all time.Final Rating 4.5 out of 5 stars - Fix the bugs and some of the minor flaws and this game is perfection.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is a great game with a few issues.  Even with my negative points below I still recommend it for people who like RPG+Turn based battles, if you liked games like Baldur’s Gate series then you will likely enjoy this game.Good:+Great Graphics.+Moody atmosphere for dungeons.+Talk/trade with almost every neutral NPC.+Developers are listening to players and updates/patches are coming out frequently.Not so Good:-Inventory management is clunky.  Yes you can use "Send to Homestead" but I would love to see an option to access it from anywhere as well as quick transfer, say CTRL+left click to transfer to Homestead.  -Enemy visual range is so large that often you’re in battle before you can even see them.  Once in battle you often have to move the map around just to spot the enemy, since they are so spread out.-Quest tracking.  I know this was their intent but the lack of any visual clues and limited suggestions in quest log can make questing painful and slow.  I’ve spend a large amount of my time running between people in town asking the same questions and hoping for a different answer or quest update.  If there were better visual clues (pointer) or more details in quest log on what is expected next I wouldn’t feel some much like I’m wasting time running around.-Movement speed, I know this is subjective but for me I feel like the characters move too slowly even at max speed.-So far with my limited play it seems like the enemy count is too low on the maps, i.e. only one or two groups of enemies per map area.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												D:OS is a gorgeously polished old-school RPG in the traditions of Baldur's Gate and similar top-down isometric games.   Its story is engaging and deep if one takes the time to slow down and read.Pros:Beautiful graphics and amazing soundtrackCrunchy tactical turn-based combat (reminiscent of Fallout/Fallout2 and XCOM meets digital D&D)Rewarding to play without the help of online guides -- provides a real sense of accomplishment & advancementThoughtful storyline with no "morality meter" -- your choices can affect the plot and open or close certain possibilitiesGood mix of RP-investigation, puzzles, exploration and combatVery little hand-holding: no quest trackers on the radar, easy to get in over your head in combat. Fun and brain-teasing!It's multiplayer co-op!  Go find a duo buddy on your friends list.Cons:Cumbersome inventory systemLots of text to read, if you don't like text (why are you playing old-school RPGs if you don't want to read, tho?)Early game can be difficult until one figures out the character build system.  Plan on re-starting once or twice to find a build you like for your Source HuntersSome combats can be very puzzle-like... this may be a + or - depending on your personal preferences. 9/10 would replay and struggle against the oblivion of the Void again.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game is everything I love about video games. It's extremely engaging and a game that is enjoyed best with friends. You will start strategizing, planning out, and manuvering about how to make the best of a situation. You have complete freedom to do whatever it is you want, and your actions actually matter.The writing is as strong as the gameplay. Since the actions you take have real impactful outcomes, you will pay attention to what people are saying, which makes you really focused on the awesome quests there are. This game doesn't dumb anything down. It expects a lot of you. It's challenging, but never impossible. Being able to make the environment a strategic part of a fight feels natural and fun, and you will miss the combat system once you play other RPGs. You will want more, you will want to know what happens to the NPCs, you will want to defeat that boss, you will want to play this game all the time. Enjoy it while it's fresh. Take your time. Personally, it's my GoTY. There's no shame in recreating your characther after a while. I've restarted countless times, and I experience the game differently each time. It's the best game I've played. I wouldn't think twice about reccommending it to anyone who loves strategy and classic-style RPGs. Or anyone.

												I've donated to a good number of crowdfunded/early access titles over the past year and Divinity: Original Sin is the first one of them that has officially launched and I just gotta say that they have set the bar extremely high (Hot Damn have they evah!) as far as this development trend goes. Their alpha was impressively polished a few months ago and it just got better as the days went on. Larian was so on point, it was sick (in the good way! :P). Now playing the official release is just pure joy.  I'm right back where I was in the 90s playing so many of the amazing cRPG titles that were so much fun and D:OS has brought that all back and then some.  Crowdfunding/EA has allowed Larian to make the game they always wanted to make with total creative freedom and it shows, ohmgosh does it show.Sure there have been some hiccups since launch with issues but there has also been a steady stream of updates as Larian listens to all the feedback and fixes the issues as they pop up.The modding toolkit is ready as well and just waiting for Valve to flip the switch so there is a whole lot more of the goodness to be had from talented modders out there. I am so stoked!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												9/10Pros:-Challenging tactical turn based combat-Impressive bullpen of skills and spells-Not a "baby mode" rpg.  Prepare to have to explore for quests and tinker for crafting.-Freedom to build the party to cater to your specific playstyle-Solid visuals that add to the atmosphereCons:-Overly ambitious story loses its charm by the finale-Ambiguous crafting system is sometimes too...ambiguous-A few annoying glitchesSynopsis:D:OS is the best game of its kind (party based rpg) to be released since neverwinter nights 2 but is not without flaws.  The narrative suffers from being overly ambitious.  The very world is at stake and it seems that the story writers struggle with how to weave the player characters naturally into the puzzle.  The result is an awkward dance where the game attempts to convince us these source hunters were of course much more than just that.  We don't need to be saving the world for the story to matter.  Having said that, the game has plenty of obvious strengths.  First of all, it is gorgeous.  Dungeons and locales spring to life with the appropriate ambiance and give you a real sense of being in a fantasy world. Next of course is the core gameplay.  I found the turn based combat system is extremely entertaining with diverse groups of enemies bringing equally interesting challenges.  In addition, the questing system forces you to use your head and eyes to advance.  No brainless killing and gathering to be found here.  Overall, a polished RPG experience with a robust amount of content

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												What Bioware couldn't achieve with Dragon Age series Original Sin has brought to us after so many years of waiting. Yes, they did it - CRPG in modern graphics and with sophisticated, yet easy to understand, game mechanics. Fallout (1&2)-esque combat system, Baldur's Gate exploration and story-telling mechanics and Divinity world that will make you come back again and again. Story is not as epic as you'd like but its execution brings satisfaction and fun. Battles are challenging and you'll have to implement a lot of tactics and preparation (nothing new for BG fans - you are going to LOVE the combat) but they will reward you appropriately - however, you must be aware of the level of your enemies - don't tread into locations with creatures that are 2-3 levels above you or you'll get owned (or not - the game actually lets you wander into such locations and if you are resourcefull enough, you may win those fights - but at a cost of money, resurrection, potions and patience). The only minor down-side of this marvel are a few bugs here and there but developers are getting rid of them as you are reading this - after all, they are nothing game breaking and even AAA titles are often buggy as hell shortly after the release. That's right,this is not an AAA title - it's a Kickstarter game and what a game it is! If Shadowrun was considered a success, this jewel is a miracle. Trully a MUST-HAVE for all RPG fans.

												60 hours in and I love this game. Brings back the feeling of games like Baldurs Gate and Icewind Dale series. If you are old enough to know these games you will fall in love instantly. If your a younger gamer it may take some geting use to the fact that there is little hand holding with the quests. If you can forget everything you have learned from most recent rpg's (Diablo 3) then you will really start to enjoy the game. The combat is very tactical and satisfying. It is possible to overcome encounters above your level if you employ a little bit of tactics and use the terrain. I wont say the story is Tolkien worthy but its put together well enough and keeps the game progressing. Also there is a lot of hidden humor if you take the time to dialog with npc's. All in all I am loving this game and for once the hype is true. Pick it up and give it a try.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												After 80 hours, I finished the game.  I enjoyed my experience, though I'm slightly conflicted in my recommendation.  It's not for everyone, or even everyone who has only played recent RPG's.  It is, however, a worthwhile experience.Does this game have heart?  Yes.  Is the story and combat engaging?  Yes.  Is it challenging?  Yes.But is it good?  Well, mostly.Make no mistake.  This is influenced by traditional RPG from the days of old, where you cut your teeth doing seemingly very difficult things until you've figured out their trick (much like real life).  There are rarely quest map markers to show you your next objective ala Skyrim, and no fairy hanging around telling you what to do.  It's just a world where there are lots of problems, and lots of possible solutions.In a way, this game reminds me of the Stalker series and The Witcher.  You can do anything you want, but a lot of it will end in a quick demise.  Of course I can refuse the troll bridge toll, but doing so will get me pounded.  I can, and did, murder some town NPCs I disliked, and I did so when I knew I would come out on top.  That was satisfying.Enough abstracts.  Here's my in game experience.Hours 1 - 5 (WTF am I doing?): I landed on a beach with little clue how to proceed in the world.  I did some random things, was generally lost.  There are so many deathtraps around town and enemies harder than me, that I didn't want to venture anywhere and contemplated uninstalling the game.Hours 5 - 20 (Oh hey, this is cool):My friend who played the game 10 more hours than me told me about the crucial "Minor Heal" spell and free bed at the inn.  That, combined with teleporting pyramid abuse (infinite town portals, group teleport anywhere, anytime), injected whole new life into exploration and combat.Hours 20 - 30 (Money, money money!):I've discovered that sneaking and invis lets me liberate the entire wealth of my town.  I am now swimming in gold, and fights are enjoyable.  I love my rogue Wolgraff, but he dies so quickly.  At least I have an infinite supply of minions to summon to be fodder for me.I've defeated several awesome bosses through ingenuously manipulating weather effects and feel like a bad♥♥♥♥♥  This is fun!Hours 30 - 40 (2nd town: keeping things fresh):Yeah, being badass is relative.  There are many things more dangerous than I.  Things are challenging, but I'm getting along.Hours 40 - 60 (Yeah!!!!):I've had a blast!  I've been to exotic locations of legend.  Slew tyrants and monsters alike.  Made major plot points and am fighting a crazy, ridiculous cult.  I sparred my wits against many enemies that would have crossed swords with me, and then killed them anyway for the XP.  It's totally justified, since they were the evil ones, not me.Hours 60 - 70 (still good, but getting stale):I now own the collective wealth of many nations.  I can't even sell my gear because no trader has any money left (despite restocking when I level). Only the legendary (and previously invulnerable) death knights give me pause. Most enemies have too many HP and do too little damage, making fights unnecessarily long.  This feels like a grind.Hours 70 - 80 (OCD kept me going):Game is over! Whew.  The final stretch was interesting, but combat posed no challenge. There were some ludicrous puzzles that would've been frustrating if I didn't consult a wiki guide every hour.  The last boss could never damage any character below 90% hp due to my gear, shields, and healing.  He did, however, take 30 minutes of solid whacking to kill.  My friend has also reviewed this game and pointed out the following:1) This game feels like an inventory management chore at times.  Me: CORRECT.  There are many quest items and I didn't want to throw anything away.  Therefore, I hoarded stuff like I did in Skyrim.2) Early game, enemies poison and burn you way too much; the AI can be unforgivingly brutal.  Me: YEP.  But I exploited the AI as I would Dark Souls -- nothing is a cheap shot.  If I have to run away 10 times to kill some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and then cast smoke screen and do cheap lightning bolts from areas they can't see, I'd do it in a heart beat. The world is unforgiving, and so am I.Protip: Zombies bleed poison.  Poison + fire = explosion.  Throw an infinite use, indestructible, lit candle into their "blood" and yell YIPEE KIYAY as you send them into their fiery un-deaths.3) It's hard to click on enemies in combat.  Me: FALSE.  Press "B" to have an overhead view.  Now you can click on everyone, every time.  To be fair, I didn't discover this button until hour 70, which by then is too late.In conclusion, D:OS has been a fun but at times tedious ride.  I enjoyed the openness and challenges that its combat and puzzles gave me early game, and disliked their tedium and obtrusiveness later on near the end.  I would recommend this to anyone who misses Icewind Dale, Baldur's Gate, and enjoys a challenge.  For those who can't live without quest markers, exploiting enemy AI, and sometimes reading a wiki to get ahead, this game may not be for you.  And nothing is wrong with that.P.S. The "Pet Pal" perk was good to have.  Animals say VERY useful and interesting things (not to mention give quests and XP).  I thought it worthless and shunned it for half the game, but in hindsight, it dramatically enhances the flavor of the game.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Honestly, one of the best RPG games I have ever played and I play a lot of RPGs. If you are a fan in any way of old style RPG games or are just a RPG fan in general, you have to get this game. And even if you not a hardcore RPG fan, I really think that you can still have fun with it. I don't understand why its not more popular however this game deserves to be main stream all the way.Pros:- Awesome combat which makes you think before you enter combat situations and really rewards you for eating food which gives you buffs.- No hand holding what so ever therefore making the game challenging but still a lot of fun- Game is long! Finally a game worth the price... I didn't think those existed any more.- Awesome story line that im not where near to finishing but am enjoying so much.- Awesome interaction with the citizens around the city and an all around immersive RPG style game.- Multiplayer is awesome!(Many, many more Pros but I don't want to go on forever)Cons:- The game may not be updated as frequently as most would like.- There is the possibility that you may miss a quest item completely and you may not be able to retrieve this item literally making the game unbeatable, which would make some people mad... but hey pay attention and you should be fine.- Same goes for if you kill an NPC. The NPC might be a quest giver or required for a quest later in the game.- You really have to read up on the forums and research different builds and watch How-Tos... A lot.- Even though Multiplayer is awesome, its only two player, however you can easily download one of the many four player mods out there. I think there is even one on the steam workshop now. Should be easy to find and install.Even with these Cons, this game is so worth it and if you weren't convinced of buying this game before, I really wish that this review convinces you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I'll list my complaints first because that's usually what people look for in reviews.1. The crafting system is pretty unintuitive and not very creative. All you do is drag one item over the other and it creates a product, so literally all you need is 2 items to make something.2. If you misclick because the enemy was moving around too much in his idle animation and issued a move command instead of attack, you can't cancel your move command.3. The god damned NPCs keep repeating the same phrases over and over... you can't exactly mute dialogue either because you'd still hear their echoes even though their voice is silent.4. Stealing makes the game way too easy early on; you can get 20k+ gold before you even hit level 45. Some skills/traits/talents are completely obsolete, such as choosing between altruistic and egotistical. All reputation does is give you better prices when bartering with someone, so that +2 reputation is garbage compared to +1 bartering.6. There are 4 characters you can have in your party, but max players for co-op is 2, unless you get the mod that unlocks the 3rd and 4th slots for others to join.Now, for the positives1. There is no class system; you can literally build your character in however way you want it.2. The game doesn't hold your hand; you simply pick up quests and figure out how to do them. It's not like "go to this location pinpointed exactly on your map and do this for me." I mean♥♥♥♥♥♥ if they knew exactly how to do the thing they requested you to do, why the ♥♥♥♥ would they send you on that quest to begin with?3. I usually hate turn based combat, but this game actually makes it really fun with the variety of abilities your characters have.4. Everything is RNG like a true old school RPG. Loot has random stats, henchmen have random talents, etc.5. Lots of references, riddles, and secrets, which makes exploration feel like it's worth your time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												9/10Pros:-Challenging tactical turn based combat-Impressive bullpen of skills and spells-Not a "baby mode" rpg.  Prepare to have to explore for quests and tinker for crafting.-Freedom to build the party to cater to your specific playstyle-Solid visuals that add to the atmosphereCons:-Overly ambitious story loses its charm by the finale-Ambiguous crafting system is sometimes too...ambiguous-A few annoying glitchesSynopsis:D:OS is the best game of its kind (party based rpg) to be released since neverwinter nights 2 but is not without flaws.  The narrative suffers from being overly ambitious.  The very world is at stake and it seems that the story writers struggle with how to weave the player characters naturally into the puzzle.  The result is an awkward dance where the game attempts to convince us these source hunters were of course much more than just that.  We don't need to be saving the world for the story to matter.  Having said that, the game has plenty of obvious strengths.  First of all, it is gorgeous.  Dungeons and locales spring to life with the appropriate ambiance and give you a real sense of being in a fantasy world. Next of course is the core gameplay.  I found the turn based combat system is extremely entertaining with diverse groups of enemies bringing equally interesting challenges.  In addition, the questing system forces you to use your head and eyes to advance.  No brainless killing and gathering to be found here.  Overall, a polished RPG experience with a robust amount of content

D:OS, is one of today's hand down best RPG games, it has the exploration value and fun, as such games like Skyrim, exploring is truly fun, and as well as that, important for character progression.
