content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This CRPG is one of the best out there. The game is played in real-time but the battles are turn-based, with great elemental and landscape interactions. The world itself wonderfully drawn--a nice combination between pretty landscapes and cartoonish monsters. The music is awesome and I enjoy the voicing (I talk to the rats more often than necessary because it makes me giggle). The price is well worth the amount of content for the game ($40). (Edited to add--finished the game at ~91 hours. Awesome value for dollar). The story is engrossing and you make many choices along the way that affect your gameplay. In fact, beware; choices are permanent and have consequences. If you choose to shoot an NPC in the face with a fireball in broad daylight...well, I recommend you save often in case you need to roll back after some instant regret. The puzzles in this game can be hard, and the most difficult aspect is likely the fact that you have to pay attention to EVERYTHING--there's a lot of story and the game expects you to listen and learn. If you get confused or lost (which happened to us...erm, often....) you might get a little frustrated. Consider all of your actions, pay attention to story and quests, put care into where you put your skill points, and you'll be fine. My complaints are small: inventory can become unwieldy, and some of the puzzles are hard (or require patience levels that I don't possess). However, the sheer fun of this game more than makes up for the small bugs and there are a lot of surprises waiting inside this gameI give it a 10/10 for co-op.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Think how great it would be if you had some kind of insane mashup of Baldur's Gate and Divine Divinity. Now treble it, throw in a healthy dose of Larian's usual tongue in cheek humour, and you're looking at Original Sin.  Beginning with two characters (with more NPC's available to recruit along the way) you're a pair of source hunters (think witch finder♥♥♥♥♥inquisition) dispatched to investigate a murder. Though as usual, things aren't quite what they seem, what with the mysterious undead horde at the gates and constant attacks by an Orc invasion fleet.  Combat is turn based and thankfully manages to remain interesting. All combatants act according to an initiative order, with a reserve of action points they can use for clobbering, shooting or spell slinging. What's likely to garner most attention here is the environmental effects - create a poison cloud to gas your foes, then ignite it with a fireball to set them ablaze for good measure. Then douse them with water, which puts out the fire but creates a cloud of blinding steam instead. A cloud which can be electrified to bring a shocking conclusion to the fight.  Dialogue is your good old fashioned multi-choice dialogue tree. Your party members will chime in frequently when certain events happen, both within the party and without.  For your two initial characters you can choose their responses to each other, which seems weird but works quite well. Conversational skills are handled via a mini-game of rock-paper-scissors (though this is skippable) with the character's various skills impacting how this plays out.  The little touches are great; enter sneak mode for example and your character will pull off the old 'walking bush' trick with whatever seems to fit the environment. The screen fades slightly with character's vision cones highlighted so you can try and avoid whoever you're trying to sneak up on from spotting you. The ability to move objects within the world is put to good use in some of the puzzles and offers an interesting means of dealing with things like traps.  Writing so far is fantastic, with Larian's tongue being firmly in their cheek. Three hours in and I'm dressed as a barrel trying to pickpocket the commander of the city guard so I can steal his handkerchief to take to a dog I met in the graveyard so it can tell me if he's involved in his master's murder. This is after I've returned a talking clam to the sea and been transported through time and space to meet the weaver of time who'd quite like some help dealing with the final death of the universe. Never mind RPG of the year, this is probably my RPG of the previous decade.

If you want to enter in a beautiful fantasy world with awesome feeling which requires the patience to read any dialog and crafting recipes, then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Author’s note: Whilst a Kickstarter funder myself, I did not touch the game during its development process – therefore I cannot compare any pre- and post-release changes. This is an early, first impressions review. I shall amend this upon further venturing into the game.Divinity: Original Sin is Larian Studio’s latest addition to the Divinity series, going back to its roots as a turn-based RPG set in an open world with unlimited possibilities. You control two customizable characters, who arrive on an Island chasing down sorcerers, fighting off orcs, and investigating the reports of undead activity in the area. Quirky and engaging, Larian’s Kickstarter darling is a welcome addition to anyone’s game library.Original Sin starts you off by letting you customize your two playable characters. You can change their class, appearance, and even their initial stats, if you wish. There are numerous options to choose from, with the classes ranging from fighter to wayfarer, offering varied styles of play, but can probably be grouped into three major roles (coinciding with the three voice pack choices in game): rogue, warrior, and wizard. There are many roles that min-max certain skill sets, while others act as a blend between two major roles. Overall, there is enough variety here to cater to different play styles. Cosmetic customization is also rich, with options to change gender, hair, voice, skin tone, face, and portrait all available.The game features a very neat art style and visual aesthetic. The world of Original Sin is colourful, vivid, and full of life. The trees sway gently, torches burn brightly, and water flows smoothly – the world feels dynamic and active with every little detail added in. The quality of the game’s graphics is astoundingly good, while also being somewhat efficient – it runs on Ultra by default on my GTX 765M, and I’ve had no issues with it dropping below 30, usually floating at the 40s on FRAPS. The art style is akin to a more realistic Torchlight – colours pop out and everything is somehow cartoonish, but it definitely feels like a believably real representation of its world.Combat in Original Sin goes about in a turn-based, action point oriented style. It is reminiscent of other classic RPGs such as Fallout 1 and 2. Certain actions cost a certain amount of AP, movement AP cost is dependent on distance (in meters, unsure if you can change this to the empirical format) and certain units are given priority to move first. Various stats affect what weapons and armor you can equip, how certain skills work for your character, hit chance, dodge chance, and inventory space. So far, the combat flows nicely, and is quite enjoyable. One of the more noticeable breaks from the usual AP system is that any unused AP in a turn is carried over, adding more options for your later turns.A major part of Original Sin is interaction with its various characters, with special focus between the two player characters. Often times, when a decision is to be made, your characters exchange dialog, with each option affecting certain traits of the characters, such as their persuasion, obedience, and altruism.So far, with roughly two hours in, Original Sin is showing plenty of signs of a good game, and I will definitely invest more time in it to further develop my opinion. It seems like the game is made for coop, with two players controlling one character each. I can see that playing out fairly well, with hilarious results in the inter-character dialog! Overall, I would say that if you were already interested in the game, it wouldn’t be such a bad idea to get it, especially if you have a friend playing it as well.

You can play alone, or coop, every player gets the chance to answer questions, to agree or disagree completely.     If you want to enter in a beautiful fantasy world with awesome feeling which requires the patience to read any dialog and crafting recipes, then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Author’s note: Whilst a Kickstarter funder myself, I did not touch the game during its development process – therefore I cannot compare any pre- and post-release changes. This is an early, first impressions review. I shall amend this upon further venturing into the game.Divinity: Original Sin is Larian Studio’s latest addition to the Divinity series, going back to its roots as a turn-based RPG set in an open world with unlimited possibilities. You control two customizable characters, who arrive on an Island chasing down sorcerers, fighting off orcs, and investigating the reports of undead activity in the area. Quirky and engaging, Larian’s Kickstarter darling is a welcome addition to anyone’s game library.Original Sin starts you off by letting you customize your two playable characters. You can change their class, appearance, and even their initial stats, if you wish. There are numerous options to choose from, with the classes ranging from fighter to wayfarer, offering varied styles of play, but can probably be grouped into three major roles (coinciding with the three voice pack choices in game): rogue, warrior, and wizard. There are many roles that min-max certain skill sets, while others act as a blend between two major roles. Overall, there is enough variety here to cater to different play styles. Cosmetic customization is also rich, with options to change gender, hair, voice, skin tone, face, and portrait all available.The game features a very neat art style and visual aesthetic. The world of Original Sin is colourful, vivid, and full of life. The trees sway gently, torches burn brightly, and water flows smoothly – the world feels dynamic and active with every little detail added in. The quality of the game’s graphics is astoundingly good, while also being somewhat efficient – it runs on Ultra by default on my GTX 765M, and I’ve had no issues with it dropping below 30, usually floating at the 40s on FRAPS. The art style is akin to a more realistic Torchlight – colours pop out and everything is somehow cartoonish, but it definitely feels like a believably real representation of its world.Combat in Original Sin goes about in a turn-based, action point oriented style. It is reminiscent of other classic RPGs such as Fallout 1 and 2. Certain actions cost a certain amount of AP, movement AP cost is dependent on distance (in meters, unsure if you can change this to the empirical format) and certain units are given priority to move first. Various stats affect what weapons and armor you can equip, how certain skills work for your character, hit chance, dodge chance, and inventory space. So far, the combat flows nicely, and is quite enjoyable. One of the more noticeable breaks from the usual AP system is that any unused AP in a turn is carried over, adding more options for your later turns.A major part of Original Sin is interaction with its various characters, with special focus between the two player characters. Often times, when a decision is to be made, your characters exchange dialog, with each option affecting certain traits of the characters, such as their persuasion, obedience, and altruism.So far, with roughly two hours in, Original Sin is showing plenty of signs of a good game, and I will definitely invest more time in it to further develop my opinion. It seems like the game is made for coop, with two players controlling one character each. I can see that playing out fairly well, with hilarious results in the inter-character dialog! Overall, I would say that if you were already interested in the game, it wouldn’t be such a bad idea to get it, especially if you have a friend playing it as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is a beautiful game, everything from the look of the water, to the sound design is top notch in my opinion. What really makes it awesome, is that it relies on a sort of "old school" methodology when it comes to combat and questing. I think that is what sets it apart from so many other games, and in a good way. This game is not easy, but at the same time, I wouldn't say that its unfairly difficult. As long as you take the time to understand the mechanics, it won't be too bad. It really makes the player analyze each encounter, and use that knowledge to be better prepared for future fights. The game's combat is turn base, so that might put some people off, but I personally think thats part of the reason the game is so great. It gives you the freedom to stop and think instead of rushing into a fight. Another point I mentioned, was the questing system. This game is totally free of hand holding, so you really need to use your head to figure out the quests, you actually need to talk to the NPC's and explore the environment to have any chance of completing them. (Get petpal ASAP!)"Player choice" and "Freedom" are terms often used to describe games, but usually I feel, most games fall short of allowing the player to really play the game how they want. With Divinity: OS, this is not the case, you really can play the game how you want. If you want to kill the starting NPC's that give you the first quests, you can do it. There is no set path that you are supposed to follow, you can really play the game how you want.Lastly, I just want to mention that somethings are hard to figure out when first playing the game. For instance, you will want to save up ability points so you can unlock better skills instead of spending them right away. Certain things like this can be tough to figure out, so I would recommend reading some beginner guides online first. There are some great ones on Steam already. Past the basic stuff, I wouldn't read anything else online though, part of the fun of this game is figuring stuff out on your own.Honestly, this is one of the best games I have ever played. I don't think I've been this engrossed in a game in years. If you like RPG's and rewarding/challenging games, please get this game, it really is amazing.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												D:OS is in a word...amazing. Think Baldurs Gates but Co-Op with a little Magicka thrown in as far as spell interaction goes. Nasty archers with fire arrows or pyrokinetic mages have your friends on fire? Use your magician to make it rain and quench the flames...and guess what now everyone is wet and susceptible to being frozen with a chill spell. Not to mention you can fire lightning at a puddle of water or blood to make a stun field. So many possibilites. Wanna steal from an NPC but they keep walking around? Break up your party and talk to up 3 NPCs separately while you rob them blind. Pick up a talent called Leech and everytime blood toches your character (even their own) they recieve Health. Nasty Melee enemy right in your caster/ranger's face? Teleport him into the sky and drop him on his head (or his friends) for great damage and better position.So much can be said about this game but know this TACTICS RULE THE DAY. Fully utilizing your party is the key to victory even on normal difficulty. Learn how ALL OF YOUR SKILLS interplay, DO NOT I REPEAT DO NOT stifle your own development by only sticking to Oil/Fire. Nothing can beat a varied party that really knows how to change any situation. And Last but not least FULL ONLINE CO-OP not just some watered down mode.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This CRPG is one of the best out there. The game is played in real-time but the battles are turn-based, with great elemental and landscape interactions. The world itself wonderfully drawn--a nice combination between pretty landscapes and cartoonish monsters. The music is awesome and I enjoy the voicing (I talk to the rats more often than necessary because it makes me giggle). The price is well worth the amount of content for the game ($40). (Edited to add--finished the game at ~91 hours. Awesome value for dollar). The story is engrossing and you make many choices along the way that affect your gameplay. In fact, beware; choices are permanent and have consequences. If you choose to shoot an NPC in the face with a fireball in broad daylight...well, I recommend you save often in case you need to roll back after some instant regret. The puzzles in this game can be hard, and the most difficult aspect is likely the fact that you have to pay attention to EVERYTHING--there's a lot of story and the game expects you to listen and learn. If you get confused or lost (which happened to us...erm, often....) you might get a little frustrated. Consider all of your actions, pay attention to story and quests, put care into where you put your skill points, and you'll be fine. My complaints are small: inventory can become unwieldy, and some of the puzzles are hard (or require patience levels that I don't possess). However, the sheer fun of this game more than makes up for the small bugs and there are a lot of surprises waiting inside this gameI give it a 10/10 for co-op.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												I've finished the game yesterday. It's a good game, but it's overrated.Pros:- Interesting, turn based combat system.- Controlling two independent characters at once (would love to try this with multi).- Classless character system.- Mod system.- Soundtrack.Okays:- Graphics.- Amount of content.   Well, I think there's a lot of content, but not everything seems to be well thought out. I dislike the Diablo-esque loot system, where bosses or chests drop too much of random loot. Old BlackIsle games didn't do stuff like this :/- Dialogues.   Lots of work went into them, but they seem to be unpolished sometimes. Sometimes they're quite clichee.- Plot. Beginning was good. The rest.. okay. The execution wasn't always good - sometimes too light-hearted, and not that consistent atmoshpere.Cons:- Too big adventage for elemental users.- Too big focus on the combat, not on the plot development. The fights are challenging on normal difficulty, but once you have to repeat 5 fights 3 times each to advance the plot a little, it becomes tiresome. Especially since the combat is kind of repetetive. (played as a Knight and a Marksman)- Pixel hunting puzzles.- Lack of interface for crafting.- The way mouse is raycasted over objects. Sometimes I would have to move my mouse to an exact spot to hit a monster, otherwise I would use Action Points trying to walk behind it before attacking.In the end I think it is a well made game, but not a revolutionary one. The game lacks a little bit of polish here and there. It has some 'novel' concepts, which should be interesting to those who weren't exposed to them before.But I don't think this game deserves 10/10. Maybe compared to nowdays RPG titles, yes. But compared to broader RPG experience, I'd say it's 7/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I am completely enthralled with this game :)And as I'm progressing in my age :O that does not happen all that often anymore...First of all, I will admit that fans of the series, or simply people familiar with the previous installments, are surely more likely to get more out of this title :) But isn't that always true? And is it a "con?" That said, it being a prequel - it is absolutely unnecessary for anyone to play any of the previous games ;)Meeting old pals, or in this case, "premet" pals (like preheated or precooked or something? :O), references to some special quests (the healing conundrum, anyone? :D), and other lore quirks that transcend all the titles - the game is brimming with those! And I absolutely adored the original Divinie Divinity - one of my first crpgs I have ever played to completion and with multiple playthroughs. Some of the other sequels to the original were... let's just say, they were trying different approaches. But finally, Larian Studios struck gold, by creating this masterpiece of a game :)I have spent about 10 hours in this new version of the realm of Rivellon and I haven't even moved out of the starting hub xD Really! I have scouted every nook and cranny of this little town, discovering its secrets and easter eggs :D And if the remainder of the content is anything like the starting town, the game is just huge! But not as much in area as in detail, and I find that to be a much more valuable trait - one often ignored in times of vast, open-world games, which offer size, but not quality :/The sneaking system - OMG, so funny! Metal Gear Solid references there I can see... is what Yoda would have said... :O Anyways, there is plenty of these innuendoes, references to other games, to life in general. At one point, the two main heroes, who are your avatars (yes, you lead two characters, but you command a larger party later on), comment on how ridiculous it is, that they can't jump over a simple rope to get to a loot chest. And in fact, nothing can be done to the rope, and there is no way to go around it with the chest being on a pier. But there is a way to get to the loot :)And this is the next thing I want to talk about. These days, when developers say "multiple choices, multiple approaches, multiple endings," I usually cringe, because the word multiple often does not go beyond the number two... sometimes 3... but, I guess, technicially, 3 qualifies as multpile... -.- Anyway, in Divinity: Original Sin, if you can think it, you can probably do it :) Well obviously, I'm exaggerating, but what is not exaggerated, though, is the word multiple in this game ;) Sneaking, and stealing, using your characters as distractions to divert the line of sight of unsuspecting owners, suffering the consequences if caught and reaping the benefits, if not, could be a game on its own :) And I loved, when I looted yet another painting off a wall (I found them to be a great source of income!) and my partner congratulated me on yet another heist well done. Usually in those random conversations the options are only binary, however, they each have a consequence which often reflects in a trait in permanent stats of the characters.And yes the stats! Talents, abilities, skills.... so many things to make each character unique, offering infinite replayability. And the number of classes has also increased, when compared to other Divinity RPGs. Most of your talents affect one another, not just spells, interacting with the environment, but other traits as well - charisma, speed, leadership, luck - there are so many factors to affect your gameplay, yet it is all seemlessly blended in, so that you always intuitively know which stat to boost and which to ignore (telekinesis FTW, though! It reminded me so much of the original Divinity :D).Only, if the game was more graphically pleasing... Just kidding - it is truly gorgeous! The world is rich and detailed, as is the whole game. The depth of field does wonders at closer zoom, the characters are nicely outlined, so that it is never too confusing during the battles.... Oh, yes! The fighting system.Now, turn-based is the way to go in classic crpgs, in my opinion. Trigger-happy button smashing is fun, but for action-adventure games. For RPGs, which aim at a longer gameplay, richer plot, multitude of side-quests, a turn-based system fits better into the general mechanic and is consistent with the source behind cRPGs - the actual role-playing games, which obviously are based on the dice ;) With the amount of interactivity between the various talents and the environment, this particular system makes each encounter a unique experience. And again, the game rewards clever thinking, choosing the path less traveled by, which may be less obvious, too, but offers a more visceral final scores :)Scores... Have I talked about the music already? No, and I should have started with that - it is gorgeous, no wait, already used gorgeous... mesmerizing, yes! It is mesmerizingly beautiful. There are lovely new scores, as well as some tracks from the orignal Divine Divinity, whose soundtrack is often praised to this day! And some of the tracks are even variations on those original tracks! It's so nice when you hear the tavern music, or the Rivertown farmlands choiry march one more time and it actually has some twist to it :) The music in the Divnity titles has always been of high quality, and this legacy is well-kept still.I have mentioned rewarding clever thinking. I think, coming to a close here, that the success of this game is the best kind of a reward for the clever thinking the developers have resorted to in creating this title :) It is a true spiritual successor to the highly acclaimed Divine Divinity - both in mechanics, interactivity of the environment, a unique twist on the classical fantasy paradigm, but - above all - in the range of options that is given to the player to progress in the game. There is a million other things I probably wanted to have said but did not... and remember, I only experienced the very beginning :) Larian Studios has long saught to find a formula to repeat their initial success - I strongly believe they have found one :)Congratulations to them, and salutations to all of you - I hope you are, or will be, as satisfied with Divinity: Original Sin as I am.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												Divinity: Original Sin is a fantastic game.  I can't recommend it enough.  I grew up playing the older turn-based RPGs such as Torment and Baulder's Gate, as well as the Fallout series so this game was right up my alley.  Even if you've never played a turn-based RPG you owe it to yourself to check it out.  The graphics are really good for the genre and the spell effects are great.  The sound quality was also pretty good except the background characters' lines got annoying..."nobody has as many friends as the man with many cheeses" and "How did you find Hiberheim this time of year my dear.... cold, very cold"   will be forever etched into my memory as well as other lines too numerous to count.  The game is LONG.  I played around 100 hours, doing almost all of the side quests.  There is loot galore in addition to the ability to craft some very strong armors.  I didn't explore crafting into late into the game however adding element resistances to armor was extremely helpful in the endgame.  I also crafted some rings to boost Constitution on a couple of characters to make up for deficiencies.This game was a joy to play and I am really looking forward to see what Larian comes up with next.

												Phenominal game. Music, graphics, gameplay, voice acting (even the annoying archeologist). Even though the combat is turn based its action is mezmorizing. The way they have woven many NPC's fate together keep you guessing whats next or who done it. Anyone loving Baldurs Gate or Icewind Dale style games will love this. Its hard to put down. I don't know what it is but I just love the fact that you always have a key to the door or chest, whether in the form of a key, lockpick or brute strength, my favorite having Madora smash something into oblivion. The "effects" that npc's are put under add depth to combat, a group of Orcs standing in a puddle causing them to be "wet" now you get to zap them with electricity for extra damage/stunning but be careful. If you are within that same puddle you feel the effects too. Another aspect which is wonderful, keeping you on your toes.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Playing Divinity honestly felt like playing Dungeons and Dragons with a fairly creative DM who managed to ♥♥♥♥ up some times. The game is a turned based magic and sorcery RPG, with a lot of bizarre magic interactions. Let's say that there's a fire in your way. Casting rain will put out the fire, leaving behind a steam cloud that blocks line of sight and a bunch of puddles. Casting lightning on the puddles will then cause them to be electrified, stunning anyone who walks over them. There are all sorts of elemental interactions like this can make for fairly deep and nuanced combat. The story is fairly compelling, with a well realized world and interesting intrigue between different players. I played through this game 100% coop and think that it deserves to be lauded for making a deep RPG with an interesting story that actively encourages people to work together. I feel that that's the next step for gaming. We've had plenty of Left 4 Dead-ish action co op games, but now I feel that story-oriented coop can become a real thing. But unfortunately, the game needs some simple UI adjustments to become a bit more coop friendly. If you have two different people doing two different things in a game, then you need to clearly deliver all plot essential dialogue to both players. Often I'd be off crafting something and my partner would go and have an important conversation and I'd be left wondering what the heck was going on. Considering that the game gives you a teleport pyramid thing early on, it really wouldn't have hurt to pull the other player to important dialogues the moment they started (and to pop a dialogue window for both players the moment said dialogue began). Another problem is that the game's puzzles are completely awful. Any puzzle where you have to run around a room looking for a button to press (which usually is impossible to see with the default camera angle) is not really a puzzle at all. Portal 2 taught us that group puzzle solving can be incredibly fun and there are moments when I got that same high of being able to figure out a solution and brag about it, but those moments were heavily outweighed by the pixel hunt puzzles. With a little more polish in these departments, this would have been a superb game. As it stands right now, I'd call it a pretty good game (maybe even a REALLY good game) that is certainly moving in the right direction. If they make an expansion pack, I'll certainly get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Baldur's Gate with a splash of XCOM. Linear and not particularly repeatable, but a good co-op diversion with a dedicated partner.No cover drawn from its XCOM heritage, but tactical combat control and lockdowns are the order of the day. Scoundrels, Men at Arms, and Expert Marksmen are effectively 'mages in armor', with broad spell variety saved for dedicated INT casters, who will have a few skill trees due to less attribute dependence. Spend some time studying the character generation and level up systems, as understanding how tightly you will need to specialize is vital - the game is parsimonious with stat improvements. The tactical combat will pull no punches though the AI can sometimes be baited into foolish mistakes of positioning. Get friendly with your quicksave key, and put a grin on - the combat can be brutal, and a winning contest can go south quickly when new enemy abilities make their first appearance. D:OS won't warn you about what's coming.For mages doing damage, elemental combinations are the order of the day, and being able to apply all of the earth(poison)/fire and water/air(electricity) pairings is useful, but specialize in one pairing. Countering these works as you might imagine - water dries up when heated, fire goes out when rained upon. Be able to counter them all, amongst your group. Poison can be burned off (explosively!). Ice will melt, faster with help. Witchcraft is the INT caster version of Man-at-Arms, with fewer controls, but more ranged debuffs and pet summons - an armored decapitator appearing behind enemy lines is nothing to sneer at. (Nor are the various elementals and animals from the elemental skills, for that matter, but one summon per caster at a time.)The writing is adequate, but not stellar. The first who-dun-it wasn't particularly inspiring, and oftentimes progression has been a matter of "what level are those enemies?" rather than a cohesive sense of direction and progress. The quest journal is next-to-useless for many quests, providing little or no information to follow up. Use markers liberally, and don't be ashamed to augment the game's lacking journalling with some of your own. If you're doing every quest, expect to either miss a few things or need a walkthrough/guide from time to time.The rock-paper-scissors mechanic for the 'persuasion minigame' is by turns novel and tiresome. It's cute the first couple of times you see it, and it's a new way to 'randomize' a mechanic that no one seems to get right (persuasion) but it misses the mark in not having an "autoplay". Frankly, I don't want to play RPS against the computer, or my partner, and if the point is to provide some uncertainty to 'speech checks', that's fine - but I don't care for the minigame much. Fortunately, it's been relatively rare thus far...Character control is relatively straightforward - two players control four characters between them, in any combination. The host controls who gets to run which, allowing one player to AFK while the other plays a combat or to allow a tactical novice to mind only a single character in combat, etc. Wife and I split our characters into two teams of two, and it works out well - I run the NPC warrior Madora (man-at-arms) and shadow cleric (witchcraft/some water/man-at-arms), she handles the mage duties (one in all colleges for access, specializing earth/fire for stronger effects) and the sneaky rogue Wolgraff we recruited.Combat is turn based and is the real meat of the game, with players asked to deploy skills and weapons to defeat foes in a number of varied battlefield conditions. Often, a different approach or tactical plan is the difference between victory and reloading, and fights have been challenging often.All around, an enjoyable game, but remember those roots - the game doesn't pretend to be a more modern RPG, no matter the pretty graphics, so study up on how the level system works. It doesn't pretend to have autopilot combat, either. Bring your tactical thinking to the table....and get ready to read, because this is a long, slow march, not a sprint.Edit:Bugs, however, abound. Often, we notice desync issues when the host reloads the game and player #2's characters appear to have no stats (base scores all reset to 5) and not be wearing their gear, etc. We've not experienced any corruption from these episodes, but save often to avoid screams of hair-rending frustration when player 2 says "My character is bugged. Again." I'm amazed this wasn't caught and corrected, given how prevalent it's been for us!We've seen a couple of minor oddities (one bug involved a repeatedly-exploding poison gas trap that killed a boss in a single round because the poison would detonate, leave a fire puddle, the gas would refill the area, detonate... The boss standing in the cloud never took a combat turn - the explosion cycle took himn from 100% to 0% in one round of chained, buggy explosions (not that I'm complaining).Learn how to temper armor and weapons, learn how to make basic equipment (Madora makes a decent smith) and you can take advantage of movement speed penalty reductions on heavy armor and enhanced basic damage on weapons (for free). Don't play 'hard mode' if you don't have to!If you're into RPGs this one's worth a look, but don't expect all the rough corners to be filed down or a 100% bug-free experience, because they're not and it's not.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin has two very big thumbs up from me.  It's one of the best RPG's I've played in a long, long time. That said, there certainly are a few issues which I'm sure will be remedied over time.  The responsiveness and care that Larian has put into the release and post release of this product is second to none.The freedom that the player has while clumsily wandering throughout the very large and immersive world is unparalleled.  Being able to do whatever I want, whatever I want - good or bad is powerful.  That kind of freedom really allows the player to be a part of the world and really drive where the game goes (or doesn't go).Aside from some intrusive tutorial stuff and some weird UI management - the game is pretty spectacular.  I know I'll be playing it for a while to come and I've already sunk over 90 hours into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Divinity Original Sin is old-school-style RPG, with a rich atmosphere, lots of character-building, turn-based combat and excellent coop-support where you (or you and a friend) play as the two main-characters, called the "source-hunters".TLDR-version: I definitly recommend this game to all non-casual RPG fans, for it highly depends on much reading and using ones own wits to solve or even find quests.[4/5] Gameplay The gameplay as it is would be perfect. You have interesting combat (more on that later), trading and dialouge options with almost every character in the world, a gripping story and huge freedom in terms of character-building. Battle-mage that vanishes like a rouge during combat? No problem. The typical grumpy, know-it-all wizard with devasting spells? Of course. A weak charismatic healer with almost no combat skills? Here you go.There regullary are dialouges between the two heros, where you can define their attitude towards each other and their nature.So the observing reader may ask: Why only 4 out of 5 stars? Well the gameplay experience is hindered by some bugs from time to time (not that often). There is for example a bug, that lets the attributes and breastplate of your controlled hero disappear (only on your client). The host has to save the game and reload it to fix it. Or there is this bug that prevent you from hitting enemies that are to close to rocks or walls (only had this bug twice in my playtime).With these bugs fixed the gameplay would be perfect.[5/5] Combat The combat is round-based. Normally I prefer real-time combat over turn-based, but Divinity: Original Sin is an exception I guess. The combat is incredibly complex (yet easy, don't get me wrong!), so the turn-based system lets you use the terrain and fight very strategicaly. There are tons of different spells and lots of different weapon styles. You can (with the right talent) backstab enemies for extra damage or create a oil surface and inflame that, teleport an enemy into that burning surface, electrify water sufaces or steam-clouds, the possiblities are endless.[4.5/5] Controls Not much to say about the controlls. One could say good controlls don't come to your attention and that's the case here. The game is mainly controlled with the mouse, though there are shortcuts for the spells in your hotbar, the inventory...The only problem that occured to me is that when you try to get some item out of an poisoned/burning/electrified area and you can't reach it from out of that area, your hero steps into it and (especially in the begining of your journey) dies. So you have to be careful...[3.5/5] AIThe AI in this game controlls your character when you are walking by clicking on the ground instead of holding the left mouse button to guide him or her. It does a decent job at that, avoiding hazardous areas or traps, as long as it is able to (see "controlls").The AI of enemies on the other hand somtimes is quite dumb. For example: It attacked my main character until he had 20hp left. Now it could have killed him with another successful hit. Instead it started attacking my companions and ended up losing that fight.Sometimes I'm quite thankful for quirks like that, for the fights can be really hard from time to time, yet it feels "wrong", if you know what i mean.Often the AI beautifully combines spells and terrain effects, creating challenging fights without feeling unfair. Many times there was that "WTF?!" effect when an enemy shot an poison arrow at my group and in the next turn a mage set it on fire, nearly wiping the party.[5/5] Immersion What can I say about this one, except it is perfect? The dialouges are interesting and you can have them with literally every person on the map (except the mobs of course...). A certain talent allows you to speak with animals, which often have an intersting story to tell, a funny sentence (Imagine a rooster saying: "Soon the cleaver of decapitation will be turned upon you, the revolution is coming!!"), or even tips on how to solve puzzles.[5/5] MapAll of the levels are beautiful designed and contain many details. There are hidden secrets and treasure, quests off the beaten path. Could you ask for more?[4.5/5] GraphicsThe graphics are held in a isometric view and rotatable by some 90°, but you can zoom in really close and look your hero into the eyes (while having a cool blurred background). The game nicely plays with different ambient lighting and weather effects. The spell effects are solid, not always brilliant, but definitly nice. Some of the animations are kind of clunky, yet they do not destroy the atmosphere or immersion.[4/5] AudioThe game has a amazing soundtrack, that beautifully accompanies combat, travel or dialgoues. All the other audio is solid, but sometimes repetitive.Take for example the marketplace of the first city, where you will spend very much time. All of the merchants have a few lines they say, some funny, some serious. But they repeat that few lines over and over again.After hearing "No one has as many friends, as the man with the many cheeses!" for the 40th time you have an urge to slaughter that man, believe me. Only a few of the dialouges are spoken, but considering the vast amount of dialouges I guess it's ok. Yet, everything that is spoken is done very well.[NA/5] DevelopersI had no contact with the developers.Though it has some flaws this game is definitly worth buying. It is highly addictive, especially in coop. Divinity: Original Sin is one of my favourite games of all time.Final Rating 4.5 out of 5 stars - Fix the bugs and some of the minor flaws and this game is perfection.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												[Please note: I reserve to change this review as I proceed in the adventure and as game patches come in].Divinity: Original Sin is a solid classic-style RPG, focused on co-op play (but absolutely enjoyable in solo play as well) with very modern graphics and with *lots* of things to do. A first thing to consider: this game is hard if you compare it to most contemporary titles -- you will die multiple times if you are not careful, trust me, so save often! -- and it does not take you by hand, it lets you explore the world and do what you like, when you like it; it feels old-school in a way, but at the same time extremely fresh. And speaking of it, the game world is enormous and should provide from 60 to 100 hours of fun, even without considering any of the user generated content that fans will provide on the Steam Workshop.The levelling system is classless so you can literally become anything you like (although the game delivers tens of starting archetypes if you don't want to mess too much with all the traits and abilities): for example, you can start as a warrior and acquire magical skills later in the game as you level up and assign points accordingly.Combat is tactical and turn-based and therefore quite complex... but don't worry, it's fun and you can plan your next move without being in a hurry!The post-launch lack of "AI personalities" for your party members has been fixed, and therefore now in singleplayer you can enjoy dialogues and banter with your own party members without having to pick all lines for everybody. :POverall I'm very impressed with this game, and I am looking forward to play it for much time to come. If you like CRPGs like me... get it, you won't be disappointed.My vote: 9 / 10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is reminiscent of Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, and all those great D&D based games from the 90's. The only difference is the turn based combat which doesn't detract from the game itself. I myself dislike turn based combat, but found that in Divinity, the combat was a very entertaining aspect.In the above list of games, if you spent time pausing combat, planning moves and then executing them, then Divinity: Original Sin will handle that just fine with it's turn based combat. The isometric (yes, isometric) views are gorgeous, and you can zoom in and get pretty up close and personal with the rest of the world. Speaking of views, you can disable it and have a full 360 view, but the main campaign doesn't recommend it due to, "graphical artefacts". However, when player made campaigns get released, they will hopefully make full use of the 360 immersion.Gameplay wise, the world is immersive and expansive. Characters are rather believable, and the choices you make do impact the rest of the world. I have yet to experience these choices, but my gut feeling tells me that some of the people I helped, shunned or let go will come back to haunt me in the future. At some points, you'll get inter-party conversations, which are nice, but some of them add a little twist to the gameplay. Depending on your choices, characters will gain trait points which can apply different bonuses to your character, or party. For instance, if you have a person who demonstrated good leadership, they'll inspire the rest of your team. However, if a conversation later down the line makes that same character act like less of a leader, they can lose that leadership trait.The game world is both expansive and immersive. The nice paintings in people's houses are very decorative... and profitable. A quick sleight of hand, and practically every object can belong to you. Broomsticks turn into weapons, buckets turn into helmets, pillows can be cut open and their feather's taken. Barrels and boxes can be moved to create some barricades to help with a battle, or to block traps. The amount of detail put into the environment and how you interact with it is astonishing. If you were like me, and were awaiting a game to astound and captivate you like Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, Divinity: Original Sin won't disappoint. So far, everything in the game has been executed very well and has been polished rather nicely. I'm looking forward to delving further into the game world, and then experiencing it with online with other players.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Has a cat romance quest, 10/10.Seriously, though, Divinity: Original Sin, is one of the finest RPGs I have ever had the pleasure of playing. Clever writing (though, the constant talking of the NPCs in the town can get annoying, they have a tendency to talk over each other), a quite pleasing art style and more stats and skills than you can shake a wizard staff at! Having the two main characters interact is also a great roleplaying mechanic, either with a friend, or even alone.The combat, especially, is a real treat. Turn-based, eschewing mana or other resources in favour of an Action Point system, a la the old X-COM. Enemies are tough and their favourite past-time is chopping adventurers to bits, so you'll need to use your skills intelligently, especially considering magic and their assorted elemental combos.Overall, a few minor nuisances here and there aside, Original Sin is a splendid game, well worth your time, especially if you feel casting cold spells in the rain should do more than just increase damage.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is the latest entry in the Divinity series of games, chronologically following Divinity: Dragon Commander and preceeding the events of Divine Divinity.  It is also an unbelievably good game and you should play it immediately.Maybe I should explain.Original Sin chronicles the tale of two Source Hunters, inquisitorial figures who have been granted vast authority by the Council of Seven, as they travel the world of Rivellon.  The premise is well-trod in other games; crusaders questing to destroy dark Sourcerers, who must face dire threats while keeping themselves from becoming the very monsters they yadda yadda yadda.But this is a Divinity game.  This is the direct sequel to the game wherein you played an army commander who was also a dragon wearing a jetpack.Rivellon is an incredible world to explore- one part hilarious, one part tragic, two parts engrossing.  After you've made your way through the tomb which serves as a tutorial, the game world is simply open, the tasks blinking in your journal neither pushing nor pulling.  In our playthrough, my friend and I have found ourselves moving through the world like water; taking the most interesting paths of least resistance and criss-crossing the map in crazed fashion.  Against the backdrop of a town Councillor's murder, we helped a cat find love, or fought the ghosts of pirates, or battled our way slowly through a monsterous hellscape on a whim.  Every screen has something noteworthy taking place on it, even if it's not immediately obvious what,  and NPC conversations, dialogue, environmental cues and short in-game books are meshed seamlessly into a dramatic and intriguing whole.As far as the cliche-sounding plotline goes, the story may surprise you.  Nearly as soon as the mundane primary quests begin, they are interwoven with a metaplot on a cosmic level- but they remain fulfilling and well-done stories.  Every named character has a tale, and many of them are well-developed and emotional enough to give you an unusual sense of connection to the character.  After a few hours into the story, the game washes its hands of any responsibility it has to give you moral cues, and it pulls no punches with the complexity of the situations you're forced to resolve on a whim.  Lives and fortunes often depend upon a moment's indecision, and entire populations can be decimated due to a loss at rock-paper-scissors.(I did remind you that this was a Divinity game.  How else would you resolve social conflicts?)It might be more helpful to think of Divinity: Original Sin as a complex and interwoven series of events rather than a quest.  Most of the situations throughout the world are resolvable through several vectors, and the whole narrative can shift and adapt as you resolve things 'out of order' or shank a hapless character who caught you pawing through their storeroom.  Plots and schedules in the game world exist with some degree of independance- so when I accidentally set a fishing boat on fire and was forced to slay all of the enraged dockworkers, I cut away the thread which would have led me to the location of the mutineer who'd stolen a valuable artifact... but I came across him later anyway.Speaking of killing, combat in this game is interesting in a way I've seldom seen before.  Proper fights are turn-based, and unbelievably dynamic and well-balanced.  No abilities are lost on the live-time overworld, however, and so encounters can be started after hurling a fireball at an unwitting group, or re-arranging the scenery to form barricades.  Fights are dangerous affairs- the game does not beleive in pulling punches, and being outnumbered is a threat which must be countered with cunning tactics and even emergant changes of planning.  No more dangerous than the world itself, though.  Rivellon is riddled with traps, puzzles and (well) riddles, and a lapse in attention can mean the death of even an over-levelled party.  Death is a serious matter- ressurection scrolls are real, but rare, and even those won't help you if your entire party goes up in flames.  This is a key element of the game; that the things happening on-screen are things you have to pay attention to, lest you walk blithely into the basement of a paranoid trap-maker or idly break a barrel full of oil while an open fire is alight nearby.  Finally, the multiplayer element is excellent.  While (by default, anyway) only two people can play the same game, each one has full control over a character, and frequent opportunities for choices by each player helps to tailor the character to fit both desires.  The game's plot is built with a dual protagonist in mind, and teamwork is absolutely required in even the most routine battles.  Best of all, the game's interconnectivity system allows players to swap items or teleport to the other in a flash, giving each hero freedom to wander the world map while retaining the ability to show up and participate in combat.Are there problems with this game?  Of course, but they're blessedly minor.  The game has a few more bugs than you might expect, and load times between areas are long.  It's also easy to skip side-quests, and some of the more important ones contain puzzles sufficiently obscure to create serious problems for some players- plus, though the game lets you do what you want and ignore what you don't, skipping the wrong side-quests can cause serious problems later on.  Finally, the game's NPCs have a solid reprotoire of relevant and witty dialog... which they will repeat, ad infinitum.  This can quickly come to grate on the senses, and I have legitimately killed NPCs merely to make them shut up.Still, these substantive quibbles are minor.  Divinity: Original Sin, is one of the most solid RPG titles which I've seen in years, and more fun to boot.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Baldur's Gate with a splash of XCOM. Linear and not particularly repeatable, but a good co-op diversion with a dedicated partner.No cover drawn from its XCOM heritage, but tactical combat control and lockdowns are the order of the day. Scoundrels, Men at Arms, and Expert Marksmen are effectively 'mages in armor', with broad spell variety saved for dedicated INT casters, who will have a few skill trees due to less attribute dependence. Spend some time studying the character generation and level up systems, as understanding how tightly you will need to specialize is vital - the game is parsimonious with stat improvements. The tactical combat will pull no punches though the AI can sometimes be baited into foolish mistakes of positioning. Get friendly with your quicksave key, and put a grin on - the combat can be brutal, and a winning contest can go south quickly when new enemy abilities make their first appearance. D:OS won't warn you about what's coming.For mages doing damage, elemental combinations are the order of the day, and being able to apply all of the earth(poison)/fire and water/air(electricity) pairings is useful, but specialize in one pairing. Countering these works as you might imagine - water dries up when heated, fire goes out when rained upon. Be able to counter them all, amongst your group. Poison can be burned off (explosively!). Ice will melt, faster with help. Witchcraft is the INT caster version of Man-at-Arms, with fewer controls, but more ranged debuffs and pet summons - an armored decapitator appearing behind enemy lines is nothing to sneer at. (Nor are the various elementals and animals from the elemental skills, for that matter, but one summon per caster at a time.)The writing is adequate, but not stellar. The first who-dun-it wasn't particularly inspiring, and oftentimes progression has been a matter of "what level are those enemies?" rather than a cohesive sense of direction and progress. The quest journal is next-to-useless for many quests, providing little or no information to follow up. Use markers liberally, and don't be ashamed to augment the game's lacking journalling with some of your own. If you're doing every quest, expect to either miss a few things or need a walkthrough/guide from time to time.The rock-paper-scissors mechanic for the 'persuasion minigame' is by turns novel and tiresome. It's cute the first couple of times you see it, and it's a new way to 'randomize' a mechanic that no one seems to get right (persuasion) but it misses the mark in not having an "autoplay". Frankly, I don't want to play RPS against the computer, or my partner, and if the point is to provide some uncertainty to 'speech checks', that's fine - but I don't care for the minigame much. Fortunately, it's been relatively rare thus far...Character control is relatively straightforward - two players control four characters between them, in any combination. The host controls who gets to run which, allowing one player to AFK while the other plays a combat or to allow a tactical novice to mind only a single character in combat, etc. Wife and I split our characters into two teams of two, and it works out well - I run the NPC warrior Madora (man-at-arms) and shadow cleric (witchcraft/some water/man-at-arms), she handles the mage duties (one in all colleges for access, specializing earth/fire for stronger effects) and the sneaky rogue Wolgraff we recruited.Combat is turn based and is the real meat of the game, with players asked to deploy skills and weapons to defeat foes in a number of varied battlefield conditions. Often, a different approach or tactical plan is the difference between victory and reloading, and fights have been challenging often.All around, an enjoyable game, but remember those roots - the game doesn't pretend to be a more modern RPG, no matter the pretty graphics, so study up on how the level system works. It doesn't pretend to have autopilot combat, either. Bring your tactical thinking to the table....and get ready to read, because this is a long, slow march, not a sprint.Edit:Bugs, however, abound. Often, we notice desync issues when the host reloads the game and player #2's characters appear to have no stats (base scores all reset to 5) and not be wearing their gear, etc. We've not experienced any corruption from these episodes, but save often to avoid screams of hair-rending frustration when player 2 says "My character is bugged. Again." I'm amazed this wasn't caught and corrected, given how prevalent it's been for us!We've seen a couple of minor oddities (one bug involved a repeatedly-exploding poison gas trap that killed a boss in a single round because the poison would detonate, leave a fire puddle, the gas would refill the area, detonate... The boss standing in the cloud never took a combat turn - the explosion cycle took himn from 100% to 0% in one round of chained, buggy explosions (not that I'm complaining).Learn how to temper armor and weapons, learn how to make basic equipment (Madora makes a decent smith) and you can take advantage of movement speed penalty reductions on heavy armor and enhanced basic damage on weapons (for free). Don't play 'hard mode' if you don't have to!If you're into RPGs this one's worth a look, but don't expect all the rough corners to be filed down or a 100% bug-free experience, because they're not and it's not.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin has two very big thumbs up from me.  It's one of the best RPG's I've played in a long, long time. That said, there certainly are a few issues which I'm sure will be remedied over time.  The responsiveness and care that Larian has put into the release and post release of this product is second to none.The freedom that the player has while clumsily wandering throughout the very large and immersive world is unparalleled.  Being able to do whatever I want, whatever I want - good or bad is powerful.  That kind of freedom really allows the player to be a part of the world and really drive where the game goes (or doesn't go).Aside from some intrusive tutorial stuff and some weird UI management - the game is pretty spectacular.  I know I'll be playing it for a while to come and I've already sunk over 90 hours into it.

Early Access Review
								I loved the concept of Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights, but I could never get into that style of gameplay (even though I'm a hardcore KotOR fan). This game does an excellent job of delivering an RPG with elements very much like the classic Bioware titles and mixes in some contemporary features (but just enough to stay true to the old genre). Excellent graphics, witty dialogue (and there's a lot of it, even for it being currently in Beta), smooth combat (a bug here or there as expected), and a smack of nostalgia makes this game fit quite well in the hands of a player who spends far too much time in Elder Scrolls games. You want open-ended story with complex character crafting? Grab this. Grab the two originals as well.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												Okay, so intially I reviewed this game while it was still in beta, and I recommended it wholeheartedly, however, it has since been released in full, so I thought I would update my review to reflect that.This game is, for me, one of the best rpg's of recent times. Larian has always seemed, to me at least, like a studio with great ideas, but limited execution. With Original Sin however, they have absolutely smashed that perception of them. This game is no less than a masterpiece. The story is fairly rich, with deep characters, that have their own motives and personalities. It's also pretty damn funny, with many conversations (and in-game books) having genuine laugh-out-loud moments. The combat is intuitive, and well worked, although there are one or two small bugs with it when playing co-operatively, but nothing game or immersion breaking.The co-op is where this game shines more than most. It is simple, old fashioned, damn good fun. Co-op combat is great, with each player able to feel an important part of the battle, and using abilities to destroy your enemies together is great fun, for example; one player creates a pool of oil beneath your foe, the other then lights it on fire, or perhaps one player teleports an enemy up into the air, before slamming them down into the ground... right in front of your ally, and their massive sword. It rocks, on every level.So, long story short, if you like rpg's that inherit much from baldur's gate and neverwinter, like your games to be fun and funny in equal measure, enjoy co-op or just enjoy beating things in the head, this is a fantastic game. If you don't like any of those things, then this review probably isn't for you, because anyone that hipster would never do anything so mainstream as to read a review.Buy it if you like things.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Not having played this game for very long. I am writing an early review of what I think of this game so far. I do recommend this game, although I will talk about both what I find good and bad.Divinity: Original Sin has a turn-based combat system. I find this combat style was very well done. It is difficult to choose the wrong place to attack if you are paying attention, and it takes strategy to get through the battles. They certainly are not battles that you want to rush into. However, there is certainly a lot of difficulty early on in Divinity: Original Sin. I currently am Level 3 and Level 3 creatures are very difficult for me. I do rely on my cleric and healing potions a lot to get through them, and even then a party member dies usually. So it is not a game for a casual player who wants to feel above the opposition. Although it is fun, and makes me think I should be more tactical before I turn a corner, and check for enemies.One issue I have is that quests rely heavily on what is in the dialogue between the characters, because the Journal you have does not depict location well at all and there are no markers. An example is searching for a Church of Legionnaires, and I do not know where this Church is and the Journal does not tell me where to go. It gets very confusing with the amount of dialogue you do before you get around to doing the quests.Although, the amazing variety of things to do is awesome. If you explore the first city enough, you manage to find qhat seems to be a second main questline that over-arcs everything. On the surfac, it seems like a lot of fun. A very confusing puzzle to piece togetehr as I play and go through this murder-mystery / source-hunting main quest line. Exploring more into the first main questline also opens up the door to more allies to add to your pack, something that becomes very useful early on due to the difficulty of battles.Divinity: Original Sin after only a few hours seems like such an amazing game. The story is intriguing and catches your interest, and the amount of stories raveled together layered as such makes me want to pour more of my time into it. The combat is fluent and makes you think and act slowly to survive, and when you do level-up it really feels like you have accomplished something.I highly recommend this game if you think you can handle the difficulty and amount of dialogue.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is an incredibly fun hardcore RPG. It is nothing like Diablo or Torchlight; if anything, it's more like Wasteland 2 (or 1) or the original Fallout 1 (or 2). It's best played with a friend. Please note that to create a co-op game, one player has to make a game with both players' characters. You don't just create a character and join your friend. You join your friend's game and take control of one of the characters (2-4, there are 2 main characters they create and you can recruit up to 2 other characters in the game, but personally I think the Lone Wolf perk is much better than another character). The game is absolutely MASSIVE. The first area in the game is a pretty big place with a surrounding area, and there's a place with LOTS of portals you activate later.Here are some tips to new players:- Steal every painting or gold ______ (such as Light Gold Cup) in the game! You can sell them for a lot, although this does make the money system rather unbalanced.- Make sure to have characters that can do more than one thing! For example, a rogue-type character is great but knives mainly do piercing damage, which does very little to undead monsters, and there are a lot of those!- Mages (Wizards, particularly) can be so useful, I'd almost call them overpowered. If you're going to be a mage, be sure to put points into every magic type (Aerothurge, Pyromancy, etc.); the more the better!- When you're making a character, absolutely look at every aspect of it! If you don't like the perks or the spells you start with, change them!- Last but not least, there are some Smelly Panties at the top of Esmeralda's house. They give Charisma +1.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												Divinity: Original Sin is one of the best games I've played in a long time!As of writing, I'm almost 30 hours in, level 5 and just about ventured outside of the first city. There is a plethora of things to do and multitudes of people to talk to. In most games talking to people is boring and more of a chore than an enjoyment. However in this game I'm looking forward to the next dialogue and to see what people have to say, and to see how they react to my crazy decisions.I've read a couple of "guides" online, such as this is how you should play and this build is optimal. Bah! I'm having my own way and the game lets me do just that. I'm facing 9 same level monsters at once... died about 7 times before I got through it, but I learned that zombies heal from poison (and splash poison when you hit them!), but they freeze easily, especially when wet. But freezing everything makes the ground slippery and my guys keep tripping over it, so I melted the poison-ice mix with fire... and it exploded! Now everything is burning. Lets calm down and cast some rain. No more fire or ice, just lots of water, but my weapon has electricity! If I hit something, I stun my whole group, and the poison heals the zombies, but kills me.... I need a new tactic, lets try this again! Maybe oil will work?The combat is good, the dialogue is good, graphics are good and music is awesome! The quests are interesting with good twists and this is definitely more of an open sandbox than a linear game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												I'm going to write this in the hopes that it persuades one of my buddies to buy it and play it with me, because this game would be an absolute blast in Cooperative mode.This is easily the best RPG that I've played in the last several years. It boasts a classic, orthographic RPG style with turn-based combat, and does it damn well. The game is very daunting at first due to its sheer depth. It doesn't hold your hand every step of the way. There are almost no actual quest markers, unlike in modern RPGs like Skyrim where you get a quest marker for every little thing. You have to read dialog and pay attention to details in order to know where to go and what to do. Quests are actually engaging, and battles take real strategizing and planning to win. The game has a much slower pace, but big battles can get pretty hectic, even though they're turn based.Character customization has tons of depth. You create TWO main characters at the start of a new game, and it even allows you to modify their base stats and perks to your liking. Unlike in many other games, classes do not ultimately define your characters. They simply determine what gear and abilities they start with. Obviously this wouldn't be the first game to do that, but I think it's a great system nonetheless.The inventory system is a lot like Diablo's, except the inventory space is only limited to a character's carry weight capacity, which can be increased via stat leveling. And since each member of your party has their own inventory, you can stock up on butt loads of loot. Buying/selling is more like bartering. You don't just go up to any random vendor and sell all your loot for tons of gold. Vendors actually have a finite amount of gold they can spend. However, you can trade any of your loot for an item provided you have enough to match the gold value of the item you're trying to acquire. In other words, you don't just farm gold like in Diablo.And now for the meaty part: combat. A lot of people will probably think of the older Final Fantasy games when they hear "turn based." Rather than transition from the game world to a setpiece for a battle, a grid of tiles appears right where you encounter your enemy, and you fight within that. Trying to exit the grid means fleeing from battle. Each character has a pool of action points (AP) that they consume per turn. Moving between tiles uses up points, and a higher encumberance means a higher AP cost for moving. Obviously, using abilities or basic attacks costs points too. They slowly regenerate per-turn, so having a party member hold for a turn will save points to allow them to use stronger abilities later on. There are stats and items that can increase the total points a character has, and the number regenerated per-turn. Once you are finished commanding your party, you end your turn, and the enemy proceeds with their strategy.The combat itself is astoundingly complex. Positioning is always important. Archers are more likely to miss the further they are from their target. Large enough obstructions will even prevent arrows and projectile spells from reaching their target. There are also tons of environmental elements that can either be your greatest ally or your worst enemy. Enemy AI WILL take advantage of it when you least expect it. If it's raining, characters will become wet, which makes them more susceptible to lightning and frost spells. There are other things like poison clouds which will ignite from flames (and, obviously, poison anyone who enters), and patches of ice that can cause characters who tread upon them to slip and fall, rendering them useless for a couple of turns. And there's plenty more. All of this complexity means that every battle you fight feels unique and engaging.The story isn't anything original, but it's written well regardless. There's plenty of whitty humor, and the small amount of voice acting in the game is done superbly. Basically, it's an easy-to-love classic fantasy story. Larian Studios was not worried about creating centuries of lore for a bunch of different races and religions and countries. The world of Divinity is simply perceived as, well, "the world." That doesn't mean there's a total lack of lore. There's just enough to give the story a framework so things make sense and things feel "real." But you still get a sense of epicness from the narrative. They focus on discovering the lost pasts of your characters, which keeps you invested since you basically CREATED your characters at the start.Anyway, do I recommend this game? Absolutely. I won't give a X/10 rating since I think ratings are a joke. Hopefully my review is enough to give you an idea of how freakin' awesome I think this game is.Now will one of my friends BUY THIS GAME SO THEY CAN PLAY IT WITH ME?!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is a great game with a few issues.  Even with my negative points below I still recommend it for people who like RPG+Turn based battles, if you liked games like Baldur’s Gate series then you will likely enjoy this game.Good:+Great Graphics.+Moody atmosphere for dungeons.+Talk/trade with almost every neutral NPC.+Developers are listening to players and updates/patches are coming out frequently.Not so Good:-Inventory management is clunky.  Yes you can use "Send to Homestead" but I would love to see an option to access it from anywhere as well as quick transfer, say CTRL+left click to transfer to Homestead.  -Enemy visual range is so large that often you’re in battle before you can even see them.  Once in battle you often have to move the map around just to spot the enemy, since they are so spread out.-Quest tracking.  I know this was their intent but the lack of any visual clues and limited suggestions in quest log can make questing painful and slow.  I’ve spend a large amount of my time running between people in town asking the same questions and hoping for a different answer or quest update.  If there were better visual clues (pointer) or more details in quest log on what is expected next I wouldn’t feel some much like I’m wasting time running around.-Movement speed, I know this is subjective but for me I feel like the characters move too slowly even at max speed.-So far with my limited play it seems like the enemy count is too low on the maps, i.e. only one or two groups of enemies per map area.

												I've donated to a good number of crowdfunded/early access titles over the past year and Divinity: Original Sin is the first one of them that has officially launched and I just gotta say that they have set the bar extremely high (Hot Damn have they evah!) as far as this development trend goes. Their alpha was impressively polished a few months ago and it just got better as the days went on. Larian was so on point, it was sick (in the good way! :P). Now playing the official release is just pure joy.  I'm right back where I was in the 90s playing so many of the amazing cRPG titles that were so much fun and D:OS has brought that all back and then some.  Crowdfunding/EA has allowed Larian to make the game they always wanted to make with total creative freedom and it shows, ohmgosh does it show.Sure there have been some hiccups since launch with issues but there has also been a steady stream of updates as Larian listens to all the feedback and fixes the issues as they pop up.The modding toolkit is ready as well and just waiting for Valve to flip the switch so there is a whole lot more of the goodness to be had from talented modders out there. I am so stoked!

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game is everything I love about video games. It's extremely engaging and a game that is enjoyed best with friends. You will start strategizing, planning out, and manuvering about how to make the best of a situation. You have complete freedom to do whatever it is you want, and your actions actually matter.The writing is as strong as the gameplay. Since the actions you take have real impactful outcomes, you will pay attention to what people are saying, which makes you really focused on the awesome quests there are. This game doesn't dumb anything down. It expects a lot of you. It's challenging, but never impossible. Being able to make the environment a strategic part of a fight feels natural and fun, and you will miss the combat system once you play other RPGs. You will want more, you will want to know what happens to the NPCs, you will want to defeat that boss, you will want to play this game all the time. Enjoy it while it's fresh. Take your time. Personally, it's my GoTY. There's no shame in recreating your characther after a while. I've restarted countless times, and I experience the game differently each time. It's the best game I've played. I wouldn't think twice about reccommending it to anyone who loves strategy and classic-style RPGs. Or anyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Though I'm only 18 hours in as of this point, I must say it is the best cRpg I've played... It might not mean much seeing as I've only played baldur's gate 2 and drakensang before this, but this game should set an example to all future RPG games. The interactivity is amazing, if it's not the ground/a building you can interact with it, and in many ways. Even things that would be trivial in other games like crates and barrels, load up your inventory with them, go into combat, and make a maze while you're in combat, or sneaking around and dropping them off while you scurry back a safe distance to initiate.Another thing that stands out is that EVERY stat/talent/ability matters, and you should have each member be varied in what they're expertised in so that you have someone for every situation. Perception lets you spot secrets/traps/switches, and is even needed for discovering things in the main story to continue so it's not just a trivial stat that you can reload every time you step on a trap, Having a character with leadership grants a boost to your whole parties initiative, damage, precision and so forth. Having a loremaster lets you identify items, enemies, and objects... and so on.The crafting system is pretty nice too, generally if you think two items should combine they generally do. For example, a branch + nine inch nails would make a spiked club, though if things don't combine you may need a higher crafting level :P.There's absolutely NO hand holding, past a few tutorial popups which just tell you the basics, When you're initiating a quest, you're expected to read through and actually find this location without any help markers, no ignoring the story you must read some of the finer details. The things I've listed above are only what's on the surface, It's a very deep and detailed game, and compared to modern rpgs, a godsend. I wholly recommend this to anyone who is interested in classic rpgs, and even modern rpg fans (though the difficulty may be a bit much for a casual ;), there is an easy setting... I haven't tried it though, I hear it's much easier than default though.)
