content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												As someone who is relatively new to turn-based RPGs, I was hesistant to play this game. The art style is incredible and completely suits the soundtrack accompaniment. Many NPCs unnecessarily have dialogue, especially market vendors, which began to infuriate me to the point that I wanted to throw my speakers at the person who bought me this game. I found the gameplay progressed a little too slowly for my liking and although it was good in some aspects that there was limited handholding, I would have appreciated a little bit of direction in the beginning. The turn-based combat was fun, albeit a little tough to get used to (but as I said I am new to this game style). I did find it annoying that the characters always took the most dangerous path during combat usually walking through fire or acid. The Co-Op idea is great in theory, not so great in initial practice. I was under the impression it was a drop in/out Co-Op and this is definitely not the case. If you were not the initial host but want to play some more of the game, too bad you get to start all over again, or wait to play with your friend again. Also, if you want to have a specific main character you better get the host to create it how you want otherwise you are stuck with whatever they create. Trying to get a Co-Op game going took me and my playmate over an hour to sort out. 7.5/10 - The Co-Op initial setup soured me on this game so much that my care factor about the story is severely limited. I will keep on playing it, but would be more inclined to replay Diablo 3 over this at this stage.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												TL;DR: Fantastic, as long as you don't mind the slow progression pace.Divinity: Original Sin has become one of my new favorites. Starting with the simple, it's a turn-based "tactical" RPG. You can control up to a party of 4, and you cycle through your characters in an order based on their (and their enemies') initiative stat. In combat, you fire off spells and hack away at enemies in this turn-based fashion. It may sound dull to some, but every choice counts in a battle, especially if you are facing a boss or a group that is a higher level than you are. If you play any other RPG. you would probably not think twice about taking on a level 6 enemy when you're level 5, it would just take a bit longer, right? In DIvinity, although it is possible with the right strategy, taking on a group that is one level higher than yours can result in your enemies to steamroll over your group. It can be quite hard, especially before you get a hang of the combat system.The combat is very satisfying; it looks good, sounds good, and your characters deal a significant amount of damage whenever you get an attack off. The difficulty doesn't come from the enemies being arrow-sponges, it comes from your own mistakes. While shooting a fire arrow into a oil surface sounds great at first, you soon realize that your archers and mages cannot see through the smoke, forcing you to wait for the black clouds to disperse. I've personally accidentally gotten many party members killed by shooting a fire arrow into a barrel, only to have them be killed in the resulting explosions from a gas cloud that emerged from the barrel. There are many fun and unique ways to die, as well as kill enemies. Some fights can be over before your close-quarters guys can even reach the enemies, just by taking advantage of different material surfaces (Oil, water, gas, etc.).When you're out of combat, you're probably running around trying to solve a puzzle or interrogate someone for clues, which is all fairly enjoyable. The writing is brilliant, and pulls me right into the universe. Fortunetely, the game doesn't take itself too seriously, and will crack a joke every now and then. Sometimes the main characters will poke fun at ech other, or you'll read a silly book. The crafting system is deviously simple, and many recipies can be solved just by thinking about them for a bit. How do you make pizza sauce? Smash a tomato.My only observation about the game that could turn some people away from the game is the exteremely slow progression. I've put about 30 hours into one party at the time of this review, and they are all level 9. Compared to other RPG's, Divinity runs at a snail's pace. It doesn't bother me though. As a result of the leveling being so slow, you have to seriously consider how to allocate your skill points, instead of just throwing them in whatever sounds the best at first glance. Do I want to talk to animals, or be able to heal when I stand in blood? Do I want to be able to cast fireballs, or wield that awesome crossbow I found? You get the idea.Overall, this is easily my GOTY 2014. If you are a fan of turn-based combat and RPG's, I would highly recommend this game. Even if you aren't so keen on turn-based, the Divinity system feels oddly...Satisfying, and might just change your mind.If you're ready for an adventure, I couldn't think of a better choice.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a gleaming reminder of what made me fall in love with RPG's over a dozen years ago. Like Fallout, Planescape and Baulder's Gate before it, it boasts a great combat system, charming characters, memorable music and a living, breathing world to adventure in. There are a few modern improvements though, like more physics-based interactions with the environment and a good amount of depth in character creation and development. My only complaints would be that in its current (beta) form, some of the animations are a bit clunky and fully voiced dialogue is extremely sparse. Those issues are soon forgotten, as the game does an excellent job of immersing you in its world. NPCs will talk to eachother often, and the game finds a great balance between witty humor and interesting banter. Your party members will speak up and comment on things, giving them life and value. Player choice affects not only the story, but how your own party members view you. Early in the game, I found myself delving in dungeons that I could have easily skipped, stealing items from a shop while using a party member to distract them, and killing people that didn't need to die just because they were rude to me. It's those kind of things that pull you in and keep you up late at night.If you like Diablo, Elder Scrolls and classics like Fallout, you will almost certainly like this game. And the fact that a game this deep has online co-op is fantastic. I could go on and on, but I've just scratched the surface and the game is calling me back. Can't wait for the full version!

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												How this handles battles, compared to other games.Other games:-Hit them a few times, maybe use a couple spells. You're stronger than them.This game:-Drop oil around an enemy-Set the oil on fire, causing an explosion-Fire a poison dart, causing another explosion-Have your partner leave the battle, then sneak back in to backstab the enemy(s)-Summon a spider to tank damage-Teleport other enemies on to the already burning oil-Shoot the nearby water barrel to weaken the fire enemy-Kill the final enemy, the fire one, with your spider.Then, throw in some incredible sidequests, such as a murder investigation with multiple paths and false leads, and achievements, great voice acting and a sense of humour, and what do you get?Divinity: Original Sin

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is CRPG done right: non-linear questing, meaningful character development, deep turn based tactical combat, a consistently interactive world, cool loot, crafting, lore, humour, etc. I cannot thank the developers enough for the commitment they had to bringing a quality modern-day successor to old-school crpgs. The game literally feels like it combined the best and most complex systems of older rpgs, and then upgraded them while adding a few original twists to them. It has the tactical combat of something like the temple of elemental evil (perhaps a bit more streamlined, but superior in depth and challenge), the interactive world of something like fallout 1 or 2 (but again, with much better implemented and more varied systems), the lore and scope of the likes of baldur's gate 2, and more than a few new ideas of its own to keep things interesting. And most importantly, everything ties in well together to form a coherent, consistent sand box of rpg experimentation. Be warned however! This game requires an insane commitment of time and attention. There are so many things to micromanage. But that is exactly what I love about it. It is not a simple matter of grinding until your numbers are high enough. It rewards patience, exploration, experimentation and careful decision making. It is entirely possible to screw yourself over completely in this game... which again, makes for an awesome role playing experience. Progress does not come swiftly or at a steady pace. There may long stretches of time when you are just trying to figure out the best way to outfit your characters. You might spend an hour navigating a house full of traps and figuring out how to get all of the loot without blowing yourself up. You might spend some time learning recipes and crafting items. You might be reloading the same battle 5-10 times. There are literally endless possibilities of both emergent and prescripted gameplay...I can only hope that Larian studios, as well as other developers, get the message and start making more games like these.

content:

												You know those games where it feels like the devs took time to make sure even the little aspects of the games had significant time spent on them? This is one of those games.One common flaw in turn based tactical games is the combat is just not tactical enough. D:OS does an amazing job with their skill system combined with the environmental dangers on the battlefield. I found I wasn't doing well until I was utilizing the environment in almost every battle, and it is awesome.Co-op games are so easy to set up! I had 0 issues getting my friend in my game and its fast every game. If I had one issue with the game it comes in this category though. Conversations started by one person are difficult and sometimes not observable by the other player. I want to see that amazing story too!Are there bugs? Yes, but nothing gamebreaking and not many considering it just released. The one bug I kept encountering they fixed in one of their 4 small patches in 4 days anyways. I love knowing the devs won't wait forever to patch this game.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												As someone who is relatively new to turn-based RPGs, I was hesistant to play this game. The art style is incredible and completely suits the soundtrack accompaniment. Many NPCs unnecessarily have dialogue, especially market vendors, which began to infuriate me to the point that I wanted to throw my speakers at the person who bought me this game. I found the gameplay progressed a little too slowly for my liking and although it was good in some aspects that there was limited handholding, I would have appreciated a little bit of direction in the beginning. The turn-based combat was fun, albeit a little tough to get used to (but as I said I am new to this game style). I did find it annoying that the characters always took the most dangerous path during combat usually walking through fire or acid. The Co-Op idea is great in theory, not so great in initial practice. I was under the impression it was a drop in/out Co-Op and this is definitely not the case. If you were not the initial host but want to play some more of the game, too bad you get to start all over again, or wait to play with your friend again. Also, if you want to have a specific main character you better get the host to create it how you want otherwise you are stuck with whatever they create. Trying to get a Co-Op game going took me and my playmate over an hour to sort out. 7.5/10 - The Co-Op initial setup soured me on this game so much that my care factor about the story is severely limited. I will keep on playing it, but would be more inclined to replay Diablo 3 over this at this stage.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												TL;DR: Fantastic, as long as you don't mind the slow progression pace.Divinity: Original Sin has become one of my new favorites. Starting with the simple, it's a turn-based "tactical" RPG. You can control up to a party of 4, and you cycle through your characters in an order based on their (and their enemies') initiative stat. In combat, you fire off spells and hack away at enemies in this turn-based fashion. It may sound dull to some, but every choice counts in a battle, especially if you are facing a boss or a group that is a higher level than you are. If you play any other RPG. you would probably not think twice about taking on a level 6 enemy when you're level 5, it would just take a bit longer, right? In DIvinity, although it is possible with the right strategy, taking on a group that is one level higher than yours can result in your enemies to steamroll over your group. It can be quite hard, especially before you get a hang of the combat system.The combat is very satisfying; it looks good, sounds good, and your characters deal a significant amount of damage whenever you get an attack off. The difficulty doesn't come from the enemies being arrow-sponges, it comes from your own mistakes. While shooting a fire arrow into a oil surface sounds great at first, you soon realize that your archers and mages cannot see through the smoke, forcing you to wait for the black clouds to disperse. I've personally accidentally gotten many party members killed by shooting a fire arrow into a barrel, only to have them be killed in the resulting explosions from a gas cloud that emerged from the barrel. There are many fun and unique ways to die, as well as kill enemies. Some fights can be over before your close-quarters guys can even reach the enemies, just by taking advantage of different material surfaces (Oil, water, gas, etc.).When you're out of combat, you're probably running around trying to solve a puzzle or interrogate someone for clues, which is all fairly enjoyable. The writing is brilliant, and pulls me right into the universe. Fortunetely, the game doesn't take itself too seriously, and will crack a joke every now and then. Sometimes the main characters will poke fun at ech other, or you'll read a silly book. The crafting system is deviously simple, and many recipies can be solved just by thinking about them for a bit. How do you make pizza sauce? Smash a tomato.My only observation about the game that could turn some people away from the game is the exteremely slow progression. I've put about 30 hours into one party at the time of this review, and they are all level 9. Compared to other RPG's, Divinity runs at a snail's pace. It doesn't bother me though. As a result of the leveling being so slow, you have to seriously consider how to allocate your skill points, instead of just throwing them in whatever sounds the best at first glance. Do I want to talk to animals, or be able to heal when I stand in blood? Do I want to be able to cast fireballs, or wield that awesome crossbow I found? You get the idea.Overall, this is easily my GOTY 2014. If you are a fan of turn-based combat and RPG's, I would highly recommend this game. Even if you aren't so keen on turn-based, the Divinity system feels oddly...Satisfying, and might just change your mind.If you're ready for an adventure, I couldn't think of a better choice.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												A pretty amazing achievement as far as RPGs go, and games in general. It definitely harkens back to the Ultima series and Baldur's Gate in terms of story, depth and interactivity. I like that it doesn't hold your hand, yet is still pretty accessible. The amount of interactivity is staggering. The graphics are gorgeous and rich, and the gameplay is a lot of fun. The combat is challenging - you will get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked if you aren't carerful, but it is fun and very strategic. Being able to use certain elements to your advantage (lighting oil on fire underneath a monster or electrocuting them in water) adds another layer to your strategy. I've barely scratched the surface on this game, but I'm incredibly impressed and very happy I purchased it. It's a masterpiece, and will go down as one of the greatest computer RPGs ever made. It is in very good company.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is CRPG done right: non-linear questing, meaningful character development, deep turn based tactical combat, a consistently interactive world, cool loot, crafting, lore, humour, etc. I cannot thank the developers enough for the commitment they had to bringing a quality modern-day successor to old-school crpgs. The game literally feels like it combined the best and most complex systems of older rpgs, and then upgraded them while adding a few original twists to them. It has the tactical combat of something like the temple of elemental evil (perhaps a bit more streamlined, but superior in depth and challenge), the interactive world of something like fallout 1 or 2 (but again, with much better implemented and more varied systems), the lore and scope of the likes of baldur's gate 2, and more than a few new ideas of its own to keep things interesting. And most importantly, everything ties in well together to form a coherent, consistent sand box of rpg experimentation. Be warned however! This game requires an insane commitment of time and attention. There are so many things to micromanage. But that is exactly what I love about it. It is not a simple matter of grinding until your numbers are high enough. It rewards patience, exploration, experimentation and careful decision making. It is entirely possible to screw yourself over completely in this game... which again, makes for an awesome role playing experience. Progress does not come swiftly or at a steady pace. There may long stretches of time when you are just trying to figure out the best way to outfit your characters. You might spend an hour navigating a house full of traps and figuring out how to get all of the loot without blowing yourself up. You might spend some time learning recipes and crafting items. You might be reloading the same battle 5-10 times. There are literally endless possibilities of both emergent and prescripted gameplay...I can only hope that Larian studios, as well as other developers, get the message and start making more games like these.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												This is my first review on Steam, although I have written reviews on other services, but given that I will merely enumerate a few high-level points given there are probably a hundred better reviews already.1) Combat is difficult on Normal, but with some thought and experience you can win, and win in style.  Be patient, save right before each fight so that you can reload if you make a tactical mistake.  Winning a battle in D:OS gives you a real sense of satisfaction.2) Gold is difficult to come by early on if you do not steal.  I am not a thief therefore I had to scrimp and save to obtain gold early on.  That extra scroll, potion, armor, etc. can be key in the combat so make that early gold count.3) I tend to be thrifty with single-use items like scrolls, health potions, etc. but again, to win a close battle and not lose any of your team members you may need to sacrifice going for damage and burn action points to quaff that potion.The game is very in-depth, a good challenge, with nice graphics, humorous moments, and a nice mix of quests (I am only up to the Silverglen area so I cannot speak to the entirety of the game at this time.)  The game world is large, and is an "open world" but the level of the enemies encountered make it linear to a degree in reality as you simply will not survive the fights if you veer too far off the path.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												You can explore dungeons, wilderness, urban, fight monsters & NPCS (turn-based,) roleplay with PCs/NPCs, and solve traps, tricks, & puzzles. You participate in a "story" through quests in this fantasy RPG world. What makes this game unique-- Compelling array of magical spells that can be cast tactically during combat so as to combine with each other, and create effects and injure opoonents. For example, casting an oil slick to slow an target, then igniting it and the target with a fire spell. Alternatively, chilling an opponent and then freezing it. The possiblities are large. An engaging wilderness environment. Combat that is amazingly balanced, almost perfectly to the character levels. Combat that is intense, interesting, and challenging. Beautiful graphics. A reward systems of skills, talents, etc that allow you to customise the character uniquely. A well-paced game that is neither dull nor hugely exciting but then you suffer a large period of boredom -- no, the game is consistently paced.This game can be addictive it is that good.Each of these good points may not seem special, but when you combineall of them together you get Divinity Original Sin (I know it sounds corny but it's true).This is one of the greatest games of the last 15 years. Of course, benefits continue: you have multi-player; you can select a certain "class" but ultimately create whatever you want, literally anything, within the bounds of traits, talents, ability scores, etc; which gives you huge scope to customise characters from the start and throughout the game. You create and control more than one character at a time.Buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is a throwback to what Action RPGs used to be.  When I was a young adult back in the late 90s early 2000s we had games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment, and Nox.  These games, while real-time based (technically based on DND rules), flowed well and the envrionment was at your disposal.  Divinity should not be compared to any of these games as the gameplay itself may be similar but some of the major elements are still missing.  Divinity is a turn based action RPG based in the Divinity world.  You don't need any former knowledge of the series but you will see some appearances and references to other games.  The world is, in my opinion, a medium sized world that captures your attention and makes it feel much larger due to several factors.  First, everything is usable or can be modified from one state to another.  Some of this comes into play during combat.  In fact, some battles that could not normally be won until a later level can be won earlier if you play your battle correctly.  Oil barrels that explode upon getting hit by a fireball, poison barrels that lay poison onto the ground which can be ignited by fire, and water that can be electrically charged, stunning everything in its area.  These are all aspects of a battle that can be turned against you or the enemy, don't forget, blood conducts electric too, so that blood puddle isn't something you want to stand in if a mage is slamming bolts everywhere!The one thing that really intrigues me as well as adds points to the game is the difficulty.  This game, as said before, is a throwback to the old school games of the early part of last decade.  There are no quest markers or hand holding.  You need to figure things out for yourself and this could be a turn off to the new generation of gamers.  Please don't take this as an insult but most newer games step you through the entire game, Divinity does no such thing.  The map is useful for markers that you can place, town areas of interest, secret boxes marked on your map, and waypoints.  With no handholding you are left to fend for yourself, this often entails you wandering for a few minutes until you get your bearings.  Walls of text that can get in the way and have no meaning to the current quest line can get annoying but are there to help you immerse yourself.  Quests can often go either way, kill the troll or let him live.  Sometimes you find friends in the strangest areas, so before you go blasting into combat make sure that the skeleton you get your eyes on isn't a friendly.That brings me to the combat which is extremely well designed.  Everything is turn based meaning that each character goes and does what he/she does for their turn and then it is the next characters turn, friend or foe.  Action points make up your characters ability set and define how many things they can do in a given turn.  Walking, attacking, casting most spells, and drinking potions all consume action points.  The good news is, if you want, you can save up your action points to a certain amount and unload three, four, or even five attacks in one turn.  This adds an element to the combat that makes it strategic.  Some spells cost so much that you need to wait one turn to even cast them while other spells have a cooldown regardless of how many action points you have stored up.  As you level your characters you quickly learn how to lose professionally.  Enemies two levels above you can completely pulverize your party unless you got a trick up your sleeve.  However, the level difference begins to get a little easier as you get more powerful.  Character creation is somewhat of a detailed job that you can easily spend an hour getting right.  The classes presented to you are merely templates as you can modify them to be anything.  Want a geomancer with pyromancing abilities? Go for it.  Want a mage that can wear heavy armor and cast spells?  Sure, go for it.  You do end up sacrificing some things over others as going the latter route will undoubtly have you suffering in one aspect or the other eventually but it is still a viable jack of all trades class.  I am a personal fan of the Red Mage play style so when I can get a party to have a red mage I do it.  On a final note on character creation, you have to create two as the story line does entail two protagonists, so your other two party members will be whomever you choose as you go throughout the game.As far as the graphics go, the game is good enough.  Nothing stellar but it was never designed in that fashion.  The music rocks and the voice overs are nice.  The game can run on high end systems with no issues and even on middle and low end systems fluidly.Now with every review comes a few of the bad things.  First I would like to point out that you need to read the manual.  This isn't a flaw or a bad thing for me but again, the newer generation wants everything done for them as games are designed in this fashion.  Another flaw is that sometimes you intend to attack an enemy via melee but your character moves around them instead.  I have had this happen a few times and it gets irritating to say the least.  I haven't lost a battle because of this but it drags out some battles an extra turn when it could have been over earlier.  My other complain is the walls of text I referred to earlier.  Sometimes you end up reading a page out of a book from one conversation before the point is made.  While this adds depth, doing this to often gets tiresome, especially when you are eager to go out and whoop some butt.  Overall, Divinity: Original Sin does the old days justice.  It captures what made games so good back then and then amplifies it to another level.  I was really hoping for an open world in which I could go anywhere and do anything.  While you can do as you wish, some areas are just way to powerful for you and you get spanked.  The story has a set path that you will be at certain points at certain levels, give or take one or two.  I don't think this is bad but enemies don't respawn so other than retracing steps to get some older quest complete or a secret dug up, there is little reason to go back to old areas of the map already explored.Points Breakdown:Combat and Controls:9/10* The moving instead of attacking bug/glitch gets annoying so I took a point away here.Graphics:7/10* Nothing Stellar but still good none the less.Sound:9/10*Fantastic Sound track and decent voice acting.Difficulty:9/10*Set it to easy, normal, or hard.  No hand holding!Story:9/10*Well designed from the start.  You begin not knowing much other than that you are a source hunter.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Long have I searched for an RPG that captures the nostalgic feelings of Baldur's Gate that innovates and improves with modern technology and game design. My search has ended.Divinity: Original Sin provides a compelling atmosphere with a lengthy list of party customization that allows you to build an effective party based on your own, personal whims. Want a caster who can also get up in to melee range and go to town? Done. Want a ranger that casts spells alongside her arrows? Done. All you need to do is learn some of the basics and figure out what abilities will complement one another and you're good to go.On that note: This game is not (typically) easy. Be prepared to save and load games frequently! The tides of battle can and often are easily decided on your tactical decisions, and sometimes incapacitating an enemy at a crucial moment really does mean all the difference.The game also allows you to build two very different characters in terms of personality. Your characters can have conversations with one another and your choices during these conversations will help shape how that character is at their core. If all that wasn't enough to interest you, then I'd suggest looking to the company themselves. They have a very clear understanding about what makes this kind of game enjoyable, and their commitment to go from KickStarter to launch proves they are willing to support this project going forward.TL;DR: If you enjoy tactical based RPG games such as old school Baldur's Gate then you'll probably really enjoy Divinity: Original Sin. If you want a game you can just blast through without much thought, you may be disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												I'll start with my summary: Yes, buy the game, it is a great, "old school" RPG with tons of text and little hand holding, and it's refreshing. Forget the other Divinity titles, not having them or having them is irrelevant (or, if you're a pachyderm, irrelephant.)I'll continue with my experience: I have very little other than character creation and the initial city you start in, because NO MATTER what character class combo I come up with (you have two primary characters, and can get two more before leaving the city to begin the brunt of the game) as soon as I head out- in any direction- and encounter enemies... I get party wiped.I have seen NONE of the game, because I simply don't know what I'm doing wrong. The game relies on environmental damaging and elemental attacks a lot- for instance, casting lightning or shooting a lightning arrow into a pool of water enemies are in stuns them. Great mechanic.The problem I've encountered at the start, that has prevented me from moving past the start of the game, is your turns in combat are limited to action points. Your few moves for your characters take most- or more than- those action points. Then those skills have cool downs. That means, my warrior smashes into a pack of two undead, and does decent damage to both. One gets knocked down, the other doesn't. My ranger hits four undead with a ricochet arrow. Great start to the fight. Then it's their turn. The undead next to my warrior hits him three times in the same turn for 26-35 damage each hit. Two undead archers thunk him for a shot each, and he'll either be at about 5 hps, or dead.  My other two characters may kill one more undead, or simply damage a few, but don't help much.Next turn, I *must* use a character to either heal or ressurrect the warrior. This ends that characters turn, and the warrior is revived with only a percent of health- so you have to revive him away from combat (the spell allows you to teleport them back to life in a radius). That means two characters can fight that second round. One swings at an undead, misses. Swings again, hits, its still alive. The other casts a spell that burns another twice, but doesn't kill it. Next turn, the undead archers move up, thwap my warrior dead again with arrows, nearly kill two of the other characters, and the other undead charge forward and poison them, knock them down, etc. EVEN if I live, I have to spend the entire next turn drinking a health potion or casting a ressurect spell. Every fight I've been in so far (beyond the tutorial) ends up with my characters downing health potions or casting healing spells for their turns, then getting beat on again and repeating, until I lose. I've tried not healing, but that only gets them killed a turn earlier. It has been frustrating and surprising, given how easy most games are nowadays.So, oddly enough, I like the game- it's got great visuals, it reeks of old school Baldur's Gate style gameplay, and I've read up a ton on other people's experiences, and it is indeed deep and full of exploration. I, sadly, haven't - and can't - experience it yet. I don't know what I'm doing wrong, I've tried everything, but to start, once leaving the city, the game can be utterly brutal. I've never "rage quit" a game before this one, but I simply have put it on the back burner until I can try again someday and try something I haven't before (whatever that might be, I've tried it all. Yes- what you're thinking of suggesting? I've tried it. Yes, with a llama. And the duck.) Still, I will return- it strikes me as that good of a game. I would suggest purchasing it. You will probably not struggle like I have- others have moved on, apparently it's simply my own malfunction with this game. It's like my nemesis, and I will one day prevail.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												How this handles battles, compared to other games.Other games:-Hit them a few times, maybe use a couple spells. You're stronger than them.This game:-Drop oil around an enemy-Set the oil on fire, causing an explosion-Fire a poison dart, causing another explosion-Have your partner leave the battle, then sneak back in to backstab the enemy(s)-Summon a spider to tank damage-Teleport other enemies on to the already burning oil-Shoot the nearby water barrel to weaken the fire enemy-Kill the final enemy, the fire one, with your spider.Then, throw in some incredible sidequests, such as a murder investigation with multiple paths and false leads, and achievements, great voice acting and a sense of humour, and what do you get?Divinity: Original Sin

But so far I feel this has alot of potential and like what I see. Solid RPG straight up.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a gleaming reminder of what made me fall in love with RPG's over a dozen years ago. Like Fallout, Planescape and Baulder's Gate before it, it boasts a great combat system, charming characters, memorable music and a living, breathing world to adventure in. There are a few modern improvements though, like more physics-based interactions with the environment and a good amount of depth in character creation and development. My only complaints would be that in its current (beta) form, some of the animations are a bit clunky and fully voiced dialogue is extremely sparse. Those issues are soon forgotten, as the game does an excellent job of immersing you in its world. NPCs will talk to eachother often, and the game finds a great balance between witty humor and interesting banter. Your party members will speak up and comment on things, giving them life and value. Player choice affects not only the story, but how your own party members view you. Early in the game, I found myself delving in dungeons that I could have easily skipped, stealing items from a shop while using a party member to distract them, and killing people that didn't need to die just because they were rude to me. It's those kind of things that pull you in and keep you up late at night.If you like Diablo, Elder Scrolls and classics like Fallout, you will almost certainly like this game. And the fact that a game this deep has online co-op is fantastic. I could go on and on, but I've just scratched the surface and the game is calling me back. Can't wait for the full version!

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Good RPG for about 60-80 hours, especially since market lacks good team-based RPGs with turn, tactical combat. Humor and very well made world interaction are additional pros.Game suffer a bit from losing momentum after 2/3 and "nerfing spree" of devs - since small group of people on official forums constantly demands nerfs of various elements, skills, traits and mechanics (because they find game too easy, even on highest difficulty - I found it quite okay and fitting, nothing too hard and nothing "clearing itself"), devs are mostly focused on that aspect, apparently forgetting about additional companions and other features they promised. I finished game before that happened, but if you would run into heavy reduced resistances or find something like "glass cannon" reducing hp by 80% instead of 50%, while giving +2 AP instead of 2x AP per turn, then you will know who to thank for that.But since I cleared the game withing ~75 hours and I dont regret playing, I dare to say that it is still good product. After all, games should be all about fun, right?

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												The art assets are pretty sharp and colorful. The dialogue is good and the choices are interesting. Though a lot of the text it isn't voiced, the game still has great voice work. There are still quite a lot of bugs in this game: Some quests cannot be finished if you try to finish them in a certain way.Sometimes the designers didn't forsee you trying to solve a quest in a specific way, making the dialogue between the questgiver and player incorrect.Sometimes savedgames can get corrupted (this can however be attributed to certain mods screwing things up) so save regularly.The game can crash to desktop at times (also can be attributed to mods).All in all it's a great game and although I'd recommend playing this game on your own pace, I'd still say it is an amazing game to play with friends! A good mod choice for this game would be Fourplay, so you can have up to 4 people playing together rather than only 2.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												This game captures the spirit of Baldurs Gate perfectly!I even would go so far and say it is better. Graphics are really good and it runs flawless on my machine. The music is not superepic but fits in nicely in all the areas.Although there is almost no voice-acting the dialogues are well written and there is plenty to explore if you are interested in the lore!Where the game REALLY shines is the tactical combat. It starts out very good and gets better and better and better.At level 10 you have so many spells and skills and every single one is usable either with the enviorment or works as a catalyst with other spells - this is the best tactical combat I have EVER experienced!I don't know how huge D:OS is. The world just invites me to explore (no quest markers, no quest compass - you have to THINK!) and I cannot remember the last time a game has hooked me in that level. After 22 hours I finished everything around the first village - and that is when the story begins!The quests have a wide reach from funny to creative to combat to explore.And the best thing : If you think of a creative way to solve quests or riddle-situations (there are a lot!) - it usually works!I did not experience a single situation in which I thought "damn, this HAD to work now, but it didn't!"And it gets better and better : This game is actually playable in coop from start to finish! Hell, it is MEANT to be played cooperatively!In addition to the 2 main characters you can recruit 2 more heros. The downside is that these are not customizeable but there are so many options to choose from that it does not really matter, because you can branch them out any way you like anyway.There are no classes in this game, so feel free to experiment. I would even recommend to do so. For example one of my characters started out as a healer and is now a 2hand-tank-cleric-witch and extremely powerfull! This game rewards you to play a hybrid, not like other games! Even with just 1 point in witchcraft (for example) you can use a high-lvl witchcraft spell, but have to pay more action-points to use it in combat. This is just an awesome system!Every npc you meet - and sometimes enemies as well - want to trade stuff with you!If you have a rogue in your party (which I also recommend!) you will spend hours and hours to steal all the good stuff from the nice people in the towns ^^ But beware - if you get cought, you will have to fight. I would recommend loading a quicksave if that happens.Oh, and have you ever been angry about doors in other games? Or chests that you do not have a key for?In D:OS everything works as it logically should : burn down a door with mighty fire-spells, break a chest with your sword or even put a chest in your inventory for later, if you hope to find a key! That is just PURE AWESOMENESS!You can even teleport things like barrels and crates around! Block enemys with them, put an oil-barrel from your inventory next to a boss, ignite the oil and then cast a rain-spell to transform the burning field into a steamcloud followed by a lightning strike that will stun all the wet enemies at once! But beware - such a reaction can hit your party too, with your OWN spells! So always pay attention to positioning!I could go on and on and on, this game had me hooked from the start and I did not have it in my "interesting game"-list.Check it out, play it, you won't regret it! This is VERY VERY hard competition for pillars of eternity, wasteland 2 and torment 2.I will close my review now - this is the 4th night in which I stayed up untill 6am, because the game is so great!GET-IT-NOW!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is CRPG done right: non-linear questing, meaningful character development, deep turn based tactical combat, a consistently interactive world, cool loot, crafting, lore, humour, etc. I cannot thank the developers enough for the commitment they had to bringing a quality modern-day successor to old-school crpgs. The game literally feels like it combined the best and most complex systems of older rpgs, and then upgraded them while adding a few original twists to them. It has the tactical combat of something like the temple of elemental evil (perhaps a bit more streamlined, but superior in depth and challenge), the interactive world of something like fallout 1 or 2 (but again, with much better implemented and more varied systems), the lore and scope of the likes of baldur's gate 2, and more than a few new ideas of its own to keep things interesting. And most importantly, everything ties in well together to form a coherent, consistent sand box of rpg experimentation. Be warned however! This game requires an insane commitment of time and attention. There are so many things to micromanage. But that is exactly what I love about it. It is not a simple matter of grinding until your numbers are high enough. It rewards patience, exploration, experimentation and careful decision making. It is entirely possible to screw yourself over completely in this game... which again, makes for an awesome role playing experience. Progress does not come swiftly or at a steady pace. There may long stretches of time when you are just trying to figure out the best way to outfit your characters. You might spend an hour navigating a house full of traps and figuring out how to get all of the loot without blowing yourself up. You might spend some time learning recipes and crafting items. You might be reloading the same battle 5-10 times. There are literally endless possibilities of both emergent and prescripted gameplay...I can only hope that Larian studios, as well as other developers, get the message and start making more games like these.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Without a doubt, one of the most merciless, and greatest games ever. It's so content rich tha I've logged over 30 hours into the game, and haven't even progressed in the main storyline too much. The quest system is lacking, and there is little in the way of waypoints/markers on the map, but that help adds to the fun of exploring on your own, really bringing the game to life. The lack of direction makes you read all the books you find, learn the lore of the game, and most importantly, finally progress in the story. The loot amount dropped is nothing short of fantastic, as even after a smallish battle, there are several pieces of loot that make that battle worth it. Combat is turn based, which adds a new degree of difficuty to the game, like in chess, you have to think several turns ahead. I dont want to get to long in detail, but this game is worth the 40 without a doubt, 10/10, wihtout a doubt, several small bugs, but not enough to take away from the gameplay. Serioulsy, Buy it. Buy it now

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												let me preface this review by saying that this is one of the best games that i have had the pleasure of playing, period.you start by making a character. this is the most dissapointing part of the game since there are few options to customize your characters. you also must chose their classes. this is the hardest part of the game because if you chose two classes that dont work well together than you are completely and utterly screwed. now that thats out of the way lets do pros and cons :DCONS:- trial and error when creating and choosing classes- the difficulty may be off-putting to some people- if you want cool armor for your melee character then you have to choose a male, the female armor pales in comparison- lots of reading (not a con for me but it might bother some people)PROS:- a large world- LOOT- character progression that could be compared to dark souls - turn based combat (unless thats not you're thing)- modding - inspired art styleworth a buy for the current price. i might have to make another steam account just so i can buy it a second time#GOTY #BUCKETHELMETS #STEAMDOESNTDOHASHTAGS #THATLASTONEMIGHTHAVEBEENABITLONG #IF THIS GAME WERE  A PERSON I WOULD BE JEALOUS OF THAT PERSON #FINDTHEODDONEOUT #TOOMANYHASHTAGS #IHATEMYSELF
